pages.title: ݙ
pages.text:
{{Arabic-script sidebar|Saraiki}}

{{SpecialChars}}

'''<big>ݙ</big>''' is an additional letter of the [[Arabic script]], not used in the [[Arabic alphabet]] itself but used in [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]] to represent a [[voiced alveolar implosive]], {{IPAblink|ɗ}}.
Its other form is also found in Saraiki Spoken in [[Jhang]] in the form of [[voiced retroflex implosive]], {{IPAblink|ᶑ}}.

It is written as [[ॾ]] in Saraiki and Sindhi's Devanagari orthography.
It is derived from [[dāl]] (د), with a small [[ṭāʼ]] (ط) above to represent [[retroflex consonant|retroflexion]] (as in [[Urdu language|Urdu]]), and two [[dot (diacritic)|dots]] below to represent [[implosive consonant|implosion]] (as in [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]]). The unicode for saraiki letter '''ݙ''' was approved in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/0759/index.htm|title=Unicode Character 'ARABIC LETTER DAL WITH TWO DOTS VERTICALLY BELOW AND SMALL TAH' (U+0759)|website=www.fileformat.info}}</ref>

==Forms==
The letter ݙ has 2 forms.
{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ݙ}}
It may not rendered or joined if you are using a custom [[font]] because it's in [[Arabic Supplement|Arabic Supplement block]] but not [[Arabic (Unicode block)|Arabic block]]. Some [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] users also won’t render because [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] is using various [[font]] to render Arabic text. For other uses, go to see [[Help:Arabic]].

pages.title: Ḍād
pages.text: '''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ḍād}}''' ({{lang|ar|ﺽ}}), is one of the six letters the [[Arabic alphabet]] added to the twenty-two inherited from the [[Phoenician alphabet]] (the others being {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ṯāʾ]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ḫāʾ]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ḏāl]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ẓāʾ]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ghain|ġayn]]}}). In name and shape, it is a variant of {{transl|ar|DIN|[[tsade|ṣād]]}}. Its numerical value is 800 (see [[Abjad numerals]]). The sound it represented at the time of the introduction of the Arabic alphabet is somewhat uncertain, likely a [[pharyngealization|pharyngealized]] [[voiced alveolar lateral fricative]] {{audio-IPA|Voiced pharyngealized alveolar lateral fricative.ogg|[ɮˤ]}} or a similar [[affricate]]d sound {{IPAblink|d͡ɮ|d͡ɮˤ}} or {{IPAblink|d͡ɮ|dˡˤ}}. In contemporary Arabic, it may represent a [[pharyngealization|pharyngealized]] [[voiced alveolar stop]] {{audio-IPA|Voiced_pharyngealized_alveolar_stop.ogg|[dˤ]}}, pharyngealized voiced dental stop {{IPAblink|d̪|d̪ˤ}} or [[velarization|velarized]] voiced dental stop {{IPAblink|d̪|d̪ˠ}}. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|ض}} ==Origin== Based on ancient descriptions of this sound, it is clear that in [[Classical Arabic|Qur'anic Arabic]] ''ḍ'' was some sort of unusual [[lateral consonant|lateral]] sound. [[Sibawayh]], author of the first book on [[Arabic grammar]], explained the letter as being articulated from "between the first part of the side of the tongue and the adjoining [[Molar (tooth)|molars]]". It is reconstructed by modern linguists as having been either a [[pharyngealization|pharyngealized]] [[voiced alveolar lateral fricative]] {{audio-IPA|Voiced pharyngealized alveolar lateral fricative.ogg|[ɮˤ]}} or a similar [[affricate]]d sound {{IPAblink|d͡ɮ|d͡ɮˤ}} or {{IPAblink|d͡ɮ|dˡˤ}}. The affricated form is suggested by loans of ''ḍ'' into Akkadian as ''ld'' or ''lṭ'' and into Malaysian as ''dl''. However, not all linguists agree on this; the French orientalist André Roman supposes that the letter was actually a voiced emphatic alveolo-palatal sibilant {{IPAslink|ʑ|ʑˤ}}, similar to the Polish ''[[ź]]''. This is an extremely unusual sound, and led the early Arabic grammarians to describe Arabic as the {{lang|ar|لغة الضاد}} ''lughat aḍ-ḍād'' "the language of the ''ḍād''", since the sound was thought to be unique to Arabic. The emphatic lateral nature of this sound is possibly inherited from [[Proto-Semitic]], and is compared to a phoneme in [[South Semitic]] languages such as [[Mehri language|Mehri]] (where it is usually an [[ejective consonant|ejective]] [[lateral fricative]]). The corresponding letter in the [[South Arabian alphabet]] is [[File:himjar za2.PNG|14px|ḍ]] {{transl|sem|ṣ́}}, and in [[Ge'ez alphabet]] '''{{transl|sem|Ṣ́appa}}''' ፀ), although in [[Ge'ez language|Ge'ez]] it merged early on with ''{{transl|sem|ṣ}}.'' The reconstruction of [[Proto-Semitic language|Proto-Semitic]] phonology includes an emphatic [[voiceless alveolar lateral fricative]] {{IPAblink|ɬ|ɬʼ}} or [[Ejective alveolar lateral affricate|affricate]] {{IPAblink|tɬ|t͡ɬʼ}} for ''{{transl|sem|ṣ́}}''. This sound is considered to be the direct ancestor of Arabic ''{{transl|ar|DIN|ḍād}}'', while merging with {{transl|sem|ṣād}} in most other [[Semitic languages]]. The letter itself is distinguished a derivation, by addition of a [[Arabic diacritics|diacritic dot]], from [[ص]] ''ṣād'' (representing /sˤ/). ==Pronunciation== [[File:The_main_Pronunciations_of_written_ض_in_Arabic_dialects.png|thumb|The main pronunciations of written {{angbr|{{lang|ar|ض}}}} in Arabic dialects.|500x500px]] The standard pronunciation of this letter in modern [[Standard Arabic]] is the "[[emphatic consonant|emphatic]]" {{IPA|/d/}}: [[pharyngealization|pharyngealized]] [[voiced alveolar stop]] {{audio-IPA|Voiced_pharyngealized_alveolar_stop.ogg|[dˤ]}}, pharyngealized voiced dental stop {{IPAblink|d̪|d̪ˤ}} or [[velarization|velarized]] voiced dental stop {{IPAblink|d̪|d̪ˠ}}. In most Bedouin influenced Arabic vernaculars {{lang|ar|ض}} ''ḍād'' and {{lang|ar|ظ}} ''[[ẓāʾ]]'' have been merged quite early. like in the varieties (such as [[Bedouin Arabic|Bedouin]] and [[Mesopotamian Arabic|Iraqi]]), where the dental fricatives are preserved, both the letters are pronounced {{IPA|/ðˤ/}}. However, there are dialects in South Arabia and in [[Hassaniya Arabic|Mauritania]] where both the letters are kept different but not in all contexts. In other vernaculars such as Egyptian the distinction between {{lang|ar|ض}} ''ḍād'' and {{lang|ar|ظ}} ''[[ẓāʾ]]'' is most of the time made; but Classical Arabic ''ẓāʾ'' often becomes {{IPA|/zˤ/}}, e.g. ''ʿaẓīm'' (< Classical {{lang|ar|عظيم}} ''ʿaḏ̣īm'') "great". "De-emphaticized" pronunciation of the both letters in the form of the plain {{IPA|/z/}} entered into other non-Arabic languages such as Persian, Urdu, Turkish. However, there do exist Arabic borrowings into [[Ibero-Romance languages]] as well as Hausa and Malay, where ''ḍād'' and ''ẓāʾ'' are differentiated. ==Transliteration== {{lang|ar|ض}} is transliterated as ''ḍ'' ([[D]] with [[dot (diacritic)|underdot]]) in [[romanization of Arabic|romanization]]. When transliterating Arabic in the Hebrew alphabet, it is either written as {{Hebrew|[[ד]]}} (the letter for {{IPAslink|d}}) or as [[Romanization of Hebrew#فغغTable|{{Hebrew|צ׳}}]] (''[[tsadi]]'' with [[geresh]]). ==Unicode== {{charmap |0636|name1=Arabic Letter Dad }} ==See also== *[[Arabic phonology]] *{{transl|sem|[[Sat (letter)|Sat]]}} *{{transl|sem|[[Śawt]]}} *{{transl|ar|DIN|[[Ḍ]]}} ==References== {{cite journal|last1=Ferguson|first1=Charles|title=The Arabic koine|journal=Language|date=1959|volume=35|issue=4|page=630|doi=10.2307/410601|url=}} {{cite book|last1=Ferguson|first1=Charles Albert|editor1-last=Belnap|editor1-first=R. Kirk|editor2-last=Haeri|editor2-first=Niloofar|title=Structuralist studies in Arabic linguistics: Charles A. Ferguson's papers, 1954–1994|date=1997|orig-year=1959|publisher=Brill|isbn=9004105115|pages=67–68|chapter=The Arabic koine|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l03h94vqCQMC&pg=PA67}} {{cite book|last1=Roman|first1=André|title=Étude de la phonologie et de la morphologie de la koiné arabe|date=1983|publisher=Université de Provence|location=Aix-en-Provence|volume=1|pages=162–206}} {{cite book|last1=Versteegh|first1=Kees|title=The Arabic language|date=2003|orig-year=1997|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=Edinburgh|isbn=9780748614363|page=89|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OHfse3YY6NAC&pg=PA89|edition=Repr.}} {{cite book|last1=Versteegh|first1=Kees|editor1-last=Arazi|editor1-first=Albert|editor2-last=Sadan|editor2-first=Joseph|editor3-last=Wasserstein|editor3-first=David J.|title=Compilation and Creation in Adab and Luġa: Studies in Memory of Naphtali Kinberg (1948–1997)|date=1999|pages=273–286|chapter=Loanwords from Arabic and the merger of ḍ/ḏ̣ |chapter-url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=hNNHi_RdJ1MC&pg=PA273}} {{cite book|last1=Versteegh|first1=Kees|editor1-last=Kinberg|editor1-first=Leah|editor2-last=Versteegh|editor2-first=Kees|title=Studies in the Linguistic Structure of Classical Arabic|date=2000|publisher=Brill|isbn=9004117652|pages=197–199|chapter=Treatise on the pronunciation of the ''ḍād''|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_EJ861jo4AQC&pg=PA197}} {{cite book|last=Retsö|first=Jan|editor-last=Weninger|editor-first=Stefan|title=The Semitic Languages: An International Handbook|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SMzgBLT87MkC&pg=PA786|year=2012|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-025158-6|pages=785–786|chapter=Classical Arabic}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dad}} [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Ge'ez language]]

[[File:The_main_Pronunciations_of_written_ذ_in_Arabic_dialects.png|thumb|The main pronunciations of written {{angbr|{{lang|ar|ذ}}}} in Arabic dialects.|500x500px]]

'''''{{Transl|ar|DIN|Ḏāl}}''''' ({{lang|ar|ذ}}, also be transcribed as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|dhāl}}'') is one of the six letters the [[Arabic alphabet]] added to the twenty-two inherited from the [[Phoenician alphabet]] (the others being {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ṯāʾ]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ḫāʾ]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ḍād]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ẓāʾ]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ġayn]]}}). In [[Modern Standard Arabic]] it represents {{IPAslink|ð}}. In name and shape, it is a variant of {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[dāl]]}} ({{Lang|ar|د}}). Its numerical value is 700 (see [[abjad numerals]]). The Arabic letter {{lang|ar|ذ}} is named {{lang|ar|ذال}} ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|ḏāl}}''. It is written is several ways depending in its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|ذ}}
The [[South Arabian alphabet]] retained a symbol for {{Transl|sem|ḏ}}, [[Image:himjar dhal.PNG|14px]].

When representing this sound in transliteration of Arabic into Hebrew, it is written as {{Hebrew|ד׳}}.

This sound is found in English, as in the words "'''th'''ose" or "'''th'''en". In English the sound is normally rendered "[[Pronunciation respelling for English|dh]]" when transliterated from foreign languages, but when it occurs in English words it is one of the pronunciations occurring for the letters "[[Th (digraph)|th]]".

== Pronunciations ==
Between and within contemporary [[varieties of Arabic]], pronunciation of the letter ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|ḏāl}}'' differs:

* The [[Gulf Arabic|Gulf]], [[Iraqi Arabic|Iraqi]], [[Tunisian Arabic|Tunisian]] dialects use the [[Classical Arabic|Classical]] and [[Modern Standard Arabic|Modern Standard]] sound of  {{IPAblink|ð}}.
* In [[Maghrebi Arabic]], it is consistently pronounced as the [[voiced dental plosive]] {{IPAblink|d̪}}.
* In [[Hejazi Arabic]], it merges with {{IPAslink|d}} or {{IPAslink|z}} depending on the word. Furthermore it keeps its classical value  {{IPAslink|ð}} in some Classical Arabic words.
* In the [[Mashriq]] (in the broad sense, including [[Egyptian Arabic phonology|Egyptian]], [[Sudanese Arabic|Sudanese]] and [[Levantine Arabic|Levantine]] dialects), it becomes a [[sibilant]] [[voiced alveolar fricative]] {{IPAblink|z}}. Furthermore, in words fully assimilated into a Mashriq dialect, the sound has merged with {{IPAslink|d}} ({{lang|ar|[[د]]}}).

Regardless of these regional differences, the pattern of the speaker's variety of Arabic frequently intrudes into otherwise Modern Standard speech; this is widely accepted, and is the norm when speaking the [[mesolect]] known alternately as ''lugha wusṭā'' ("middling/compromise language") or ''ʿAmmiyyat/Dārijat al-Muṯaqqafīn'' ("Educated/Cultured Colloquial") used in the informal speech of educated Arabs of different countries. (cf. [[Arabic dialect#Formal vs. vernacular speech]])

pages.title: Ghayn
pages.text:
{{distinguish|text=[[Ghayn (Cyrillic)|Ғ (Ghayn), a Cyrillic letter]]}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox grapheme |name=Ghayn |letter=غ |variations= |image= |imagesize=200 |imagealt= |script=[[Arabic script]] |type=[[Abjad]] |typedesc= |language=[[Arabic language]] |phonemes= |unicode= |alphanumber=4 |number=1 |fam1=V28 |fam2=𓎛 |fam3=[[File:Ghayn.svg|20px|Proto-Sinaitic Ghayin]] |fam4=[[File:Protoghayn.svg|20px|Proto-Caananite Ghayin]] |fam5=[[File:Phoenician_ayin.svg|20px|Phoenician Ayin]] |fam6=[[File:Ayin.svg|20px|Aramaic ayn]] |fam7=[[File:16_ein.svg|20px|Nabatean ein]] |fam8=[[ع]] |usageperiod= |children= |equivalents= |associates= |direction=Right-to-left }} {{Arabic-script sidebar}} The Arabic letter {{lang|ar|غ}} ({{lang-ar|غين}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ghayn}}'' or ''{{transl|ar|DIN|ġayn}}'') is the nineteenth letter of the [[Arabic alphabet]], one of the six letters not in the twenty-two akin to the [[Phoenician alphabet]] (the others being {{transl|ar|ALA|[[Ṯāʾ|thāʼ]]}}, {{transl|ar|ALA|[[Ḫāʾ|khāʼ]]}}, {{transl|ar|ALA|[[Ḏāl|dhāl]]}}, {{transl|ar|ALA|[[ḍād]]}}, {{transl|ar|ALA|[[ẓāʼ]]}}), it represents the sound {{IPAslink|ɣ}} or {{IPAslink|ʁ}}. In name and shape, it is a variant of [[ayin|ʻayn]] ({{lang|ar|ع}}). Its numerical value is 1000 (see [[Abjad numerals]]). In the Persian language it represents {{IPAblink|ɣ}}~{{IPAblink|ɢ}} and is the twenty-second letter in the new [[Persian alphabet]]. A [[voiced velar fricative]] {{IPA|/ɣ/}} or a [[voiced uvular fricative]] {{IPA|/ʁ/}} (usually reconstructed for [[Proto-Semitic]]) merged with ʻ[[ayin]] in most languages except for Arabic, [[Ugaritic]], and older varieties of the [[Canaanite languages]]. Canaanite languages and Hebrew later also merged it with ʻayin, and this merger was complete in [[Tiberian Hebrew]]. The [[South Arabian alphabet]] retained a symbol for ''{{transl|sem|ġ}},'' 𐩶. Biblical Hebrew, as of the 3rd century BCE, apparently still distinguished the phonemes ġ /ʁ/ and ḫ /χ/, based on transcriptions in the [[Septuagint]]. (example: [[Sodom and Gomorrah|Gomorrah]] is represented in Hebrew as {{Hebrew|עֲמֹרָה}}, which sounds like ''‘Ămōrāh'' in Modern Hebrew; however, the Greek transcription of ''Γομορραν'', ''Gomoras'', suggests that at this point in time the Hebrew lemma was still pronounced as ''Ġămōrāh'') The letter ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ghayn}}'' ({{lang|ar|غ}}) is sometimes used to represent the [[voiced velar plosive]] {{IPA|/ɡ/}} in loan words and names in Arabic and is then often pronounced {{IPA|/ɡ/}}, not {{IPA|/ɣ/}}. Other letters, such as [[gimel|{{script/Arabic|ج}}]], [[qāf|{{script/Arabic|ق}}]], [[kāf|{{script/Arabic|ک/ك}}]] (also {{lang|ar|[[gaf|گ]]}}, {{script/Arabic|[[ݣ]]}}, {{script/Arabic|[[ݢ]]}}, {{script/Arabic|ڨ}}, {{script/Arabic|ڠ}}, instead of the original [[Arabic letters]]), can be used to transcribe {{IPAslink|ɡ}} in loan words and names, depending on whether the local [[varieties of Arabic|variety of Arabic]] in the country has the phoneme {{IPAslink|ɡ}}, which letter represents it if it does, and on whether it is customary in the country to use that letter to transcribe {{IPAslink|ɡ}}. For instance, in Egypt, where {{lang|ar|ج}} is pronounced as {{IPAblink|ɡ}} in all situations, even when speaking Modern Standard Arabic (except in certain contexts, such as reciting the [[Qur'an]]), {{lang|ar|ج}} is used to transcribe foreign {{IPAblink|ɡ}} in virtually all contexts. In many cases {{lang|ar|غ}} is pronounced in loan words as expected—{{IPAslink|ɣ}}, not {{IPAslink|ɡ}}—even though the original language had {{IPAslink|ɡ}}. When representing this sound in transliteration of Arabic into Hebrew, it is written as ע׳. In English, the letter {{lang|ar|غ}} in Arabic names is usually transliterated as ‹{{transl|ar|ALA|gh}}›, ‹{{transl|ar|DIN|ġ}}›, or simply ‹g›, e.g. {{lang|ar|بغداد}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Baghdād}}'' '[[Baghdad]]', or {{lang|ar|غزة}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Ghazzah}}'' '[[Gaza City|Gaza]]', the latter of which does not render the sound {{IPAblink|ɣ}}~{{IPAblink|ʁ}} accurately. The closest equivalent sound known to most English speakers is the [[Standard French|Parisian]] [[French language|French]] "[[French r|r]]" {{IPAblink|ʁ}}. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Ghayn}}'' is written is several ways depending in its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|غ}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! width="14%" | Proto-Semitic ! width="14%" | [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] ! width="14%" colspan="2" | [[Arabic language|Arabic]] ! width="14%" colspan="2" | [[Canaanite language|Canaanite]] ! width="14%" colspan="2" | [[Tiberian Hebrew|Hebrew]] ! width="14%" colspan="2" | [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] ! width="14%" colspan="2" | [[South Arabian alphabet|South Arabian]] ! width="14%" colspan="2" | [[Ge'ez language|Geʻez]] |- ! {{transl|sem|ġ}} | - | {{lang|ar|غ}} || {{transl|ar|ALA|gh}} | [[Image:phoenician ayin.png|16px]] || {{transl|sem|ġ, ʻ}} | {{lang|he|ע}} || {{transl|he|ʻ}} | {{lang|he|ע}} || {{transl|he|ʻ}} | [[Image:Himjar ghajn.PNG|16px]] || {{transl|sem|ġ}} | ዐ || {{transl|sem|ʻ}} |- |} ==Character encodings== {{charmap |063A|name1=Arabic Letter Ghain |FECD|name2=Arabic Letter Ghain
isolated form |FECE|name3=Arabic Letter Ghain

pages.title: Gueh
pages.text:
{{Arabic-script sidebar|Saraiki}}

{{SpecialChars}}
'''<big>ڳ</big>''',  (Arabic letter gueh (U+06B3)),  is an additional letter of the [[Arabic script]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://graphemica.com/%DA%B3|title=ڳ | arabic letter gueh (U+06B3) @ Graphemica|website=graphemica.com}}</ref> not used in the [[Arabic alphabet]] itself but used in [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] and [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]] to represent a [[voiced velar implosive]], {{IPAblink|ɠ}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://unicode-table.com/en/06B3/ |title=ڳ - Arabic Letter Gueh (U+06B3) symbol, character, sign, icon, html: ڳ - Arabic - Unicode® character table |website=Unicode-table.com |date= |accessdate=2017-04-05}}</ref> It is written as [[ॻ]] in Saraiki and Sindhi's Devanagari orthography

==Compound of ڳ ==

The '''velar nasal''' is a type of [[consonant]]al sound, used in [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] and [[Saraiki language]] and other some [[Speech communication|spoken]] [[language]]s.It is compound of 'ن' and 'ڳ'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://saraikist.blogspot.com/2014/10/blog-post_4.html|title=Saraikistan: سرائیکی دے خاص حروف|first=پرویز|last=قادر|date=October 4, 2014}}</ref> It is the sound of ''ng'' in English ''si'''ng'''''. The symbol in the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]] that represents this sound is {{angbr IPA|ŋ}}, and the equivalent [[X-SAMPA]] symbol is <tt>N</tt>. The IPA symbol {{angbr IPA|ŋ}} is similar to {{angbr IPA|ɳ}}, the symbol for the [[retroflex nasal]], which has a rightward-pointing hook extending from the bottom of the right stem, and to {{angbr IPA|ɲ}}, the symbol for the [[palatal nasal]], which has a leftward-pointing hook extending from the bottom of the left stem. Both the IPA symbol and the sound are commonly called '[[Eng (letter)|eng]]' or 'engma'.

[[File:The_main_Pronunciations_of_written_ث_in_Arabic_dialects.png|thumb|The main pronunciations of written {{angbr|{{lang|ar|ث}}}} in Arabic dialects.|500x500px]]
'''{{Transl|ar|DIN|Ṯāʾ}}''' ({{Lang|ar|ث}}) is one of the six letters the [[Arabic alphabet]] added to the twenty-two from the [[Phoenician alphabet]] (the others being {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ḫāʾ]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ḏāl]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ḍād]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ẓāʾ]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[ġayn]]}}). In [[Modern Standard Arabic]] it represents the [[voiceless dental fricative]] {{IPAblink|θ}}, also found in English as the "[[Th (digraph)|th]]" in words such as "think" and "thin". In name and shape, it is a variant of {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[tāʾ]]}} ({{lang|ar|ت}}). Its numerical value is 500 (see [[Abjad numerals]]).

The Arabic letter {{lang|ar|ث}} is named {{lang|ar|ثاء}} ''ṯāʾ''. It is written is several ways depending in its position in the word:
{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ث}}

In contemporary spoken Arabic, pronunciation of ṯāʾ as {{IPAblink|θ}} is found in the Arabian Peninsula, Iraqi, and Tunisian and other dialects and in highly educated pronunciations of Modern Standard and Classical Arabic. Pronunciation of the letter varies between and within the various [[varieties of Arabic]]: while it is consistently pronounced as the [[voiceless dental plosive]] {{IPAblink|t}} in [[Maghrebi Arabic]] (except Tunisian and eastern Libyan), on the other hand in the Arabic varieties of the [[Mashriq]] (in the broad sense, including Egyptian, Sudanese and Levantine) and [[Hejazi Arabic]], it can be pronounced as either {{IPAblink|t}} or as the [[sibilant]] [[voiceless alveolar fricative]] {{IPAblink|s}}. Depending on the word in question, words pronounced as {{IPAblink|s}} are generally more technical or "sophisticated." Regardless of these regional differences, the pattern of the speaker's variety of Arabic frequently intrudes into otherwise Modern Standard speech; this is widely accepted, and is the norm when speaking the [[mesolect]] known alternately as ''lugha wusṭā'' ("middling/compromise language") or ''ʿAmmiyyat/Dārijat al-Muṯaqqafīn'' ("Educated/Cultured Colloquial") used in the informal speech of educated Arabs of different countries.

When representing this sound in transliteration of Arabic into Hebrew, it is written as ת׳.

==Common Semitic perspective==
The choice of the letter ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|[[tāʾ]]}}'' as the base for this letter was not due to etymology (see [[History of the Arabic alphabet]]), but rather due to phonetic similarity. For other Semitic cognates of the phoneme ''{{Transl|sem|ṯ}}'' see [[Proto-Semitic language#Sound changes between Proto-Semitic and the daughter languages|Sound changes between Proto-Semitic and the daughter languages]].

The  [[South Arabian alphabet]] retained a symbol for ''{{Transl|sem|ṯ}}''.

Ve (Arabic letter)
pages.text:
[[File:Arabisch-Afrikaans.jpg|thumb|right|323x323px|South African text from 1872 by [[Abu Bakr Effendi]] in [[Arabic Afrikaans]] (upper) and Arabic (lower) showing The ''ve'' in the word ڤوت (vote) used in Arabic even though the Modern Standard Arabic word for (vote) is صوت {{IPA|/sˤawt/}}.]]
'''Ve''' or '''Vāʾ''' (based on name of the letter <big>{{lang|ar|ﻑ}}</big> {{transl|ar|DIN|[[Pe (letter)#Arabic fāʼ|fāʾ]]}}) <big>{{script/Arabic|ڤ}}</big> is a letter of the Arabic-based [[Kurdish alphabets#Sorani alphabet|Sorani]], [[Comoro language|Comoro]], [[Wakhi language|Wakhi]], [[Jawi script|Malay Arabic]], Karakhanid alphabets derived from the [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic letter]] {{transl|ar|DIN|[[Pe (letter)#Arabic fāʼ|fāʾ]]}} (<big>{{lang|ar|ﻑ}}</big>) with two additional [[dot (diacritic)|dots]]. It represents the sound {{IPAslink|v}} for all alphabets, except for Malay.

It is sometimes used in [[Arabic language]] to write names and loanwords with the phoneme {{IPAslink|v}}, such as <big>{{lang|ar|ڤولڤو}}</big> ([[Volvo]]) and <big>{{lang|ar|ڤيينا}}</big> ''viyenna'' ([[Vienna]]), but rather described, for example, in [[Egyptian Arabic]], it is called ''{{transl|arz|fe be talat noʾaṭ}}'' ({{lang|arz|فه بتلات نقط}}, "F with three dots").

It is also frequently used in [[Israel]] for transcribing names that have a {{IPAslink|v}} sound into Arabic, which is used on Israel's street plates, on signs and labels.

In [[Jawi script]], used for Malay language, <big>{{script/Arabic|ڤ}}</big> stands for {{IPAslink|p}}.

The character is mapped in [[Unicode]] under position U+06A4.
{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ڤ}}

== Similar-looking letter ==
[[File:Tunisian Cookie Packaging.jpg|205x205px|thumb|Tunisian cookie packaging, showing a three-dotted [[Qāf]] used to represent /g/ in the Arabic translite
ration of ''Galletes'' (''gālāt'').]]
The [[Maghrebi script|Maghrebi style]], used in Northwestern Africa, the dots moved underneath (Unicode U+06A5), because it is based on the other style of ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fāʼ}}'' (<big>{{script/Arabic|[[ف|ڢ]]}}</big>):{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ڥ}}
In [[Tunisian Arabic|Tunisian]] and in [[Languages of Algeria|Algerian]] {{Citation needed|date=January 2014}}, (<big>{{script/Arabic|ڨ}}</big><!--[[File:Tunisian-gaf.svg|11px]]-->, looks similar to <big>{{lang|ar|[[ق]]}}</big> but with three dots) is used for {{IPAslink|ɡ}}, such as in names of places or persons containing a [[voiced velar stop]], as in [[Gafsa]] (in [[Tunisia]]) or [[Guelma]] (in Algeria). If the usage of that letter is not possible for technical restrictions, ''[[qoph|qāf]]'' (<big>{{lang|ar|ق}}</big>) is often used instead.

In Arabic script representations of the [[Chechen language]], ڨ is used to represent the [[uvular ejective]] /q'/.
[[Image:Givat shmuel sign.png|thumb|right|200px|The ''ve'' (''fāʾ'' with three dots) in its medial form used in an [[Israel]]i roadsign on the road to [[Giv'at Shmuel]].]]

'''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ẓāʾ}}''', or '''{{transl|ar|DIN|ḏ̣āʾ}}''' ({{lang|ar|ظ}}), is one of the six letters the [[Arabic alphabet]] added to the twenty-two inherited from the [[Phoenician alphabet]] (the others being {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ṯāʾ]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ḫāʾ]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ḏāl]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ḍād]]}}, {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ghain|ġayn]]}}). 
In [[Classical Arabic]], it represents a [[Velarization|velarized]] voiced dental fricative {{IPAblink|ð|ðˠ}}, and in [[Modern Standard Arabic]], it can also be a [[Pharyngealization|pharyngealized]], {{IPAblink|ð|ðˤ}} voiced dental fricative or voiced alveolar fricative {{IPAblink|z|zˤ}}. 
In name and shape, it is a variant of {{transl|ar|DIN|[[ṭāʾ]]}}. Its numerical value is 900 (see [[Abjad numerals]]).

''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ẓāʾ}}'' does not change its shape depending on its position in the word:
{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ظ}}

== Pronunciation ==
[[File:The_main_Pronunciations_of_written_ظ_in_Arabic_dialects.png|thumb|The main pronunciations of written {{angbr|{{lang|ar|ظ}}}} in Arabic dialects.|500x500px]]
In [[Classical Arabic]], it represents a [[Velarization|velarized]] voiced dental fricative {{IPAblink|ð|ðˠ}}, and in [[Modern Standard Arabic]], it can also be a [[Pharyngealization|pharyngealized]], {{IPAblink|ð|ðˤ}} voiced dental fricative or voiced alveolar fricative {{IPAblink|z|zˤ}}. 

In most Arabic vernaculars {{lang|ar|ظ}} ''ẓāʾ'' and {{lang|ar|ض}} ''[[ḍād]]'' have been merged quite early.<ref name=Versteegh1999/> The outcome depends on the dialect. In those varieties (such as [[Egyptian Arabic|Egyptian]] and [[Levantine Arabic|Levantine]]), where the [[dental fricative]]s {{IPA|/θ/}}, {{IPA|/ð/}} are merged with the [[dental stop]]s {{IPA|/t/}}, {{IPA|/d/}}, ''ẓāʾ'' is pronounced {{IPA|/zˤ/}}; in the varieties (such as [[Bedouin Arabic|Bedouin]] and [[Mesopotamian Arabic|Iraqi]]), where the dental fricatives are preserved, ''ḍād'' and ''ẓāʾ'' are pronounced {{IPA|/ðˤ/}}.<ref name=Versteegh1999/><ref name=Versteegh2000/><ref name=Ferguson1959/><ref name=Ferguson1997/> However, there are dialects in South Arabia and in [[Hassaniya Arabic|Mauritania]] where both the letters are kept different.<ref name=Versteegh1999/> In loanwords from Classical Arabic ''ẓāʾ'' is often {{IPA|/zˤ/}}, e.g. Egyptian ''ʿaẓīm'' (< Classical {{lang|ar|عظيم}} ''ʿaḏ̣īm'') "great".<ref name=Versteegh1999/><ref name=Versteegh2000/><ref name="Retsö2012"/>

"De-emphaticized" pronunciation of the both letters in the form of the plain {{IPA|/z/}} entered into other non-Arabic languages such as Persian, Urdu, Turkish.<ref name=Versteegh1999/> However, there do exist Arabic borrowings into [[Ibero-Romance languages]] as well as Hausa and Malay, where ''ḍād'' and ''ẓāʾ'' are differentiated.<ref name=Versteegh1999/>

== Statistics ==
{{transl|ar|DIN|Ẓāʾ}} is the rarest phoneme of the Arabic language. Out of 2,967 triliteral roots listed by [[Hans Wehr]] in his [[Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic|1952 dictionary]], only 42 (1.4%) contain {{lang|ar|ظ}}.<ref name=Wehr/>

== In other Semitic languages ==
In some reconstructions of [[Proto-Semitic]] phonology, there is an [[emphatic consonant|emphatic]] interdental fricative, {{transl|sem|ṱ}} ({{IPAblink|θˤ}} or {{IPAblink|ðˤ}}), featuring as the direct ancestor of Arabic {{transl|ar|DIN|ẓāʾ}}, while it merged with {{transl|sem|[[ṣād|ṣ]]}} in most other [[Semitic languages]], although the  [[South Arabian alphabet]] retained a symbol for {{transl|sem|ẓ}}.

== Writing in the Hebrew alphabet ==
When representing this sound in transliteration of Arabic into Hebrew, it is written as {{lang|he|ט׳}}.

'''<big>ڄ</big>''', Arabic letter dyeh (U+0684),<ref>http://graphemica.com/%DA%84</ref>  is an additional letter of the [[Arabic script]], not used in the [[Arabic alphabet]] itself but used in [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] and [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]] to represent a [[voiced palatal implosive]], {{IPAblink|ʄ}}. It is written as [[ॼ]] in Saraiki and Sindhi's [[Devanagari]] orthography.

== Compound ڄ ==
When 'ن'& 'ڄ' are mixed and  'نڄ' is formed [[Palatal nasal]], {{IPAblink|ɲ}}. It is the sixth Special sound of [[Saraiki language]].<ref>http://saraikist.blogspot.com/2014/10/blog-post_4.html</ref> Some people used in last century Arabic letter nyeh '''ڃ''' (U+0683) for this compound.<ref>http://graphemica.com/%DA%83</ref> But now only   نڄ is used. For example, نڄ is used in '''ونڄ، تھنڄ۔'''

pages.text:
{{SpecialChars}}
{{Arabic-script sidebar|Saraiki}}

'''<big>ݨ</big>''' , (Arabic letter noon with small tah (U+0768)), is an additional letter of the [[Arabic script]],<ref>http://graphemica.com/%DD%A8</ref> not used in the [[Arabic alphabet]] itself but used in [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]] and [[Shina language|Shina]] to represent a [[retroflex nasal]] consonantat, {{IPAblink|ɳ}}.
'''[[ڼ]]''' is the twenty-ninth letter of [[Pashto alphabet]],Its represent the Velar nasal letter (IPA: [ɳ] ) or Ṇ in Latin Alphabets,Which is '''ण''' in [[Devanagari]].<ref>RAZAI CHE PUKHTO WALWALU (Pashto book)</ref>

It is '''retroflex nasal'''  [[consonant]]al sound  symbol, used in some [[Speech communication|spoken]] [[language]]s. The symbol in the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]] that represents this sound is {{angbr IPA|ɳ}}, and the equivalent [[X-SAMPA]] symbol is <tt>n`</tt>. Like all the [[retroflex consonant]]s, the IPA symbol is formed by adding a rightward-pointing hook extending from the bottom of an en (the letter used for the corresponding [[alveolar consonant]]). It is similar to {{angbr IPA|ɲ}}, the letter for the [[palatal nasal]], which has a leftward-pointing hook extending from the bottom of the left stem, and to {{angbr IPA|ŋ}}, the letter for the [[velar nasal]], which has a leftward-pointing hook extending from the bottom of the right stem.
The unicode for saraiki letter '''ݨ''' was approved in 2005.<ref>https://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/0759/index.htm</ref>
Saraiki uses the letter ⟨ݨ⟩ for {{IPAslink|ɳ}}. It is a compound of nūn and rre (⟨ڑ⟩). For example:
:''کݨ مݨ، چھݨ چھݨ، ونڄݨ۔''

Že
pages.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=September 2008}}

{{Arabic-script sidebar|Persian}}
'''Že''' (<big>{{lang|fa|ژ}}</big>) used to represent the phoneme {{IPA|/ʒ/}}, is a letter in the [[Perso-Arabic script|Perso-Arabic alphabet]], based on ''[[Zayin|{{transl|ar|DIN|zayn}}]]'' (<big>{{lang|ar|ز}}</big>) with two additional [[dot (diacritic)|diacritic dots]]. It is one of the four letters that the [[Persian alphabet]] adds to the original Arabic script, others being <big>{{lang|fa|چ}}</big> ,<big>{{lang|fa|پ}}</big> and <big>{{lang|fa|گ}}</big>.

It is found with this value in other Arabic-derived scripts. It is used in [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], other [[Iranian languages]], [[Uyghur Language|Uyghur]], [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] (J In modern [[Turkish alphabet]]), [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] and [[Urdu]], but not in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]. 

However, it might be used in Arabic texts to represent other phonemes when writing words with sounds not in Arabic letters. It is used to represent the sound {{IPAslink|ʒ}} or sometimes {{IPAslink|zˤ}}, just like the letter ''[[ẓāʼ]]'' (<big>{{lang|ar|ظ}}</big>). 

{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ژ}}

==Character encodings==

{{charmap
|0698|name1=Arabic Letter Jeh
}}
==In other scripts==
===Latin===
in [[English language|English]], the three letters {{angle|sio}} and the letter {{angle|s}} before {{angle|u}} are used for this sound, as in the words "televi'''sio'''n" and "plea'''s'''ure". In other languages using Latin script, the sound may be represented by {{angle|g}}, {{angle|j}}, {{angle|zh}}, {{angle|ž}},{{angle|zs}}, or {{angle|ż}}.

===[[Devanagari]]===
In [[Devanagari]] the letter झ़ (letter jha with nukta or Dot) is used to represent the sound of že. such as झ़ in टेलिविझ़न and झ़ाला बारी.

===[[Cyrillic]]===

The letter [[ж]], common in some [[Slavic languages]], has an equivalent sound to the "s" in "television" e.g. [[Zharkov]] ([[Russian Cyrillic]]: Жарков).

The '''Arabic script''' is the [[writing system]] used for writing [[Arabic]] and several other languages of Asia and Africa, such as [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Lurish language|Lurish]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]], [[Mandinka language|Mandinka]], and others.<ref>Mahinnaz Mirdehghan. 2010. Persian, Urdu, and Pashto: A comparative orthographic analysis. ''Writing Systems Research'' Vol. 2, No. 1, 9–23.</ref> Until the 16th century, it was also used to write some texts in [[Aljamiado|Spanish]]. Additionally, prior to the language reform in 1928, it was the writing system of [[Turkish language|Turkish]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bne.es/es/Micrositios/Exposiciones/MemoriaMoriscos/Obras/ |title=Exposición Virtual. Biblioteca Nacional de España |publisher=Bne.es |date= |accessdate=2012-04-06}}</ref> It is the second-[[List of writing systems by adoption|most widely used writing system]] in the world by the number of countries using it and the third by the number of users, after [[Latin script|Latin]] and [[Chinese characters]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/31666/Arabic-alphabet|title=Arabic Alphabet |accessdate=2015-05-16 |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica online| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150426185709/http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/31666/Arabic-alphabet| archivedate= 26 April 2015 | deadurl= no}}</ref>

The Arabic script is written from right to left in a [[cursive]] style. In most cases, the letters transcribe consonants, or consonants and a few vowels, so most Arabic alphabets are [[abjad]]s.

The script was first used to write texts in Arabic, most notably the [[Qur'an|{{transl|ar|ALA|Qurʼān}}]], the holy book of [[Islam]]. With the spread of Islam, it came to be used to write languages of many language families, leading to the addition of new letters and other symbols, with some versions, such as [[Kurdish alphabets#Sorani alphabet|Kurdish]], [[Uyghur Arabic alphabet|Uyghur]], and old [[Arebica|Bosnian]] being [[abugida]]s or true [[alphabet]]s. It is also the basis for the tradition of [[Arabic calligraphy]].

The Arabic script has been adapted for use in a wide variety of languages besides Arabic, including [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Malay language|Malay]], and [[Urdu language|Urdu]], which are not [[Semitic languages|Semitic]]. Such adaptations may feature altered or new characters to represent [[phoneme]]s that do not appear in Arabic [[phonology]]. For example, the Arabic language lacks a [[voiceless bilabial plosive]] (the {{IPA|[p]}} sound), so many languages add their own letter to represent {{IPA|[p]}} in the script, though the specific letter used varies from language to language. These modifications tend to fall into groups: all the [[India]]n and [[Turkic languages]] written in the Arabic script tend to use the [[Persian alphabet|Persian modified letters]], whereas the [[languages of Indonesia]] tend to imitate those of [[Jawi (script)|Jawi]]. The modified version of the Arabic script originally devised for use with Persian is known as the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]] by scholars.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}

In the cases of [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]],  [[Kurdish languages|Kurdish]], [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]], and [[Uyghur language|Uyghur]] [[writing system]]s, vowels are mandatory. The Arabic script can therefore be used in both [[abugida]] and [[abjad]], although it is often strongly if erroneously connected to the latter.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}

Use of the Arabic script in [[West Africa]]n languages, especially in the [[Sahel]], developed with the spread of [[Islam]]. To a certain degree the style and usage tends to follow those of the [[Maghreb]] (for instance the position of the dots in the letters ''[[Pe (letter)|{{transl|ar|ALA|fāʼ}}]]'' and ''[[Qoph|{{transl|ar|ALA|qāf}}]]''). Additional diacritics have come into use to facilitate writing of sounds not represented in the Arabic language. The term ''[[Ajami script|{{transl|ar|ALA|ʻAjamī}}]]'', which comes from the Arabic root for "foreign", has been applied to Arabic-based orthographies of African languages.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}

===Current use===
Today Afghanistan, Iran, India, Pakistan and China are the main non-Arabic speaking states using the Arabic alphabet to write one or more official national languages, including [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Baluchi language|Baluchi]], [[Brahui language|Brahui]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Central Kurdish]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] and [[Uyghur language|Uyghur]].{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}

=== Former use ===
Speakers of languages that were previously unwritten used Arabic script as a basis to design writing systems for their mother languages. This choice could be influenced by Arabic being their second language, the language of scripture of their faith, or the only written language they came in contact with. Additionally, since most education was once religious, choice of script was determined by the writer's religion; which meant that Muslims would use Arabic script to write whatever language they spoke. This led to Arabic script being the most widely used script during the Middle Ages.

In the 20th century, the Arabic script was generally replaced by the [[Latin alphabet]] in the [[Balkans]],{{dubious|date=November 2011}} parts of [[Sub-Saharan Africa]], and [[Southeast Asia]], while in the [[Soviet Union]], after a brief period of [[Latinisation (USSR)|Latinisation]],<ref>[http://www.azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/52_folder/52_articles/52_alphabet.html Alphabet Transitions – The Latin Script: A New Chronology – Symbol of a New Azerbaijan], by Tamam Bayatly</ref> use of [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] was mandated. [[Turkey]] changed to the Latin alphabet in 1928 as part of an internal Westernizing revolution. After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, many of the Turkic languages of the ex-USSR attempted to follow Turkey's lead and convert to a Turkish-style Latin alphabet. However, renewed use of the Arabic alphabet has occurred to a limited extent in [[Tajikistan]], whose language's close resemblance to [[Persian language|Persian]] allows direct use of publications from Afghanistan and Iran.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cimera.org/files/camel/en/27e/MICA27E-Siddikzoda.pdf |title=Tajik Language: Farsi or Not Farsi? |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060613195726/http://www.cimera.org/files/camel/en/27e/MICA27E-Siddikzoda.pdf |archive-date=June 13, 2006 |author=Sukhail Siddikzoda}}</ref>

Most languages of the [[Iranian languages]] family continue to use Arabic script, as well as the [[Indo-Aryan languages]] of Pakistan and of Muslim populations in [[India]]. However, the [[Bengali language]] of India and Bangladesh was never written in Arabic script, which has been written in the [[Bengali alphabet]] since inception.<ref name=it46>{{cite web | url=http://www.it46.se/docs/courses/ICT4D_localization_software_primer_it46_v1.5.pdf | author=Escudero Pascual Alberto | title=Writing Systems/ Scripts | date=23 October 2005 | accessdate=2006-11-20 | work=Primer to Localization of Software | publisher=it46.se | archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090319013436/http://www.it46.se/docs/courses/ICT4D_localization_software_primer_it46_v1.5.pdf | archive-date=19 March 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref>

* [[Banjar language|Banjarese]] in [[Kalimantan]], Indonesia
* [[Maguindanao language|Maguindanaon]] in the [[Philippines]]
* [[Malay language|Malay]] in [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]] and [[Indonesia]]. Although Malay speakers in [[Brunei]] and [[Southern Thailand]] still use the script on a daily basis.
* [[Minangkabau language|Minangkabau]] in Sumatra, Indonesia
* [[Pegon script]] of [[Javanese language|Javanese]], [[Madurese language|Madurese]] and [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]] in Indonesia, used only in Islamic schools and institutions.
* [[Tausug language|Tausug]] in the [[Philippines]]
* [[Maranao language|Maranao]] in the [[Philippines]]
====Oceania====
* [[Nauruan language|Nauruan]] in [[Nauru]]

====Middle East====
* [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] was written in Arabic letters in a number of places in the past.<ref>p. 20, [[Samuel Kramer|Samuel Noel Kramer]]. 1986. ''In the World of Sumer: An Autobiography''. Detroit: Wayne State University Press.</ref><ref>J. Blau. 2000. Hebrew written in Arabic characters: An instance of radical change in tradition. (In Hebrew, with English summary). In ''Heritage and Innovation in Judaeo-Arabic Culture: Proceedings of the Sixth Conference of the Society For Judaeo-Arabic Studies'', p. 27-31. Ramat Gan.</ref>
* [[Northern Kurdish]] in Turkey and Syria was written in Arabic script until 1932, when a modified [[Kurdish alphabets#Hawar alphabet|Kurdish Latin alphabet]] was introduced by [[Celadet Bedir Khan|Jaladat Ali Badirkhan]] in Syria
* [[Turkish language|Turkish]] in the [[Ottoman Empire]] was written in Arabic script until [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] declared the change to [[Latin script]] in 1928. This form of Turkish is now known as [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] and is held by many to be a different language, due to its much higher percentage of Persian and Arabic [[loanword]]s ([[Ottoman Turkish alphabet]])

pages.title: Romanization of Arabic
pages.text:
{{short description|Application of the Latin script to write the Arabic language in one of various systematic ways}} {{Arabic alphabet}} {{Contains Arabic text}} The '''[[romanization]] of Arabic''' writes [[Modern Standard Arabic|written]] and [[varieties of Arabic|spoken]] [[Arabic language|Arabic]] in the [[Latin script]] in one of various systematic ways. Romanized Arabic is used for a number of different purposes, among them transcription of names and titles, [[cataloging]] Arabic language works, [[language education]] when used in lieu of or alongside the Arabic script, and representation of the language in scientific publications by [[Linguistics|linguists]]. These formal systems, which often make use of [[diacritics]] and non-standard Latin characters and are used in academic settings or for the benefit of non-speakers, contrast with informal means of written communication used by speakers such as the Latin-based [[Arabic chat alphabet]]. Different systems and strategies have been developed to address the inherent problems of rendering various Arabic varieties in the Latin script. Examples of such problems are the symbols for Arabic [[phoneme]]s that do not exist in [[English language|English]] or other [[Europe]]an languages; the means of representing the [[Arabic definite article]], which is always spelled the same way in written Arabic but has numerous pronunciations in the spoken language depending on context; and the representation of short vowels (usually ''i u'' or ''e o'', accounting for variations such as ''[[Muslim]]/Moslem'' or ''[[Mohammed]]/Muhammad/Mohamed''). ==Method== Romanization is often termed "transliteration", but this is not technically correct.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} ''[[Transliteration]]'' is the direct representation of foreign ''letters'' using Latin symbols, while most systems for romanizing Arabic are actually ''[[Phonetic transcription|transcription]]'' systems, which represent the ''sound'' of the language. As an example, the above rendering ''{{transl|ar|ALA|munāẓaratu l-ḥurūfi l-ʻarabīyah}}'' of the {{lang-ar|مناظرة الحروف العربية}} is a transcription, indicating the pronunciation; an example transliteration would be ''{{transl|ar|mnaẓrḧ alḥrwf alʻrbyḧ}}''. == Romanization standards and systems == Principal standards and systems are: ===Mixed [[digraph (orthography)|digraphic]] and [[diacritics|diacritical]] === * '''[[BGN/PCGN romanization|BGN/PCGN]]''' romanization (1956).{{cite web|title=Romanization system for Arabic. BGN/PCGN 1956 System|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/320079/Arabic_Romanization.pdf}} * '''[[UNGEGN]]''' (1972). United Nations Group of Experts on Geographical Names, or "Variant A of the Amended Beirut System". Adopted from BGN/PCGN.{{cite web|url=http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_ar.pdf|title=Arabic|publisher=UNGEGN}}{{cite book|title=Technical reference manual for the standardization of geographical names|year=2007|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/geoinfo/UNGEGN/docs/pubs/UNGEGN%20tech%20ref%20manual_m87_combined.pdf |publisher=UNGEGN|page=12 [22]}} ** '''[[Institut Géographique National|IGN]] System 1973''' or "Variant B of the Amended Beirut System", that conforms to the French orthography and is preferred to the Variant A in French-speaking countries as in Maghreb and Lebanon.{{cite web|title=Systèmes français de romanisation|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/geoinfo/ungegn/docs/25th-gegn-docs/wp%20papers/crp3.pdf|publisher=UNGEGN|date=2009}} ** '''{{abbr|ADEGN|Arab delegations to the Eighth UN Conference on the Standardization of Geographical Names in Berlin (2002)}}''' romanization (2007) is different from UNGEGN in two ways: (1) ظ is dh instead of z̧; (2) the cedilla is replaced by a sub-macron (_) in all the characters with the cedilla. * '''[[ALA-LC]]''' (first published 1991), from the [[American Library Association]] and the [[Library of Congress]].{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/romanization/arabic.pdf |title=Arabic romanization table|publisher=The Library of Congress}} This romanization is close to the romanization of the {{lang|de|[[Deutsche Morgenländische Gesellschaft]]}} and [[Hans Wehr]], which is used internationally in scientific publications by [[Arabist]]s. ** '''IJMES''', used by ''International Journal of Middle East Studies'', very similar to ALA-LC.{{cite web|title=IJMES Translation & Transliteration Guide|url=http://ijmes.chass.ncsu.edu/IJMES_Translation_and_Transliteration_Guide.htm|publisher=International Journal of Middle East Studies}} ** '''EI''', ''[[Encyclopaedia of Islam]]'' (1st ed., 1913–1938; 2nd ed., 1960–2005).{{cite web|title=Encyclopaedia of Islam Romanization vs ALA Romanization for Arabic|website=University of Washington Libraries|url=http://guides.lib.uw.edu/c.php?g=341351&p=2970796}} === Fully [[diacritics|diacritical]] === * '''DMG''' (''{{lang|de|[[Deutsche Morgenländische Gesellschaft]]}}'', 1935), adopted by the International Convention of Orientalist Scholars in Rome.{{cite book |last1=Brockelmann |first1=Carl |last2=Ronkel |first2=Philippus Samuel van |authorlink1=Carl Brockelmann |title=Die Transliteration der arabischen Schrift... |date=1935 |location=Leipzig |url=http://www.naher-osten.uni-muenchen.de/studium_lehre/werkzeugkasten/dmgtransliteration.pdf |format=PDF }} ** '''[[DIN 31635|DIN]]'''[[DIN 31635| 31635]] (1982), developed by the German Institute for Standardization (''{{lang|de|[[Deutsches Institut für Normung]]}}''). ** '''[[Hans Wehr transliteration]]''' (1961, 1994), a modification to DIN 31635. ** '''EALL''', ''Encyclopedia of Arabic Language and Linguistics'' (edited by Kees Versteegh, Brill, 2006–2009).{{Cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Arabic Language and Linguistics |last=Reichmuth |first=Philipp |publisher=Brill |year=2009 |editor-last=Versteegh |editor-first=Kees |volume=4 |pages=515–20 |chapter=Transcription }} ** Spanish romanization, identical to DMG/DIN with the exception of three letters: ǧ > ŷ, ḫ > j, ġ > g.{{cite book |last1=Millar |first1=M. Angélica |last2=Salgado |first2=Rosa |last3=Zedán |first3=Marcela |title=Gramatica de la lengua arabe para hispanohablantes |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FE8w5YF7650C&pg=PA53 |year=2005 |publisher=Editorial Universitaria |location=Santiago de Chile |isbn=978-956-11-1799-0 |pages=53–54 }} * '''[[ISO 233]]''' (1984), letter-to-letter; vowels are transliterated only if they are shown with diacritics, otherwise they are omitted. ** [[:fr:ISO 233-2|ISO 233-2]] (1993), simplified transliteration; vowels are always shown.{{Verify source|date=October 2015}} * [[BS 4280]] (1968), developed by the [[BSI Group|British Standards Institution]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bsi-global.com/index.xalter |title=Standards, Training, Testing, Assessment and Certification |publisher=[[BSI Group]] |accessdate=2014-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007063234/http://www.bsi-global.com/index.xalter |archivedate=October 7, 2008}} === ASCII-based === * [[ArabTeX]] (since 1992) "has been modelled closely after the transliteration standards [[ISO/R 233]] and DIN 31635".{{Cite quote|date=October 2015}} * [[Buckwalter Transliteration]] (1990s), developed at ALPNET by [[Tim Buckwalter]]; doesn't require unusual [[diacritic]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.qamus.org/transliteration.htm |title=Buckwalter Arabic Transliteration |publisher=QAMUS LLC}}{{cite web |url=https://open.xerox.com/Services/arabic-morphology/Pages/buckwalter-about |title=Arabic Morphological Analyzer/The Buckwalter Transliteration |publisher=Xerox |accessdate=2017-04-30 }} * [[Arabic chat alphabet|Arabic '''chat''' alphabet]]: an ad hoc solution for conveniently entering Arabic using a Latin keyboard. === Comparison table === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! Appropriate Unicode points would be [[modifier letter apostrophe]] ⟨ʼ⟩ and [[modifier letter turned comma]] ⟨ʻ⟩ (for the UNGEGN and BGN/PCGN) or [[modifier letter reversed comma]] ⟨ʽ⟩ (for the Wehr and Survey of Egypt System (SES)), all of which Unicode defines as letters. The glottal stop (''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'') in these romanizations isn't written word-initially. * {{note|5|5}} In ''Encyclopaedia of Islam'' digraphs are underlined, that is th, dj, kh, dh, sh, gh. In BGN/PCGN on the contrary the sequences {{lang|ar|ـتـهـ, ـكـهـ, ـدهـ, ـسهـ}} may be romanized with [[middle dot]] as ''t·h'', ''k·h'', ''d·h'', ''s·h'' respectively; the letter ''g'' is not used by itself in BGN/PCGN, so no confusion between ''gh'' and ''g''+''h'' is possible. * {{note|6|6}} In the original German edition of his dictionary (1952) Wehr used ǧ, ḫ, ġ for j, ḵ, ḡ respectively (that is all the letters used are equal to DMG/[[DIN 31635]]). The variant presented in the table is from the English translation of the dictionary (1961). * {{note|7|7}} BGN/PCGN allows use of [[Dot (diacritic)#Underdot|underdot]]s instead of [[cedilla]]. * {{note|8|8}}''{{transl|ar|ALA|Fāʼ}}'' and ''{{transl|ar|ALA|qāf}}'' are traditionally written in [[Maghreb|Northwestern Africa]] as {{lang|ar|ڢ}} and {{lang|ar|ڧـ ـڧـ ـٯ}}, respectively, while the latter's dot is only added initially or medially. * {{note|9|9}} In Egypt, Sudan, and sometimes in other regions, the standard form for final-''[[Yāʼ|{{transl|ar|ALA|yāʼ}}]]'' is only {{lang|ar|ى}} (without dots) in handwriting and print, for both final {{IPA|/-iː/}} and final {{IPA|/-aː/}}. {{lang|ar|[[ى]]}} for the latter pronunciation, is called {{lang|ar|ألف لينة}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif layyinah}}'' {{IPA-arz|ˈʔælef læjˈjenæ|}}, 'flexible alif'. * {{note|10|10}} The [[sun and moon letters]] and [[hamza#Hamzat waṣl|hamzat waṣl]] pronunciation rules apply, although it is acceptable to ignore them. The UN system and ALA-LC prefer lowercase ''a'' and hyphens: ''al-Baṣrah, ar-Riyāḍ''; BGN/PCGN prefers uppercase ''A'' and no hyphens: ''Al Baṣrah, Ar Riyāḍ''. * {{note|11|11}} The EALL suggests ẓ "in proper names" (volume 4, page 517). ==Romanization issues== Any [[romanization]] system has to make a number of decisions which are dependent on its intended field of application. === Vowels === One basic problem is that written Arabic is normally [[Harakat|unvocalized]]; i.e., many of the [[vowel]]s are not written out, and must be supplied by a reader familiar with the language. Hence unvocalized [[Abjad|Arabic writing]] does not give a reader unfamiliar with the language sufficient information for accurate pronunciation. As a result, a pure [[transliteration]], e.g., rendering {{lang|ar|قطر}} as '''{{transl|ar|qṭr}}''', is meaningless to an untrained reader. For this reason, [[transcription (linguistics)|transcription]]s are generally used that add vowels, e.g. '''{{transl|ar|ALA|qaṭar}}'''. However, unvocalized systems match exactly to written Arabic, unlike vocalized systems such as Arabic chat, which some claim detracts from one's ability to spell.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/uae/education/arabizi-sparks-concern-among-educators-1.1181529 |title=Arabizi sparks concern among educators |publisher=GulfNews.com |date=2013-05-09 |accessdate=2014-05-18}} === Transliteration vs. transcription === Most uses of romanization call for [[Transcription (linguistics)|transcription]] rather than [[transliteration]]: Instead of transliterating each written letter, they try to reproduce the sound of the words according to the orthography rules of the target language: ''Qaṭar''. This applies equally to scientific and popular applications. A pure transliteration would need to omit vowels (e.g. ''qṭr ''), making the result difficult to interpret except for a subset of trained readers fluent in Arabic. Even if vowels are added, a transliteration system would still need to distinguish between multiple ways of spelling the same sound in the Arabic script, e.g. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif }}'' {{lang|ar|2=ا}} vs. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqṣūrah}}'' {{lang|ar|ى}} for the sound {{IPA|/aː/}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ā}}'', and the six different ways ({{lang|ar|ء إ أ آ ؤ ئ}}) of writing the [[glottal stop]] ([[hamza]], usually transcribed ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ʼ }}''). This sort of detail is needlessly confusing, except in a very few situations (e.g., typesetting text in the Arabic script). Most issues related to the romanization of Arabic are about transliterating vs. transcribing; others, about what should be romanized: * Some transliterations ignore [[assimilation (linguistics)|assimilation]] of the [[definite article]] ''[[al-]]'' before the "[[sun letters]]", and may be easily misread by non-Arabic speakers. For instance, "the light" {{lang|ar|النور}} ''an-nūr'' would be more literally transliterated along the lines of ''alnūr''. In the transcription ''an-nūr'', a hyphen is added and the unpronounced {{IPAslink|l}} removed for the convenience of the uninformed non-Arabic speaker, who would otherwise pronounce an {{IPA|/l/}}, perhaps not understanding that {{IPA|/n/}} in ''nūr'' is [[gemination|geminated]]. Alternatively, if the [[shaddah]] is not transliterated (since it is strictly not a letter), a strictly literal transliteration would be ''alnūr'', which presents similar problems for the uninformed non-Arabic speaker. * A transliteration should render the "closed tāʼ " (''[[Ta' marbuta|tāʼ marbūṭah]]'', {{lang|ar|ة}}) faithfully. Many transcriptions render the sound {{IPA|/a/}} as ''a'' or ''ah'' and ''t'' when it denotes {{IPA|/at/}}. **[[ISO 233]] has a unique symbol, ẗ. * "Restricted alif" (''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqṣūrah}}'', {{lang|ar|ى}}) should be transliterated with an [[acute accent]], ''á'', differentiating it from regular alif {{lang|ar|ا}}, but it is transcribed in many schemes like alif, ''ā'', because it stands for {{IPA|/aː/}}. * [[Nunation]]: what is true elsewhere is also true for nunation: transliteration renders what is seen, transcription what is heard, when in the Arabic script, it is written with diacritics, not by letters, or omitted. A transcription may reflect the language as spoken, typically rendering names, for example, by the people of Baghdad ([[Baghdad Arabic]]), or the official standard ([[Modern Standard Arabic|Literary Arabic]]) as spoken by a [[imam|preacher]] in the mosque or a TV newsreader. A transcription is free to add phonological (such as vowels) or morphological (such as word boundaries) information. Transcriptions will also vary depending on the writing conventions of the target language; compare English ''[[Omar Khayyam]]'' with German ''Omar Chajjam'', both for {{lang|ar|عمر خيام}} {{IPA|/ʕumar xajjaːm/}}, {{IPA-ar|ˈʕomɑr xæjˈjæːm|}} (unvocalized ''{{transl|ar|ʿmr ḫyām}}'', vocalized ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ʻUmar Khayyām}}''). A transliteration is ideally fully reversible: a machine should be able to transliterate it back into Arabic. A transliteration can be considered as flawed for any one of the following reasons: *A "loose" transliteration is ambiguous, rendering several Arabic phonemes with an identical transliteration, or such that digraphs for a single phoneme (such as ''dh gh kh sh th'' rather than ''ḏ ġ ḫ š ṯ '') may be confused with two adjacent consonants—but this problem is resolved in the [[ALA-LC]] romanization system, where the [[prime (symbol)|prime symbol]] ʹ is used to separate two consonants when they do not form a digraph;{{cite web|title=Arabic|url=https://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/romanization/arabic.pdf|work=ALA-LC Romanization Tables|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=2013-06-14|page=9|format=PDF|quote=21. The prime (ʹ) is used: (a) To separate two letters representing two distinct consonantal sounds, when the combination might otherwise be read as a digraph.}} for example: {{lang|ar|أَكْرَمَتْها}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|akramatʹhā}}'' ('she honored her'), in which the ''t'' and ''h'' are two distinct consonantal sounds. *Symbols representing phonemes may be considered too similar (e.g., ` and ' or ʿ and ʾ for {{lang|ar|ع}} [[ayin|ʻayn]] and [[hamzah]]); *ASCII transliterations using capital letters to disambiguate phonemes are easy to type, but may be considered unaesthetic. A fully accurate transcription may not be necessary for native Arabic speakers, as they would be able to pronounce names and sentences correctly anyway, but it can be very useful for those not fully familiar with spoken Arabic and who are familiar with the Roman alphabet. An accurate transliteration serves as a valuable stepping stone for learning, pronouncing correctly, and distinguishing phonemes. It is a useful tool for anyone who is familiar with the sounds of Arabic but not fully conversant in the language. One criticism is that a fully accurate system would require special learning that most do not have to actually pronounce names correctly, and that with a lack of a universal romanization system they will not be pronounced correctly by non-native speakers anyway. The precision will be lost if special characters are not replicated and if a reader is not familiar with Arabic pronunciation. == Examples == Examples in [[Modern Standard Arabic|Literary Arabic]]: {| class="wikitable" |- ! English | Amjad had a palace || To the Moroccan Kingdom |} ==Arabic alphabet and nationalism== There have been many instances of national movements to convert [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic script]] into Latin script or to romanize the language. ===Lebanon=== A Beirut newspaper ''La Syrie'' pushed for the change from Arabic script to [[Lebanese Arabic#Said Akl's orthography|Latin script]] in 1922. The major head of this movement was [[Louis Massignon]], a French Orientalist, who brought his concern before the Arabic Language Academy in Damascus in 1928. Massignon’s attempt at romanization failed as the Academy and population viewed the proposal as an attempt from the Western world to take over their country. Sa’id Afghani, a member of the Academy, asserted that the movement to romanize the script was a Zionist plan to dominate Lebanon.{{cite book|last=Shrivtiel|first=Shraybom|title=The Question of Romanisation of the Script and The Emergence of Nationalism in the Middle East|date=1998|publisher=Mediterranean Language Review|pages=179–196}}History of Arabic Writing ===Egypt=== After the period of colonialism in Egypt, Egyptians were looking for a way to reclaim and reemphasize Egyptian culture. As a result, some Egyptians pushed for an Egyptianization of the [[Arabic language]] in which the formal Arabic and the [[Egyptian Arabic|colloquial Arabic]] would be combined into one language and the Latin alphabet would be used. There was also the idea of finding a way to use [[hieroglyphics]] instead of the Latin alphabet. A scholar, [[Salama Musa]], agreed with the idea of applying a Latin alphabet to Egyptian Arabic, as he believed that would allow Egypt to have a closer relationship with the West. He also believed that Latin script was key to the success of Egypt as it would allow for more advances in science and technology. This change in script, he believed, would solve the problems inherent with Arabic, such as a lack of written vowels and difficulties writing foreign words.Shrivtiel, p. 188 Ahmad Lutfi As Sayid and Muhammad Azmi, two Egyptian intellectuals, agreed with Musa and supported the push for romanization. The idea that romanization was necessary for modernization and growth in Egypt continued with Abd Al Aziz Fahmi in 1944. He was the chairman for the Writing and Grammar Committee for the [[Academy of the Arabic Language in Cairo|Arabic Language Academy of Cairo]]. He believed and desired to implement romanization in a way that allowed words and spellings to remain somewhat familiar to the Egyptian people. However, this effort failed as the Egyptian people felt a strong cultural tie to the Arabic alphabet, particularly the older generation. == See also == *[[Arabic Chat Alphabet]] *[[Arabic diacritics]] *[[Arabic grammar]] *[[Arabic names]] *[[English exonyms of Arabic speaking places]] *[[Glottal stop (letter)]] *[[Maltese alphabet]] *[[Ottoman Turkish alphabet]] – a [[Perso-Arabic script|Perso-Arabic]]-based alphabet, which was replaced by the Latin-based [[Turkish alphabet]] in 1928 *[[Romanization of Hebrew]] *[[Standard Arabic Technical Transliteration System]] (SATTS) ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://transliteration.eki.ee/pdf/Arabic_2.2.pdf Comparative table of DIN 31635, ISO 233, ISO/R 233, UN, ALA-LC, and Encyclopædia of Islam] (not normative) {{Arabic language}} {{Romanization}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Romanization Of Arabic}} [[Category:Arabic orthography]] [[Category:Romanization of Arabic| ]]

History of the Arabic alphabet
pages.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2010}} {{Arabic-script sidebar}} {{SpecialChars}} It is thought that the Arabic alphabet is a derivative of the [[Nabataean alphabet|Nabataean]] variation of the [[region]], which descended from the [[Phoenician alphabet]], which, among others, gave rise to the [[Hebrew alphabet]] and the [[Greek alphabet]] (and therefore the [[Cyrillic]] and [[Latin alphabet|Roman]] [[alphabet]]s). ==Origins== The Arabic alphabet evolved either from the Nabataean,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=65kOAAAAYAAJ&dq=origin+arabic+script&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=origin|title=The Development of the Arabic Scripts: From the Nabatean Era to the First Islamic Century According to Dated Texts|last=Gruendler|first=Beatrice|date=1993|publisher=Scholars Press|year=|isbn=9781555407100|location=|pages=1|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fDohBQAAQBAJ&pg=PR1&dq=origin+arabic+script&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjruamsp8bSAhVBC8AKHRQvAGMQ6AEITDAJ#v=onepage&q=origin%20arabic%20script&f=false|title=A Brief Introduction to The Arabic Alphabet|last=Healey|first=John F.|last2=Smith|first2=G. Rex|date=2012-02-13|publisher=Saqi|year=|isbn=9780863568817|location=|pages=|language=en|chapter=II - The Origin of the Arabic Alphabet}} or (less widely believed) directly from the [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Kc4xAlunCSEC&pg=PA100&dq=origin+arabic+script+syriac&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzr9T6p8bSAhWDCMAKHZa8AvoQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=origin%20arabic%20script%20syriac&f=false|title=The Origins of Writing|last=Senner|first=Wayne M.|date=1991|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|year=|isbn=0803291671|location=|pages=100|language=en}} This table shows changes undergone by the shapes of the letters from the Aramaic original to the Nabataean and Syriac forms. Arabic is placed in the middle for clarity and not to mark a time order of evolution. The Arabic script represented in the table below is that of post-Classical and Modern Arabic, not 6th century Arabic script, which is of a notably different form. It seems that the Nabataean alphabet became the Arabic alphabet thus: *In the 6th and 5th centuries BCE, northern Arab tribes emigrated and founded a kingdom centred around [[Petra]], [[Jordan]]. These people (now named [[Nabataeans]] from the name of one of the tribes, Nabatu) spoke the [[Nabataean Arabic|Nabataean language]], a [[Northwest Semitic languages|Northwest Semitic]] language. *In the 2nd or 1st centuries BCE,{{Cite web|url=http://www.omniglot.com/writing/nabataean.htm|title=Nabataean abjad|website=www.omniglot.com|access-date=2017-03-08}}{{Cite web|url=http://mushecht.haifa.ac.il/catalogues/Nabateans/Joseph_Naveh.pdf|title=Nabatean Language, Script and Inscriptions|last=Naveh|first=Joseph|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} the first known records of the Nabataean alphabet were written in the Aramaic language (which was the language of communication and trade), but including some Arabic language features: the Nabataeans did not write the language which they spoke. They wrote in a form of the Aramaic alphabet, which continued to evolve; it separated into two forms: one intended for [[inscription]]s (known as "monumental Nabataean") and the other, more cursive and hurriedly written and with joined letters, for writing on [[papyrus]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FcAoBq4_EnEC&pg=PA152&dq=nabataean+script&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiov86Fq8bSAhXiJMAKHVYlBCIQ6AEIJTAB#v=onepage&q=even%20the%20earliest&f=false|title=Petra and the Lost Kingdom of the Nabataeans|last=Taylor|first=Jane|date=2001|publisher=I.B.Tauris|year=|isbn=9781860645082|location=|pages=152|language=en}} This cursive form influenced the monumental form more and more and gradually changed into the Arabic alphabet. *[[Laïla Nehmé]] has demonstrated the transition of scripts from the Nabataean Aramaic to the recognisably Arabic form that appears to have occurred between the third and fifth centuries CE, replacing the indigenous Arabic alphabet.{{cite web|publisher=University of Texas, Austin|url=https://15minutehistory.org/2016/04/27/episode-82-what-writing-can-tell-us-about-the-arabs-before-islam/|title=Episode 82: What Writing Can Tell Us About the Arabs before Islam|first1=Christopher|last1=Rose|first2=Ahmad|last2=al-Jallad|date=27 April 2016|accessdate=2 June 2017}} ==Pre-Islamic Arabic inscriptions== [[File:WadiRumPetroglyphs.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Petroglyph]]s in [[Wadi Rum]] ([[Jordan]])]] The first recorded text in the Arabic alphabet was written in 512. It is a trilingual dedication in [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Syriac language|Syriac]] and [[Arabic language|Arabic]] found at Zabad in [[Syria]]. The version of the Arabic alphabet used includes only 22 letters, of which only 15 are different, being used to note 28 [[phoneme]]s: [[File:Aram nabat arab syriac.png|thumb|600px|center|The image footnote is incorrect. It should say: 1. Phoenician ; 2. Nabataean ; 3. Arabic ; 4. Syriac ; 5. Transliteration]] Many myriads of pre-Classical Arabic inscriptions are attested, in alphabets borrowed from [[Epigraphic South Arabian]] alphabets (however, Safaitic and Hismaic are not strictly Arabic, but [[Ancient North Arabian]] dialects, and written Nabataean is an Aramaic dialect): *[[Safaitic]] (over 13,000; almost all graffiti){{cite book|last=Al-Jallad|first=Ahmad|title= An Outline of the Grammar of the Safaitic Inscriptions|date=2015|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden}}, 11-14 *[[Hismaic]] in the southern parts of central Arabia *Preclassical Arabic inscriptions dating to the 1st century BC from Qaryat Al-Faw *[[Nabataean Arabic|Nabataean]] inscriptions in [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], written in the [[Nabataean alphabet]] *Pre-Islamic Arabic inscriptions in the [[Arabic alphabet]] are very few, with only 5 known for certain. They mostly use no dots, making them sometimes difficult to interpret, as many letters are the same shape as other letters (they are written with [[rasm]] only) Here are the inscriptions in the Arabic alphabet, and the inscriptions in the Nabataean alphabet that show the beginnings of Arabic-like features. {| cellspacing="0" border="1" bgcolor="white" |- !Name !Whereabouts !Date !Language !Alphabet !Text & notes |- |[[Al-Hasa]] |[[Nejd]], Historical [[Bahrain]] region |4th century BC |3 lines in Hasean |[[Epigraphic South Arabian]] alphabets |A large funerary stone is inscribed in the Hasaean dialect using a variety of South Arabian monumental script, with three inscribed lines for the man Matmat, that records both patrilineal and matriarchal descent:http://curatorseye.com/Name=Published-Hasaean-Inscribed-Tombstone-for-Matmat&Item=4965#Cat=082&SubC=072 1. "Tombstone and grave of Matmat," 2. "son of Zurubbat, those of 'Ah-" 3. "nas, her of the father of Sa'ad-" 4. "ab.."'' ''(Dr. A. Jamme) |- |[[Qaryat al-Fāw]] |[[Wadi ad-Dawasir]], [[Nejd]] |1st century BC |10 lines in Arabic |[[Epigraphic South Arabian]] alphabets |A tomb dedicatory and a prayer to ''Lāh'', ''Kāhil ''and ''ʻAṯṯār ''to protect the tomb: "ʿIgl son of Hafʿam constructed for his brother Rabibil son of Hafʿam the tomb: both for him and for his child and his wife, and his children and their children's children and womenfolk, free members of the folk Ghalwan. And he has placed it under the protection of (the gods) Kahl and Lah and ʿAthtar al-Shariq from anyone strong or weak, and anyone who would attempt to sell or pledge it, for all time without any derogation, so long as the sky produces rain or the earth herbage."'' In the year 239 [of the era of the Provincia Arabia = 344 AD]." (Trombley) In the 5th century barracks were built. Has a few diacritic dots. |Last inscription in Nabataean language. [[Epitaph]] to one Raqush, including [[curse]] against grave-violaters: "This is a grave K b.
