"God" is written as {{lang|ar| الاله }}, see [[Allah#Typography]]: "With the help of God! Sergius, son of Amat Manaf, and Tobi, son of Imru'l-qais and Sergius, son of Sa‘d, and Sitr, and Shouraih." (C. Rabin) |- |[[Jabal Usays]] |in Syria |528 |Arabic |Arabic |Record of a military expedition by Ibrahim ibn Mughirah on behalf of the king al-Harith, presumably [[Al-Harith ibn Jabalah]] ([[Arethas of Caesarea|Arethas]] in Greek), king of the [[Ghassanid]] vassals of the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]]s: "This is Ruqaym, son of Mughayr the Awsite. Al-Ḥārith the king, sent me to 'Usays, upon his military posts in the year 423 [528 CE]" |- |[[Harrān]] |in Leija district, south of [[Damascus]] |568 |Arabic, Greek |Arabic |[[Christianity|Christian]] [[dedication|dedicatory]], in a [[martyrium (architecture)|martyrium]]. It records Sharahil ibn Zalim building the martyrium a year after the destruction of [[Khaybar]]: "[I] Sharaḥīl, son of Talimu built this martyrium in the year 463 after the destruction of Khaybar by a year." |} Cursive Nabataean writing changed into Arabic writing, likeliest between the dates of the an-Namāra inscription and the Jabal Ramm inscription. Most writing would have been on perishable materials, such as papyrus. As it was cursive, it was liable to change. The [[epigraph (archeology)|epigraph]]ic record is extremely sparse, with only five certainly [[pre-Islamic Arabic inscriptions]] surviving, though some others may be pre-Islamic. The Nabataean alphabet was designed to write 22 [[phoneme]]s, but Arabic has 28 phonemes; thus, when used to write the Arabic language, 6 of its letters must each represent two phonemes:
''d'' also represented ''ð'',
''ħ'' also represented ''kh'' '''%''',
''ṭ'' also represented ''ẓ'',
''ayin'' also represented ''gh'' '''%''',
''ṣ'' also represented ''ḍ'','''%''',
''t'' also represented ''þ''.
: In the cases marked '''%''', the choice was influenced by [[etymology]], as Common Semitic ''kh'' and ''gh'' became Hebrew ''ħ'' and ''[[ayin]]'' respectively. As cursive Nabataean writing evolved into Arabic writing, the writing became largely joined-up. Some of the letters became the same shape as other letters, producing more ambiguities, as in the table: [[Image:Arabe arch.png]] {{see also|rasm}} Here the Arabic letters are listed in the traditional Levantine order but are written in their current forms, for simplicity. The letters which are the same shape have coloured backgrounds. The second value of the letters that represent more than one [[phoneme]] is after a comma. In these tables, ''ğ'' is ''j'' as in English "June".
In the Arabic language, the ''g'' sound seems to have changed into ''j'' in fairly late pre-Islamic times, but this seems not to have happened in those tribes who invaded [[Egypt]] and settled there. When a letter was at the end of a word, it often developed an end loop, and as a result most Arabic letters have two or more shapes.
''b'' and ''n'' and ''t'' became the same.
''y'' became the same as ''b'' and ''n'' and ''t'' except at the ends of words.
''j'' and ''ħ'' became the same.
''z'' and ''r'' became the same.
''s'' and ''sh'' became the same. After all this, there were only 17 letters that were different in shape. One letter-shape represented 5 phonemes (''b t th n'' and sometimes ''y''), one represented 3 phonemes (''j ħ kh''), and 5 each represented 2 phonemes. Compare the Hebrew alphabet, as in the table at [[:Image:Hebreu hist arabe.png]]. A similar ambiguity occurs in the German [[Fraktur]] font, in which the Roman alphabet uppercase letters '''I''' and '''J''' look the same but are officially different letters. ==Early Islamic changes== [[Image:D r nabat syriaque.png|thumb|right|Table comparing Nabataean and Syriac forms of /d/ and /r/]] The Arabic alphabet is first attested in its classical form in the 7th century. See [[PERF 558]] for the first surviving Islamic Arabic writing. In the 7th century, probably in the early years of [[Islam]] while writing down the [[Qur'an]], scribes realized that working out which of the ambiguous letters a particular letter was from context was laborious and not always possible, so a proper remedy was required. Writings in the Nabataean and Syriac alphabets already had sporadic examples of dots being used to distinguish letters which had become identical, for example as in the table on the right. By analogy with this, a system of dots was added to the Arabic alphabet to make enough different letters for [[Classical Arabic]]'s 28 phonemes. Sometimes the resulting new letters were put in alphabetical order after their un-dotted originals, and sometimes at the end. The first surviving document that definitely uses these dots is also the first surviving Arabic [[papyrus]] ([[PERF 558]]), dated April, 643. The dots did not become obligatory until much later. Important texts like the [[Qur'an]] were frequently [[memorization|memorized]]; this practice, which survives even today, probably arose partly to avoid the great ambiguity of the script, and partly due to the scarcity of books in times when [[printing]] was unheard-of in the area and every copy of every book had to be written by hand. The alphabet then had 28 letters, and so could be used to write the numbers 1 to 10, then 20 to 100, then 200 to 900, then 1000 (see [[Abjad numerals]]). In this numerical order, the new letters were put at the end of the alphabet. This produced this order: alif (1), b (2), j (3), d (4), h (5), w (6), z (7), H (8), T (9), y (10), k (20), l (30), m (40), n (50), s (60), ayn (70), f (80), S (90), q (100), r (200), sh (300), t (400), th (500), dh (600), kh (700), D (800), Z (900), gh (1000). The lack of vowel signs in Arabic writing created more ambiguities: for example, in [[Classical Arabic]] ''ktb'' could be ''kataba'' = "he wrote", ''kutiba'' = "it was written" or ''kutub''="books". Later, vowel signs and [[hamza]]s were added, beginning some time in the last half of the 6th century, at about the same time as the first invention of Syriac and Hebrew [[Speech production|vocalization]]. Initially, this was done using a system of red dots, said to have been commissioned by an [[Umayyad]] governor of [[Iraq]], [[Hajjaj ibn Yusuf]]{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}: a dot above = ''a'', a dot below = ''i'', a dot on the line = ''u'', and doubled dots giving ''[[tanwin]]''. However, this was cumbersome and easily confusable with the letter-distinguishing dots, so about 100 years later, the modern system was adopted. The system was finalized around 786 by [[al-Farahidi]]. Before the historical decree by [[Hajjaj ibn Yusuf]], all administrative texts were recorded by [[Persian people|Persian]] scribes in [[Middle Persian]] language using [[Pahlavi script]], but many of the initial orthographic alterations to the Arabic alphabet might have been proposed and implemented by the same scribes. When new signs were added to the Arabic alphabet, they took the alphabetical order value of the letter which they were an alternative for: ''[[tā' marbūta]]'' (see also below) took the value of ordinary ''t'', and not of ''h''. In the same way, the many diacritics do not have any value: for example, a doubled consonant indicated by [[shadda]] does not count as a letter separate from the single one. Some features of the Arabic alphabet arose because of differences between [[Qur'an]]ic spelling (which followed the [[Makkah|Meccan]] dialect pronunciation used by [[Muhammad]] and his first followers) and the standard [[Classical Arabic]]. These include: *'''''tā' marbūta''''': This arose because the ''-at'' ending of feminine nouns ([[tā' marbūta]]) was often pronounced as ''-ah'' and written as ''h''. To avoid altering Quranic spelling, the dots of ''t'' were written over the ''h''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} *'''''y'' (alif maksura ى) used to spell ''ā'' at the ends of some words''': This arose because ''ā'' arising from [[sandhi|contraction]] where single ''y'' dropped out between vowels was in some dialects pronounced at the ends of words with the tongue further forward than for other ''ā'' vowels, and as a result in the Qu'ran it was written as ''y''.{{Clarify|date=March 2008}}{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} *'''''ā'' not written as [[aleph|alif]] in some words''': The Arabic spelling of ''[[Allah|Allāh]]'' was decided before the Arabs started using [[aleph|alif]] to spell ''ā''. In other cases (for example the first ''ā'' in ''hāðā'' = "this"), it may be that the Meccan dialect pronounced those vowels short. *'''hamza''': Originally [[aleph|alif]] was used to spell the [[glottal stop]]. But Meccans did not pronounce the glottal stop{{Verify source|date=March 2008}}, replacing it with ''w'', ''y'' or nothing, lengthening an adjacent vowel, or, between vowels, dropping the glottal stop and contracting the vowels, and the Qur'an was written following Meccan pronunciation. The Arabic grammarians invented the [[hamza]] [[diacritic]] sign and used it to mark the glottal stop. ''Hamza'' is Arabic for "hook". ==Reorganization of the alphabet== Less than a century later, Arab grammarians reorganized the alphabet, for reasons of teaching, putting letters next to other letters which were nearly the same shape. This produced a new order which was not the same as the numeric order, which became less important over time because it was being competed with by the [[Indian numerals]] and sometimes by the [[Greek numerals]]. The Arabic grammarians of North Africa changed the new letters, which explains the differences between the alphabets of the East and the [[Maghreb]].
[[Image:Compare Arabic Hebrew etc.png]]
(Greek ''waw'' = the original name of the [[digamma]]) The old alphabetical order, as in the other alphabets shown here, is known as the [[Levant]]ine or [[Abjadi order]]. If the letters are arranged by their numeric order, the Levantine order is restored:-

pages.title: Zairja
pages.text:
A '''zairja''' ({{lang-ar|زايرجة}}; also transcribed as ''zairjah'', ''zairajah'', ''zairdja'', ''zairadja'', and ''zayirga'') was a device used by medieval Arab [[astrologer]]s to generate ideas by mechanical means. The name may derive from a mixture of the [[Persian language|Persian]] words ''zaicha'' ("horoscope; astronomical table") and ''daira'' ("circle").Link, David (2010). [http://www.alpha60.de/research/scrambling_truth/DavidLink_ScramblingTruth2010_100dpi.pdf "Scrambling T-R-U-T-H: Rotating Letters as a Material Form of Thought"], in: Variantology 4. On Deep Time Relations of Arts, Sciences and Technologies in the Arabic–Islamic World, eds. Siegfried Zielinski and Eckhard Fürlus (Cologne: König, 2010): 215–266 ==Overview== [[Ibn Khaldun]] described zairja as: "a branch of the science of letter magic, practiced among the authorities on letter magic, is the technique of finding out answers from questions by means of connections existing between the letters of the expressions used in the question. They imagine that these connections can form the basis for knowing the future happenings they want to know."Ibn Khaldūn. 1958 The Muqaddimah: An introduction to history. Translated from the Arabic by Franz Rosenthal. 3 vols. New York: Princeton. [http://www.muslimphilosophy.com/ik/Muqaddimah/Chapter6/Ch_6_28.htm Chapter 6 section 28] He suggests that rather than being supernatural it works "from an agreement in the wording of question and answer ... with the help of the technique called the technique of 'breaking down'" (i.e. algebra). By combining number values associated with the letters and categories, new paths of insight and thought were created. According to Ibn Khaldun the most detailed treatment of it is a pseudographical work "Za'irajah of the World" attributed to [[Abu al-Abbas as-Sabti|as-Sabti]], which contains operating instructions in hundreds of lines of verse, beginning:
Select a star rise. Figure out its signs.
Reverse its root. Straighten it out with the cycle.
Someone will perceive those things. He will achieve his purpose
And be given their letters in whose arrangement the evidence lies...
A manuscript in [[Rabat]] recounts Ibn Khaldun's introduction to the machine by Al-Marjānī in 1370 (772 AH), and claims that it was a traditional and ancient science. When Ibn Khaldun expressed skepticism, the pair asked the instrument how old it was, and the machine told them it was invented by the prophet [[Idris (prophet)|Idris]] (identified with the Biblical [[Enoch (Biblical figure)|Enoch]]). It has been suggested that [[Catalonia|Catalan]]-[[Majorca]]n mystic [[Ramon Llull]] became familiar with the zairja in his travels and studies of Arab culture, and used it as a prototype for his invention of the ''[[Ars Magna (Ramon Llull)|Ars Magna]]''.Charles Lohr (1984) Christianus arabicus, cuius nomen Raimundus Lullus. Freiburger Zeitschrift für Philosophie und Theologie 31 [1–2]: 57– 88Dominique Urvoy (1990) La place de Ramon Llull dans la pensée Arabe. Catalan Review. International Journal of Catalan Culture 4 [1–2]: 201–220D. Urvoy (1980) Penser l’Islam. Les présupposés Islamiques de l’“art” de Llull, Paris, 1980Armand Llinares (1980), References et influences Arabes dans le Libre de contemplacio. Estudios Lulianos 24 [71]Mind as Mosaic, The Robot in the Machine, Bruce H. Hinrichs, pp. 196–197 In "Scrambling T-R-U-T-H: Rotating Letters as a Material Form of Thought", David Link provides a clear description and a full history of the device with a representation of the Arabic letters involved. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://subrealism.blogspot.com/2008/02/zairajah.html An extract from Ibn Khaldun featuring illustrations of the dial of the zairja] {{computable knowledge}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Arabic script]] [[Category:Language and mysticism]] [[Category:Objects used for divination]] [[Category:History of astrology]]

pages.text:
{{Infobox writing system | name = Arabic Braille | altname = {{Braille cell|type=text|background=transparent|b|r|i|l| |12356|r|b|i|16}} | type = abjad | typedesc = ca. 1950 | time = | languages = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | fam1 = [[Braille]] | fam2 = [[English Braille]] | fam3 = Egyptian Braille | print = [[Arabic alphabet]] | creator = | sample = | imagesize = | note = none }} '''Arabic Braille''' ({{lang-ar|بِرَيْل عَرَبِيَّة}}, ''{{transl|ar|ALA-LC|birayl ʿarabīyah}}'') is the [[braille]] alphabet for the [[Arabic language]]. It descends from a braille alphabet brought to Egypt by an English missionary prior to 1878, so the letter assignments generally correspond to [[English Braille]] and to the same [[romanization of Arabic|romanization]] as in other braille systems, like [[Greek braille|Greek]] and [[Russian braille|Russian]]. However, there were once multiple standards, some of which (such as [[Algerian Braille]]) were unrelated to Egyptian Braille. A unified Arabic Braille was adopted in the 1950s as part of the move toward [[international braille]], and it is the standard throughout the Arab world.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070605022316/http://www.sagma.ma/oapam-casa/arbraille.html] Other [[Arabic-based alphabets]] have braille systems similar to Arabic Braille, such as [[Urdu Braille|Urdu]] and [[Persian Braille|Persian]] Braille, but differ in some letter and diacritic assignments.{{cite web|title=World Braille Usage|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000872/087242eb.pdf|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=2012-04-27}} Arabic Braille is read from left to right, following the international convention. Numbers are also left to right, as in printed Arabic. == Arabic braille chart == Arabic braille includes numerous abbreviations, some marked by dot 4 or dot 5 (the comma), which are not described here. A conference in Saudi Arabia in 2002 set up a unified braille standard for Arabic, but as of 2013 not all countries had signed up; those not adopting the standard include some Arab countries but also non-Arab Muslim countries such as Iran, Malaysia, and Indonesia. ===Letters=== Although short-vowel letters are not diacritics in Arabic Braille, they are optional and generally omitted, just as in print Arabic. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! pages.title: Algerian Braille
pages.text: {{See also|Arabic Braille}} {{Infobox writing system | name = Algerian Braille | altname = | type = [[Abjad]] | typedesc = | time = | languages = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | fam1 = [[Braille]] | fam2 = (re-ordered) | print = [[Arabic alphabet]] | creator = | sample = | imagesize = | note = none }} '''Algerian Braille''' was a [[braille alphabet]] used to write the [[Arabic language]] in [[Algeria]]. It is apparently obsolete.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070605022316/http://www.sagma.ma/oapam-casa/arbraille.html Code braille arabe] {{fr icon}} In Algerian Braille, the braille letters are assigned in numeric order to the [[Arabic alphabet]]; standard [[Arabic Braille]] on the other hand uses a completely different assignment, following [[Unified international braille|international norms]] based on the order of the French alphabet. For example, the fifth braille letter, {{bc|e}}, is used in Algerian Braille for ج ''j'', the fifth letter of the Algerian/Arabic alphabet. In most braille alphabets today, {{bc|e}} is used for ''e'', the fifth letter of the French/Latin alphabet, or for a letter that sounds like ''e'', no matter where it occurs in those alphabets. Algerian-type remapping was common in early braille adaptations, but was largely abandoned in favor of mutually understandable standards beginning with the unification French, English, German, and Egyptian Braille on the original French order in 1878.{{cite web|title=World Braille Usage|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000872/087242eb.pdf|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=2012-04-27}} == Algerian Braille chart == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! '''Arabeyes''' is a [[Free Software|Free]] [[open-source software|open-source]] project that is aimed at fully supporting the [[Arabic language]] in the [[Unix]]/[[Linux]] environment. It was established in early 2001 by a number of Arab Linux enthusiasts.

== Project ==

The project runs a portal for sub-projects such as Arabic [[free software Unicode fonts]] and [[text editor]], the "ITL" ([[Islam]]ic Tools and Libraries) which provide [[Islamic calendar|Hijri dates]], [[salat|Muslim prayer times]] and [[Qibla]], and an entire distribution named ''Arabbix'', which is based on [[Knoppix]].

Located online at arabeyes.org, this network calls itself as a "meta project that is aimed at fully supporting the Arabic language in the [[Unix]]/[[Linux]] environment".  It is designed to be a central location to standardize the Arabization process. Arabeyes relies on voluntary contributions by computer professionals and enthusiasts scattered across the globe.

Like other [[Free and open-source software|Free/Open Source Software]] projects that thrive on the Internet, this one too
has its [[Collaborative software development model|contributors]] coming in from different countries and regions.

== Priorities ==

Arabeye says its priorities are to:

* Address the various font/keyboard-mapping issues (for typing in Arabic)
* Create the ability to write plain-text Arabic easily
* Create the ability to spell-check your Arabic text documents
* Create the ability to send and receive mail through an Arabic interface
* Localize (or translate) Common Graphical-User-Interface (GUI)
* Create the ability to take Arabic text files and create various enriched documents (using computer-based formats such as TeX, Word, etc.)

Arabic Speech Corpus
pages.text:
{{multiple issues|
{{COI|date=May 2017}}
{{notability|date=May 2017}}
{{primary sources|date=May 2017}}
}}
The '''Arabic Speech Corpus''' is a [[Modern Standard Arabic]] (MSA) speech corpus for speech synthesis. The corpus contains phonetic and orthographic transcriptions of more than 3.7 hours of MSA speech aligned with recorded speech on the phoneme level. The annotations include word stress marks on the individual phonemes.<ref name="HALABI2016">{{cite thesis |last=Halabi |first=Nawar |year=2016 |title=Modern Standard Arabic Phonetics for Speech Synthesis |url=http://en.arabicspeechcorpus.com/Nawar%20Halabi%20PhD%20Thesis%20Revised.pdf |type=PhD Thesis |publisher=[[University of Southampton]], School of Electronics and Computer Science}}</ref>

The Arabic Speech Corpus was built as part of a doctoral project by [[Nawar Halabi]] at the [[University of Southampton]] funded by [http://www.microlinkpc.com/ MicroLinkPC] who own an exclusive license to commercialise the corpus, but the corpus is available for strictly non-commercial purposes through the [http://www.arabicspeechcorpus.com official Arabic Speech Corpus website]. It is distributed under the [[Creative Commons]] Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.<ref name="OX2016">{{cite |year=2016 |title=Arabic Speech Corpus |url=http://ota.ox.ac.uk/desc/2561 |type=Web Page |publisher=[[University of Oxford]] }}</ref>

==Purpose==
The corpus was mainly built for speech synthesis purposes, specifically [[Speech Synthesis]], but the corpus has been used for building HMM based voices in Arabic. It was also used to automatically align other speech corpora with their phonetic transcript and could be used as part of a larger corpus for training speech recognition systems.<ref name="HALABI2016">{{cite thesis |last=Halabi |first=Nawar |year=2016 |title=Modern Standard Arabic Phonetics for Speech Synthesis |url=http://en.arabicspeechcorpus.com/Nawar%20Halabi%20PhD%20Thesis%20Revised.pdf |type=PhD Thesis |publisher=[[University of Southampton]], School of Electronics and Computer Science}}</ref>

==Contents==
The package contains the following:
* 1813 .wav files containing spoken utterances.
* 1813 .lab files containing text utterances.
* 1813 .TextGrid files containing the phoneme labels with time stamps of the boundaries where these occur in the .wav files. These files can be opened using Praat software.
* phonetic-transcript.txt which has the form "[wav_filename]" "[Phoneme Sequence]" in every line.
* orthographic-transcript.txt which has the form "[wav_filename]" "[Orthographic Transcript]" in every line. Orthography is in Buckwalter Format which is friendlier where there is software that does not read Arabic script. It can be easily converted back to Arabic.
* There is an extra 18 minutes of fully annotated corpus (separate from above but with the same structure as above) which was used to evaluated the corpus (see PhD thesis).

The corpus was also used to prove that using automatically extracted, orthography-based stress marks<ref name="HALPERN2009">{{cite conference |url=http://www.cjk.org/cjk/arabic/an_paper.pdf |title=Word Stress and Vowel Neutralization in Modern Standard Arabic |first=Jack |last=Halpern |year=2009 |conference=2nd International Conference on Arabic Language Resources and Tools |location= Cairo}}</ref> improve the quality of speech synthesis in MSA.

==See also==

pages.text: [[Image:ArabTeX logo.svg|250px|thumb|The ArabTeX logo]] '''ArabTeX''' is a free software package providing support for the [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] and [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] [[alphabet]]s to [[TeX]] and [[LaTeX]]. Written by Klaus Lagally, it can take [[Romanization|romanized]] [[ASCII]] or native script input to produce quality ligatures for [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Shahmukhi Punjabi]], [[Maghreb|Maghribi]], [[Uyghur language|Uyghur]], [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Judeo-Arabic language|Judeo-Arabic]], [[Ladino language|Ladino]] and [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]]. ArabTeX characters are placed within a TeX/LaTeX document using the command \RL{ … } or the environment \begin{RLtext} … \end{RLtext}. [[File:Arabic_keyboard.jpg|thumb|An Arabic keyboard]]
The '''Arabic keyboard''' ({{lang-ar|لوحة المفاتيح العربية}} ''lawḥat al-mafātīḥ al-`Arabīyyah'') is the Arabic keyboard layout used for the [[Arabic language]].  All computer Arabic keyboards contain both [[Arabic letters]] and [[Latin letters]], the latter being necessary for [[Uniform Resource Locator|URL]]s and [[e-mail address]]es. Since [[Arabic]] is written from right to left, when one types with an Arabic keyboard, the letters will start appearing from the right side of the screen.

==Layouts==
{{see also|Arabic alphabet#Keyboards}}
=== Arabic typewriter ===
The first Arabic layout for typewriters was invented by Selim Shibli Haddad, a Syrian artist and inventor, in 1899.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Messenger|first1=Robert|title=The Arabic Typewriter Keyboard and the Syrian Artist|url=http://oztypewriter.blogspot.ru/2014/10/the-arabic-typewriter-keyboard-and.html|website=oz.Typewriter|date=17 October 2014}}</ref>

'''Sabily''' ({{lang-ar|سبيلي}}, {{IPA-ar|sæˈbiːliː|IPA}}, ''My Way'') is a discontinued [[Linux distribution]] based on [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], designed by and for [[Muslims]].<ref name="website">[http://www.sabily.org/website/ www.sabily.org/website]</ref> 
Originally named '''Ubuntu Muslim Edition (presented as UbuntuME)''', development for Sabily was active from 2007 to 2011.

Sabily is designed for Muslim users to have  “out of the box” [[Arabic language]] support and [[Islamic software]] and tools installed, including  a prayer times tool, a  [[Qur'an]] study tool, a [[Islamic calendar|Hijri calendar]], etc.

The Unity shell is based on GNOME 3 on Sabily 11.10, Unity 2D for graphic cards without 3D capabilities. The Unity shell became available on the Sabily 11.04 Badr DVD. Ubuntu Classic Desktop was the default desktop in Sabily (11.04), but Unity in Ubuntu 11.04. New applications in Badr: Islamic Date, Zakat Calc, [[Uncomplicated Firewall#GUIs for Uncomplicated Firewall|Gufw]], DesktopNova, [[AutoKey]], [[recordMyDesktop]], Anki.<ref>[http://www.sabily.org/website/en/component/content/article/6-news/550-sabily-1104-released.html Sabily 11.04 released!]</ref>
The full version of Sabily comes with out of the box educational software, [[codec]]s for the most used media formats.<ref name="website"/><ref>[http://www.sabily.org/website/en/sabily/content.html Sabily content]</ref> Wisabi is a Sabily 11.04 installer for [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista]] or [[Windows 7]] based on [[Wubi (Ubuntu installer)|Wubi]].<ref>[http://www.sabily.org/wiki/index.php/Wisabi Wisabi]</ref>

== History ==
Sabily was previously named as Ubuntu Muslim Edition (UbuntuME). Sabily is following releasing cycle of Ubuntu. After Ubuntu 9.04, It was changed to Sabily.

* UbuntuME 7.04 released 12/10/2007
* UbuntuME 7.10 released 02/12/2007
* UbuntuME 8.04 released 17/05/2008
* UbuntuME 8.04.1 released 22/07/2008
* Sabily 9.04 Taibah released 12/05/2009
* Sabily 9.10 Gaza released 27/12/2009
* Sabily 10.04 Manarat released 28/06/2010
* Sabily 10.10 Al-Quds released 02/11/2010
* Sabily 11.04 Badr released 05/05/2011
* Sabily 11.10 Uhud released 19/12/2011

== Versions available ==
There are currently three versions of Sabily, but there is no official host at the moment.

* Small version (967.96 MB), contains the main Sabily packages, including artwork and Islamic applications and Arabic support.
* Full version (1.55 GB), contains the same as the Small version plus multimedia, educational and miscellaneous packages.<ref>http://www.sabily.org/website/en/sabily/content.html</ref>
* Ultimate version (3.3 GB), has the same content as the Full version, plus Qur'an offline recitations provided by [[Sheikh Mohamed Siddiq El-Minshawi|Muhammad Siddeeq al-Minshawi]], Huzify, Saad al-Ghamadi and [[Mishārī Rāshid al-ʿAfāsī|Mishary Rashed Alafasy]].

The Ultimate version is useful mainly when not connected to the Internet, yet all Sabily versions provide online Qur'an recitations.

Sabily is available as a [[Live CD|Live DVD]], which can be booted on the host computer without installation. The Wisabi installer can install Sabily to the hard disk within [[Microsoft Windows]], without involving risky [[Disk formatting|formatting]] or [[Disk partitioning|partitioning]].

'''Minbar''' indicates the time when [[Muslim]]s should pray. It runs in background as a tray icon and plays the "[[Adhan|athan]]" (call to prayer) at prayer times. Minbar works with the main calculation methods, such as Muslim League (default), Shafii, and Hanafi.<ref>[http://packages.debian.org/sv/sid/minbar Debian -- Details of package minbar in sid]</ref> [[Muslim]]s observe [[salat]] five times a day, and Minbar helps to remind of daily prayer times.<ref>[http://islam.about.com/cs/prayer/a/prayer_times.htm Islamic Prayer Timings]</ref>

'''Zakat Calc''' is an application for [[Linux]]. Zakat Calc helps [[Muslim]]s to calculate [[Zakat]] types: Gold, silver, stones, jewels, savings in bank, property, loans, business, firms, animals (2.5%) and agriculture (10%). Zakat Calc is included in Sabily, a free, open source operating system designed by and for Muslims.

This project is for the OS Sabily. To calculate the amount of the payment of zakat. Used for educational purpose and public use. This project is free. It was created using the [[Gambas]] programming language and it runs on [[Linux]].

[[Zakat]] or "alms giving" is one of the [[Five Pillars of Islam]], is the giving of 2.5% of one's possessions (surplus wealth) to charity, generally to the poor and needy.

{{Contains Arabic text}} As of [[Unicode]] 12.0, the [[Arabic script]] is contained in the following [[Unicode block|blocks]]:{{cite web | url=https://www.unicode.org/Public/UNIDATA/Scripts.txt | work=Unicode Character Database | title=UAX #24: Script data file | publisher=The Unicode Consortium}} *[[Arabic (Unicode block)|Arabic]] (0600–06FF, 255 characters) *[[Arabic Supplement]] (0750–077F, 48 characters) *[[Arabic Extended-A]] (08A0–08FF, 74 characters) *[[Arabic Presentation Forms-A]] (FB50–FDFF, 611 characters) *[[Arabic Presentation Forms-B]] (FE70–FEFF, 141 characters) *[[Rumi Numeral Symbols]] (10E60–10E7F, 31 characters) *[[Indic Siyaq Numbers (Unicode block)|Indic Siyaq Numbers]] (1EC70–1ECBF, 68 characters) *[[Ottoman Siyaq Numbers (Unicode block)|Ottoman Siyaq Numbers]] (1ED00–1ED4F, 61 characters) *[[Arabic Mathematical Alphabetic Symbols]] (1EE00–1EEFF, 143 characters) The basic Arabic range encodes the standard letters and diacritics, but does not encode contextual forms (U+0621–U+0652 being directly based on [[ISO 8859-6]]); and also includes the most common diacritics and [[Arabic-Indic digits]]. The Arabic Supplement range encodes letter variants mostly used for writing African (non-Arabic) languages. The Arabic Extended-A range encodes additional Qur'anic annotations and letter variants used for various non-Arabic languages. The Arabic Presentation Forms-A range encodes contextual forms and ligatures of letter variants needed for Persian, Urdu, Sindhi and Central Asian languages. The Arabic Presentation Forms-B range encodes spacing forms of Arabic diacritics, and more contextual letter forms. The presentation forms are present only for compatibility with older standards, and are not currently needed for coding text.{{cite web | url=https://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode12.0.0/ch09.pdf#G37489 | date=March 2019 | title=Section 9.2: Arabic, Arabic Presentation Forms-B | work=The Unicode Standard | publisher=The Unicode Consortium}} The Arabic Mathematical Alphabetical Symbols block encodes characters used in Arabic mathematical expressions. The Indic Siyaq Numbers block containis a specialized subset of Arabic script that was used for accounting in [[India]] under the [[Mughal Empire|Mughals]] by the 17th century through the middle of the 20th century.{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2015/15121r2-indic-siyaq.pdf|title=L2/15-121R2: Proposal to Encode Indic Siyaq Numbers|date=2015-11-05|first=Anshuman|last=Pandey}}{{cite book | title = The Unicode Standard, Version 12.0 | chapter = Chapter 22: Symbols | publisher = Unicode, Inc | date = March 2019 | location = Mountain View, CA | url = https://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode12.0.0/ch22.pdf | isbn = 978-1-936213-22-1 }} The Ottoman Siyaq Numbers block contains a specialized subset of Arabic script, also known as ''Siyakat'' numbers, used for accounting in [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] documents.{{cite book | title = The Unicode Standard, Version 12.0 | chapter = Chapter 22: Symbols | publisher = Unicode, Inc | date = March 2019 | location = Mountain View, CA | url = https://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode12.0.0/ch22.pdf | isbn = 978-1-936213-22-1 }} ==Contextual forms== A demonstration for the basic alphabet used in [[Modern Standard Arabic]]: {|class="wikitable" |- !rowspan="2"|General

'''Abjjad''' is the first [[Arabic]] [[social network]] for readers, authors, and bloggers in the [[Middle East]].<ref name="test">[http://pando.com/2012/10/03/the-new-middle-east-women-at-the-center-of-a-startup-ecosystem-pt-4/ The New Middle East: Women at the Center of a Startup Ecosystem, Pt. 4.]</ref><ref name="test1">{{Cite web |url=http://www.mediame.com/en/news/pr-newswire/announcement/abjjadcom-embarks-crowd-investing-means-raise-funds-eureecacom |title=Abjjad.com embarks on crowd investing as a means to raise funds on eureeca.com. |access-date=2014-05-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502031827/http://mediame.com/en/news/pr-newswire/announcement/abjjadcom-embarks-crowd-investing-means-raise-funds-eureecacom |archive-date=2014-05-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> It was launched in June 2012 by Eman Haylooz and Tamim Al Manaseer.<ref name="test1" /><ref name="test2">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RF5cB9f23S8 Eman Hylooz Speech at GTF.]</ref> The website enables readers to sign in and have their own account, create their own virtual library where they have three lists: previously read list, currently reading list, and planning to read list. It also allows members to rate books, write their [[book]] reviews, add [[quotation|quotes]] to authors or books pages and enrich authors' pages with related information.<ref name="test3">[http://akhbar.alaan.tv/news/post/15806/city-dubai-summit-arabnet-digital-largest-professionals-businessmen آراء عدد من المشاركين في قمة عرب نت الرقمية 2013.]</ref>

==About Abjjad==
Abjjad was designed in Arabic to attract Arabic readers and authors to a one [[social network]]. It also aims to provide an accurate and enormous database for [[Arabic books]] and authors.<ref name="test4">[http://arablit.wordpress.com/2014/03/11/abjjad-an-arabic-social-network-for-books-with-a-big-vision/ Abjjad: An Arabic Social Network for Books with a Big Vision.]</ref>
Through providing an easy to use platform and sophisticated search engine, members can easily search for books or authors in Abjjad.<ref name="test5">[http://thinkarabized.com/2012/07/01/%D8%A3%D8%A8%D8%AC%D8%AF-%D8%AD%D9%8A%D8%AB-%D8%AA%D8%A8%D8%AF%D8%A3-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A1%D8%A9/ أبجد : حيث تبدأ القراءة !.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502103533/http://thinkarabized.com/2012/07/01/%D8%A3%D8%A8%D8%AC%D8%AF-%D8%AD%D9%8A%D8%AB-%D8%AA%D8%A8%D8%AF%D8%A3-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A1%D8%A9/ |date=May 2, 2014 }}</ref> Moreover, Abjjad contains a lot of book reviews and recommendations.<ref name="test3" /> Each author's page has enough information about him in addition to his quotes page which is enriched by the members. Abjjad recommends a variety of 10 books each week and a weekly article written by one of the members.<ref name="test4" /> It also allows members to follow each other, or follow authors or books to receive notifications once a new review has been added about the books or new information was added in the writer page.<ref name="test3" />

Abjjad is linked to [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] which provides Abjjad with an extensive database of English books making it easy for members to find English books. In addition, it includes more than 30 thousand Arabic books.

Members of Abjjad call themselves "Abjjadyeen" which created a brand for the website and helped in spreading it around the Middle East. The website is featured with the "Abjadyya" where members can use to filter what to appear on their timelines from members' status, book reviews or book ratings. The "Abjadyya" is a status a member can write and share with his followers where they can like and comment on it. Members of the website tend to use the word "Abjadyya" to refer to other members statuses.

==History==
[[File:إيمان حيلوز.jpg|alt=|left|thumb|200x200px|Eman Hylooz, Founder & CEO]]
In May2012, Oasis500 provided Abjjad with the seed funding to launch the website.<ref name="test6">[http://www.wamda.com/2014/02/how-arab-reading-social-network-abjad-exceeded-its-crowdfunding-target-on-eureeca Abjjad exceeded its goal on Eureeca by 30%; what's next for the Arabic reading social network?.]</ref> In June 2012, Abjjad was launched with a budget of 15 thousand dollars.<ref name="test6" /> Within the first three months more than 10 thousand members were registered in Abjjad.<ref name="test7">[http://www.mc-doualiya.com/programs/retweet-mcd/20130912-%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AA%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AA-%D9%82%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A1%D8%A9-%D8%B4%D8%A8%D9%83%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%A3%D8%A8%D8%AC%D8%AF-%D8%AB%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%A9-%D8%A5%D9%8A%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AD%D9%8A%D9%84%D9%88%D8%B2-%D9%85%D8%A4%D8%B3%D8%B3%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D9%81%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%84-%D8%AA%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AA%D8%B1-%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%B3%D8%A8%D9%88%D9%83 "أبجد" أول شبكة تواصل عربية للقراءة.]</ref>
Abjjad has participated in different local and international forums to meet several investors and entrepreneurs. In October 2012 Abjjad participated in [[Global thinkers forum]] in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] where Eman Hylooz, founder & CEO, presented the concept of Abjjad, its vision and future plans<ref name="test8">[http://globalthinkers.com/gtf-2012-awards-for-excellence/ GTF 2012 awards for excellence.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502032238/http://globalthinkers.com/gtf-2012-awards-for-excellence/ |date=May 2, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="test9">[http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/10/10/jordans-women-celebrate-success/ Jordan’s women celebrate success.]</ref>
In mid-December 2012 Abjjad participated in [[Global Entrepreneurship]] in [[Dubai]] where it was presented to investors as a start-up and a new project in the [[Middle East]].<ref name="test10">[https://www.zawya.com/story/Oasis500_Holds_8th_Angel_Network_Event_during_Global_Entrepreneurship_Summit_in_Dubai-ZAWYA20121222073709/ Oasis500 Holds 8th Angel Network Event during Global Entrepreneurship Summit in Dubai.]</ref> In February 2013 Abjjad was one of ten startups MENA apps has nominated from Jordan and Palestine to participate in [[startup Turkey]].<ref name="test11">[http://menaapps.com/mena-apps-has-partnered-with-etohum-to-include-mena-startups-in-the-startup-turkey-event-in-antalya/ MENA Startups pitch at StartupTurkey Event through MENA Apps partnership with Etohum.]</ref> In May 2013 Abjjad participated in [[World Economic Forum]] in Amman, Jordan<ref name="test12">[http://www.weforum.org/news/jordan-host-world-economic-forum-middle-east-and-north-africa-2013 Jordan to Host World Economic Forum on the Middle East and North Africa in 2013.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502000932/http://www.weforum.org/news/jordan-host-world-economic-forum-middle-east-and-north-africa-2013 |date=May 2, 2014 }}</ref> and later in June 2013 participated in Arab Net in Dubai.<ref name="test3" />

By the end of 2013 Abjjad won the Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum’s Best Arab Start-Up Business Award for 2013.<ref name="test6" />
During 29 October 2013 till January 2014 Abjjad has launched their campaign for crowd funding through [[Eureeca]]<ref name="test6" /><ref name="test14">[http://www.crowdfundinsider.com/2014/03/33089-award-winning-startup-abjjad-successfully-raises-equity-eureeca/ Award Winning Startup Abjjad Successfully Raises Equity on Eureeca.]</ref> Abjjad managed to raise $161,000 USD in 88 days from 43 regional donors, over $40,000 USD over its initial target.<ref name="test6" /><ref name="test14" />

==Features==
*Organizing books into three lists: previously read books, currently reading books and planning to read books.<ref name="test1" /><ref name="test6" /><ref name="test13">{{cite web|url=https://startupdb.arabnet.me/startup/2687/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140329040306/http://startupdb.arabnet.me/startup/2687/ |archivedate=2014-03-29 |df= }}</ref>
*Following readers, authors, or books.<ref name="test3" />
*Searching for books, know its rates and read reviews about them which help you to build an idea about books you are looking for<ref name="test" /><ref name="test1" />
*"Abjjadyyat" which enables you to view other members' statuses, books they have finished and rated, their reading lists and reviews.
*Abjjad provide you with a list of the most active members so you can follow them.
*Sharing your progress in a book with your followers.
*Writing book reviews and rating books from one to five stars.<ref name="test1" /><ref name="test3" />
*Enriching the authors' pages with adding information about them, adding books they have written or adding quotes from their books in their quotes pages.<ref name="test2" />
*Adding books you can't find in the website by using add a book feature.
*Writing an "Abjjadyya" which is a status to share with your followers where they can like it and comment on it.<ref name="test2" />
*Linking your Twitter and Facebook accounts to Abjjad to share your books ratings and reviews.
*Abjjad provides a recommendation of 10 books on a weekly basis which helps you to find new books to read.<ref name="test4" />
*Abjjad publishes an article per week which is written by a member of the website.

==Statistics==
There are more than 39 thousands members in the website who view more than 300 thousands pages per month. The website has recorded more than 11 thousands book reviews, more than 60 thousands book ratings and members have added books more than 120 thousand times into their lists.

==Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum prize==
Abjjad has won the Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum’s Best Arab Start-Up Business Award for 2013 session.<ref name="test6" />

==Abjjad in the media==
Abjjad has taken a huge interest in the Middle Eastern and western media; the author of Startup Rising: The Entrepreneurial Revolution Remaking the Middle East, Christopher M. Schroeder, has interviewed Eman Hylooz and wrote about her experience with Abjjad in his book.<ref name="test" /> In addition, France24-Monte Carlo Doualiya has interviewed Ms. Hylooz on Retweet program to discuss Abjjad idea and provide the latest statistics of the website.<ref name="test7" /> Moreover, Sky News Arabia interviewed Ms. Hylooz to relate her experience with Oasis500 and Eureeca in Abjjad's crowdinvestment campaignPage text.<ref name="test15">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fz6RXtYP05w "أبجد" موقع الكتروني يجمع هواة القراءة.]</ref> furthermore, Al-Aan TV interviewed Ms.Hylooz in ArabNet in Dubai, 2013.<ref name="test3" />
Abjjad has been mentioned on Oasis500 website as one of the five startups which the company funded and gained different prizes.<ref name="testx">[http://www.oasis500.com/arabic/%D8%AE%D9%85%D8%B3-%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A3%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%B5%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%82-%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%B3%D8%B3-500-%D9%8A%D8%AA/#.UwCexS55Wys.twitter خمس رياديات أردنيات من صندوق أويسس 500 يتفوقن في محافل عربية ودولية.]</ref> Wamda,<ref name="test6" /> Mediame<ref name="test1" /> and crowdfundinsider<ref name="test14" /> have discussed Abjjad's experience in the corwdinvestment on Eureeca. And the expert in the Arabic literature in English, M. Lynx Qualey, has interviewed Eman Hylooz in March 2013 to talk about Abjjad's story of success, how it differs from other social networks and what are its future plans.<ref name="test4" />

[[English language|English]] |website = [http://www.ainalyaqeen.com ''Ain al Yaqeen''] |issn = }} '''''Ain al Yaqeen''''' (''Heart of the Matter'' in English) is an [[Arabic]] [[news magazine]] published weekly, focusing on [[political]] topics. ==Profile== ''Ain al Yaqeen'' has also an [[English language|English]] edition.{{cite news|last=Tierney |first=Bill |title=Who is Prince Nayef? The most powerful man in Saudi Arabia. |url=http://67.43.13.183/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/002/018fdsio.asp?page=2 |accessdate=24 May 2012 |work=The Weekly Standard |date=23 December 2002 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It is published online.{{cite book|author1=William Wager Cooper|author2=Piyu Yue|title=Challenges of the Muslim World: Present, Future and Past|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3qwuhK3BBH8C&pg=PA198|year=2008|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|isbn=978-0-444-53243-5|page=198}} The magazine is seen as a government publication{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia Finances and Islam|url=http://www.arabicbible.com/for-christians/160-saudi-arabia/1440-saudi-arabia-finances-and-islam.html|publisher=Arabic Bible|accessdate=3 June 2012}} or as a semi-official weekly political magazine.{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabian newspapers|url=http://www.world-newspapers.com/sa.html|work=World Newspapers|accessdate=20 May 2012}} ==Contents== After it was revealed that a member of the royal family had indirectly funded one of the [[hijackers in the September 11 attacks]], [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Prince Nayef]] in an article published in the English edition of the weekly on 29 November 2002 claimed that the [[Jews]] were behind the [[September 11 attacks|attacks]]. ==See also== [[List of magazines in Saudi Arabia]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ain al Yaqeen}} [[Category:Saudi Arabian magazines]] [[Category:Arabic-language magazines]] [[Category:English-language magazines]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian news websites]] [[Category:English-language websites]] [[Category:Arabic-language websites]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Online magazines]] [[Category:News magazines]]

'''''Al Bawaba''''' (البوابة, Arabic for "the portal" or "the gate") is a news, blogging<ref>Slackman, Michael. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/22/world/middleeast/22dubai.html?bl&ex=1222228800&en=007cf9e8faaaf52a&ei=5087%0A Generation Faithful Young and Arab in Land of Mosques and Bars]." ''[[The New York Times]]''. 21 September 2008.</ref> and media website headquartered in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] with an office in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="Barnhurst2007">{{cite book|author=Kevin G. Barnhurst|title=Media Q: Media/queered : Visibility and Its Discontents|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GSKsujbaGG4C&pg=PA14|accessdate=20 September 2014|year=2007|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-0-8204-9532-3|page=14}}</ref> Since 2001 it publishes the [[Mena Report]], which covers the business and economics in Arab world.<ref>{{cite news|author=Massoud Derhally|title=MENA Report launched by Al Bawaba|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/mena-report-launched-by-al-bawaba-142212.html|date=30 May 2001|accessdate=20 September 2014|work=Arabian Business}}</ref> Al Bawaba bills itself as "the largest independent producer and distributor of content in the Middle East... [with] a full-time staff of journalists and editors covering the Middle East and North Africa region's events and news".<ref name="Website">{{cite web|title=The Al Bawaba Group corporate page|url=http://www.albawaba.com/corporate|work=Al Bawaba}}</ref>

==History and content==
''Al Bawaba'' was launched in 2000,<ref>{{cite web|title=Al Bawaba|url=http://www.mediame.com/en/country/pan_arab/al_bawaba|publisher=MediaME|accessdate=20 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924114127/http://www.mediame.com/en/country/pan_arab/al_bawaba|archive-date=2014-09-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and is owned by Al Bawaba Middle East Limited based in Amman, Jordan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=110282|title=Company Overview of Al Bawaba Middle East Limited|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref> It had an office in [[Kuwait]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/feb/05/world-news-guide-middle-east|title=World news guide: Middle East|date=5 February 2002|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>

The network consists of several web portals and websites, besides Al Bawaba including Al Bawaba Blogs, Al Bawaba Music (music site), Al Bawaba Games (Later Gaming Zone)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20010813084230/http://albawaba.com/games/index.php3?lang=e|title=Archived Al Bawaba Games homepage from August 2001|last=|first=|date=2001-08-13|website=web.archive.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-04-07}}</ref>, Sharekna (online photo and video management service), Syndigate (digital content syndication service).<ref name="Website"/> It publishes news stories related to the [[Middle East]]. It has separate [[English language|English]] and [[Arabic language|Arabic]] sections.

'''''Al-Masdar News''''' (sometimes abbreviated '''''AMN''''') ({{lang-ar|المصدر نيوز}}) is an [[online newspaper]] founded by Leith Abou Fadel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Contributors & Staff: Editorial Team|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/contributors/|website=Al Masdar News|accessdate=30 April 2017}}</ref> Al-Masdar is Arabic for "the source".<ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Masdar: The Source for Arabic Teaching and Learning|url=http://www.iskme.org/our-work/al-masdar-source-arabic-teaching-and-learning|publisher=[[Institute for the Study of Knowledge Management in Education|ISKME.org]]|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref> Al-Masdar's coverage focuses largely on conflict zones in the Middle East: Syria, Yemen, and Iraq. Al-Masdar has been described as being pro-president [[Bashar al-Assad]].

==Background==
''Al-Masdar News'' (AMN) was launched in August 2014 as a media service that provides frontline news and analysis from the Middle East.<ref>[https://www.almasdarnews.com/about/ Al-Masdar News - About]</ref>

== Criticism ==
Following the April 2017 [[Khan Shaykhun chemical attack]] in the [[Idlib Governorate]], ''al-Masdar News'' published an opinion article entitled "Jumping to conclusions; something is not adding up in Idlib chemical weapons attack".<ref>Antonopoulos, Paul. [https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/jumping-conclusions-something-not-adding-idlib-chemical-weapons-attack/ Jumping to conclusions; something is not adding up in Idlib chemical weapons attack]. ''Al-Masdar News''. 2017-04-04.</ref> A report by the [[Atlantic Council]]'s [[Digital Forensic Research Lab]] (DFRLab) published three days later described a "[[digital forensics]]" trail which showed how this ''al-Masdar'' opinion article was later linked by conspiracy, pro-Russian and far-right websites. It described ''al-Masdar News'' as "an unofficial government outlet" and said that it had "repeatedly attacked regime critics and witnesses to regime atrocities, notably the [[White Helmets (Syrian Civil War)|White Helmets]]."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nimmo|first1=Ben|last2=Barojan|first2=Donara|title=How the alt-right brought #SyriaHoax to America|url=https://medium.com/dfrlab/how-the-alt-right-brought-syriahoax-to-america-47745118d1c9|website=Medium.com|publisher=[[Atlantic Council]]|date=7 April 2017}}</ref> ''[[Business Insider]]'' showed the conclusions in the AMN article differing markedly from those of other analysts.<ref name=BusinessInisider/> After deputy editor Paul Antonopoulos (author of the controversial opinion article ''Jumping to conclusions'') was shown to be active on the [[neo-Nazi]] site [[Stormfront (website)|Stormfront]], he was forced to resign from al-Masdar on 28 April 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/journalist-paul-antonopoulos-outed-for-racist-slurs/news-story/705cf62a502c41cf515a013ebe60d8a9|title=Journalist Paul Antonopoulos outed for racist slurs|date=2 May 2017|author=Jennine Khalik|newspaper=The Australian|accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref> ''Al-Masdar'' issued a statement on behalf of its board of directors,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/contributors/#board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors|work=Al-Masdar News|date=3 May 2017}}</ref> saying they found his behaviour "wholly unacceptable" and strongly condemned it, while also apologizing to its readers and all those offended by his actions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/board-directors-statement-april-28th-2017/|title=Board of Directors Statement – April 28th, 2017|work=Al-Masdar News|date=28 April 2017}}</ref>

The website was described by the [[BBC]] and ''Newsweek'' as having a pro-Syrian government viewpoint,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-38155933|title=Syria conflict: 'Israeli jets' strike outside Damascus|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|date=30 November 2016|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="newsweek-Mar2017">{{cite news|first=Tom|last=O'Connor|title=Syria at War: As U.S. Bombs Rebels, Russia Strikes ISIS and Israel Targets Assad|url=http://www.newsweek.com/syria-war-us-rebels-russia-isis-israel-569812|publisher=Newsweek|date=17 March 2017|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref> while ''[[The Independent]]'' describes it as "sympathetic to the Syrian regime".<ref name="independent Feb2017">{{cite news|last=McKernan|first=Bethan|title=Syrian army creates unit just for women after so many sign up to fight Isis|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syrian-army-creates-womens-unit-fighting-isis-islamic-state-bashar-al-assad-regime-terror-group-a7558896.html|work=The Independent|date=2 February 2017}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' has described it as a "pro-government website".<ref name="nyt-Apr2017">{{cite news|first1=Robert|last1=Mackey|first2=Hwaida|last2=Saad|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/24/world/europe/syrian-refugee-tripped-in-hungary-denies-extremist-ties.html|title=Syrian Refugee Tripped in Hungary Fights Unfounded Accusations of Extremist Ties|publisher=New York Times|date=23 September 2015|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref> Leonid Bershidsky writing in [[Bloomberg News]], also calls al-Masdar "somewhat pro-Assad."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bertshidsky|first1=Leonid|title=Trump Squeezes Putin in Syria. Don't Assume That's Good.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-04-07/trump-s-squeezes-putin-in-syria-that-s-risky}}</ref>

''Business Insider'' reporter Natasha Bertrand has described Leith Abou Fadel, the editor of ''al-Masdar'', as someone who had pushed a conspiracy theory in the past, and described him as an "Assad loyalist".<ref name=BusinessInisider>{{cite news|last1=Bertrand|first1=Natasha|title=From Al-Masdar to InfoWars: How a pro-Assad conspiracy theory got picked up by the far-right|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/syriahoax-conspiracy-alex-jones-infowars-syria-trump-hoax-2017-4?r=US&IR=T|work=[[Business Insider]] UK|date=8 April 2017|language=en}}</ref>

''The New York Times'' also accused Fadel of spreading [[fake news|unfounded misinformation]] about a victim of the [[Petra László incident]].<ref name="nyt-Apr2017"/>

'''Al-Sadr Online''' is the official website of the High Board for Media of Al-Sadr's Office.  The High Board is the media organization of [[Muqtada Al-Sadr]], a [[Shia Islam|Shia Muslim]] [[Iraq]]i religious and political leader.  The site, which commenced operation in 2007, performs several functions in support of [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] objectives.    The site's distinct format includes a section in which [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Al-Sadr]] offers religious opinions in response to queries from site followers.  Al-Sadr Online publishes news about [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] political, social, and religious activities in southern [[Iraq]] and the [[Arab]] world.  In addition, the Board's staff also posts commentary on issues pertaining to [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] and pan-Arab politics as well as some international news.  The site posts numerous links to pages of organizations sympathetic to the [[Sadrist Movement]], many of which are based in [[Iran]] and [[Lebanon]].  Al-Sadr Online posts most of its content in [[Arabic Language|Arabic]], though it does maintain a less robust [[English Language|English]] page.

==Origins==
Al-Sadr Online is registered in [[Najaf]], [[Iraq]] and has utilized the URL alsadronline.net since 21 August 2008.  Previously, Al-Sadr's media organization used the URL alsadronline.com.<ref name=Snoop>{{cite web|title=AlSadrOnline.net Information and Statistics|url=http://alsadronline.net.w3snoop.com/|work=Snoop Summary|publisher=w3snoop.com|accessdate=2 May 2012}}</ref>  The site is maintained by the High Board for Media of Al-Sadr's Office, the media of office of [[Hujjat al-Islam|Hojatoleslam]] [[Muqtada Al-Sadr]], the leader of the most prominent branch of the [[Shia Islam|Shia]] [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] movement in [[Iraq]].<ref name=SadrOnline>{{cite web|title=Al-Sadr Online|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/|work=Al-Sadr Online|publisher=High Board for Media of Al-Sadr's Office|accessdate=4 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502120447/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/|archive-date=2 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>   The High Board for Media is headed by Abdul-Jabar Al-Hajami.<ref>{{cite web|title=Political High Board Visits Media High Board|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/3648-political-high-board-visits-media-high-board.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=5 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120717131726/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/3648-political-high-board-visits-media-high-board.html|archive-date=17 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>  Al-Sadr Online is hosted on the NS1.MARAM-IQ.NET and NS2.MARAM-IQ.NET servers.<ref name=Snoop />  Previous media ventures of Al-Sadr's media organization included the ''[[Al-Hawza]]'' newspaper which was closed on 28 March 2004 by [[Combined Joint Task Force 7]], the active Ishraqat Al-Sadr newspaper, and the Al-Amarah News Network.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gettleman|first=Jeffrey|title=G.I.'s Padlock Baghdad Paper Accused of Lies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/03/29/world/gi-s-padlock-baghdad-paper-accused-of-lies.html|work=New York Times|accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BBC Monitoring Headlines, Quotes From Iraqi Press 19 Oct 05|url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/international/277043/bbc_monitoring_headlines_quotes_from_iraqi_press_19_oct_05/|work=Asia Africa Intelligence WIre|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref>

==Content==
===Sadrist News===
The [[Sadrist]] News section of Al-Sadr Online provides extensive reporting on the daily activities of Muqtada Al-Sadr's political and cultural organizations.  The articles, which generally include photos or illustrations, cover the wide range of community service activities Sadrist organizations organize throughout [[Iraq]], especially in the [[Shia Islam|Shia]] majority southern provinces.  Friday prayer sermons of [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Sadr]]-affiliated religious leaders are recounted, as well as messages from [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] [[Council of Representatives of Iraq|Council of Representatives]] members, [[Cabinet of Iraq|Cabinet]] ministers, and other politicians.<ref>{{cite web|title=Governor of Maysan Expresses Optimism on Training Courses of Human Abilities|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4317-governor-of-maysan-expresses-optimism-on-training-courses-of-human-abilities.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=6 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Minister of Construction and Housing Visits Martyr al-Sadr Office in [[Mohammad Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr|Muhammad Muhammad Sadeq Al-Sadr]], [[Mohammad Baqir al-Sadr|Muhammad Baqir Al-Sadr]], and [[Musa Al-Sadr]].<ref>{{cite web|title=32nd Anniversary of Martyrdom of Sayyid Muhammad Baqir al-Sadr|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4215-32-anniversary-of-martyrdom-of-sayyid-muhammad-baqr-al-sadr.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=6 May international policymakers in [[Iraq]], foreign nations, and international institutions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Protests in Basra Against Joe States Forces - Iraq|United States forces in Iraq]].

===Iraq News===
The [[Iraq]] News section of the website includes reporting and commentary on politics and economic development throughout the country.  The section highlights [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] officials' roles in [[Iraq]]'s political process and events in southern [[Iraq]] in particular.<ref>{{cite web|title=MP Uday Awad: Parliament will Question Minister of Electricity|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/iraqnews/4309-mp-uday-awad-parliament-will-question-minister-of-electricity.html|work=Iraq News|publisher=Al-Sadr ===Arab and World News===
The Arab and World News section of Al-Sadr online covers world events significant to the [[Sadrist Movement]] and to [[Shia Islam|Shia Muslims]]. The site publishes stories relaying [[Iran]]ian government statements on the efforts of the [[United States]] and some European nations to halt the [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iranian nuclear program]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Iran Demands to Lift Embargo|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/4230-iran-demands-to-lift-embargo.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The site gives ample coverage to movements demanding greater rights for [[Shia Islam|Shia]] minorities in nations such as [[Bahrain]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Kuwait]], and [[Yemen]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yemeni youth revolution rebel US & Saudi Arabia interference|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3278-yemeni-youth-revolution-rebel-us-saudi-arabia-interference.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bahraini Government has no real intention for dialogue|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3303-bahraini-government-has-no-real-intention-for-dialogue.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120719194943/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3303-bahraini-government-has-no-real-intention-for-dialogue.html|archive-date=19 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Nimr: "We will Never Give up Obtaining our Legitimate Right"|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3758-Al-Nimr%3A-%E2%80%9CWe-will-Never-Give-up-Obtaining-our-Legitimate-Right%E2%80%9D.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hezbollah: Resistance is Much Stronger Than in 2006|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/4306-hezbollah-resistance-is-much-stronger-than-in-2006.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712033849/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/4306-hezbollah-resistance-is-much-stronger-than-in-2006.html|archive-date=12 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The activities of affiliated political organizations such as [[Hezbollah]] are related in this section as well. The site has documented the [[Arab Spring]] series of revolutions with stories supportive of dissidents, with those from [[Syria]] being the notable exception.

===Religious Opinions===
The Religious Opinions column of Al-Sadr online is the official medium for broadcasting Muqtada Al-Sadr's controversial [[Fatwā|fatwa]]-like rulings on religious, social, and political issues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Administrator Notes |url=http://al3marh.net/news/index.php?act=artc&id=2516 |work=Hawza Spokesman Announcements |publisher=Al-Amarah News Network |accessdate=6 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006113923/http://al3marh.net/news/index.php?act=artc&id=2516 |archivedate=6 October 2014 }}</ref> [[Muqtada Al Sadr|Al-Sadr]] has attained the clerical position of [[Hujjat al-Islam|Hojatoleslam]], which does not qualify him to render religious opinions (perform [[Ijtihad]]) as would an [[Ayatollah]] in the traditions of [[Ja'fari jurisprudence|Shia Islamic jurisprudence]].  [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Al-Sadr]] has asserted wide latitude to interpret the previous rulings of his father, [[Mohammad Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr|Muhammad Muhammad Sadeq Al-Sadr]] and relate them to contemporary issues.  Despite the opposition of many [[Shia Islam|Shia]] institutions, [[Muqtada Al-Sadr]]'s rulings are widely accepted by his youthful following.<ref>{{cite web|last=Visser|first=Reidar|title=Religious Allegiances Among Pro-Iranian Special Groups in Iraq|url=http://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/religious-allegiances-among-pro-iranian-special-groups-in-iraq|work=CTC Sentinel|publisher=United States Military Academy Combating Terrorism Center|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref> The rulings, which are generally initiated by queries from [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Al-Sadr]] followers, provide religious justification for resistance against [[United States Forces - Iraq|United States forces in Iraq]] as well as purging [[Ba'ath Party|Ba'athist]] elements from the government.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sayyed Muqtada al-Sadr Answers Question About Occupation|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3702-sayyed-muqtada-al-sadr-answers-question-about-occupation.html|work=Religious Opinions|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515130451/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3702-sayyed-muqtada-al-sadr-answers-question-about-occupation.html|archive-date=15 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>   The rulings also clarify [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Al-Sadr's]] positions with respect to his support for the [[State of Law Coalition]] led by Prime Minister [[Nouri Al-Maliki]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Sadr responses to a religious question|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3064-al-sadr-responses-to-a-religious-question.html|work=Religious Opinions|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020225240/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3064-al-sadr-responses-to-a-religious-question.html|archive-date=20 October 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sayyed Muqtada: I Support Campaigns Against Baathists|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3730-sayyed-muqtada-i-support-campaigns-against-baathists.html|work=Religious Opinions|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425203752/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3730-sayyed-muqtada-i-support-campaigns-against-baathists.html|archive-date=25 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Since 2010, [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Al-Sadr]] has taken on social and cultural issues more frequently, with statements advocating restrictions on mixing of genders and prohibition of alcohol among those posted by Al-Sadr Online.<ref>{{cite web|title=Seid Muqtada reponds to a question...|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3344-seid-muqtada-reponses-to-a-question.html|work=Religious Opinions|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020225309/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/religious-opinions/3344-seid-muqtada-reponses-to-a-question.html|archive-date=20 October 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Alcohol Shops Spread in Baghdad|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4066-alcohol-shops-spread-in-baghdad.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120717171757/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4066-alcohol-shops-spread-in-baghdad.html|archive-date=17 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

===Other Media===
Features unique to the [[Arabic language]] version of the site include links to affiliate media organizations, video clips of [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] commemorations and other events of note, and features on [[Shia Islam]]ic philosophy.  In addition, there are sections detailing the activities of international [[Sadrist Movement]] offices.  An Interviews and Investigations column posts exchanges with key figures in [[Iraq]]i society and examines post-conflict lives of [[Iraq]]i citizens.<ref name=SadrOnline />

==Trends in Reporting and Commentary==
===Iraq War Era===
The early years of Al-Sadr Online coincided with the fallout from the [[Battle of Basra (2008)|Charge of the Knights]] operation in Basra and other areas of southern [[Iraq]], during which [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] militias were expelled from urban areas.  During this period, Sadrist Movement leaders shifted the priorities of the organization, transitioning former [[Mahdi Army|Jaysh Al-Mahdi]] fighters into roles supporting the Mumahidun, the social and cultural wing of the party.  The reporting on the website reflected this shift, as the activities of the Muhamidun were given ample space on its pages.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rahimi|first=Babak|title=The Future of Moqtada Al-Sadr's New Jaysh Al-Mahdi|url=http://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/the-future-of-moqtada-al-sadr%E2%80%99s-new-jaysh-al-mahdi|work=CTC Sentinel|publisher=United States Military Academy Combating Terrorism Center|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref>   The movement was also experiencing challenges with breakaway factions such as [[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq|Asa'ib Ahl Al-Haq]], and anti-dissident commentary became more prevalent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asaib Ahl al‐Haq and the Khazali Special Groups Network|url=http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/reports/Asaib%20Ahl%20al%20Haq%20and%20the%20Khazali%20Special%20Groups%20Network.pdf|publisher=Institute for the Study of War|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref>   Reports on [[United States Forces - Iraq|United States Forces']] presence in [[Iraq]] were harshly critical.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fartusi: Congratulations to those who rebel US occupation.|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/iraqnews/3154-fartusi-congratulations-to-those-who-rebel-us-occupation.html|work=Iraq News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120728175209/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/iraqnews/3154-fartusi-congratulations-to-those-who-rebel-us-occupation.html|archive-date=28 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>   The site also provided guidance and context to [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist]] political activities during the run-up to the [[Iraq]]i parliamentary elections of 2010 and afterward as political blocs negotiated leadership positions in the government.

===United States Forces Withdrawal from Iraq===
As [[United States Forces - Iraq|United States Forces]] withdrew from [[Iraq]], Al-Sadr Online addressed a number of challenges and opportunities facing the movement.  Negotiations for continuing [[United States|U.S.]] military presence in the country failed to establish a status of [[status of forces agreement]] which would allow continued cooperation. Al-Sadr Online portrayed residual [[United States|U.S.]] political and economic influences in the country as an enduring threat to [[Iraq]]i sovereignty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sayyed Muqtada's statement about the US withdrawal|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/3600-sayyed-muqtada-s-statement-about-the-us-withdrawal.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=6 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120730075838/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/3600-sayyed-muqtada-s-statement-about-the-us-withdrawal.html|archive-date=30 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> At the same time, the site outlined the [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist Movement's]] plans for demobilizing the armed [[Promised Day Brigades]] while maintaining a capability to activate militia members in cases of threats to the organizations agenda.<ref name=Mumahid/> The withdrawal also allowed the [[Sadrist Movement]] to renew calls for release of militia members from prisons, and the site's staff wrote pieces advocating for their pardons.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sadrists in Prison of Baladiyat|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4087-sadrists-in-prison-of-baladiyat.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=6 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303105626/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4087-sadrists-in-prison-of-baladiyat.html|archive-date=3 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Al-Sadr Online began to emphasize coverage of Sadrist education and community service projects during this time period.

===Post-War===
The [[Arab Spring]] uprisings commencing in early 2011 opened up a new front in the media campaign of the [[Sadrist Movement]].  Al-Sadr Online generally was supportive of the rebels in the affected countries for a variety of reasons. [[Bahrain|Bahrain's]] sizable [[Shia Islam|Shia]] minority looked to [[Iraq]] for support for its demands for greater political access, and Al-Sadr Online responded with favorable portrayals of [[Bahrain]]i protesters.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bahraini security forces suppressed a peaceful protest, on Saturday|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3699-bahraini-security-forces-suppressed-a-peaceful-protest-on-saturday.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120720051723/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3699-bahraini-security-forces-suppressed-a-peaceful-protest-on-saturday.html|archive-date=20 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Muammar Gaddafi|Muammar Qaddafi]] regime in [[Libya]] was suspected of ordering the killing of [[Muqtada Al-Sadr|Muqtada Al-Sadr's]] relative [[Musa al-Sadr|Musa Al-Sadr]], and Libyan rebels received favorable coverage from the site's writers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Colo. Gaddafi lost control the situations in Libya|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3400-colo-gaddafi-lost-control-the-situations-in-libya.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718030424/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3400-colo-gaddafi-lost-control-the-situations-in-libya.html|archive-date=18 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The insurgency in [[Yemen]] included [[Shia Islam|Shia]] [[Houthi|Huthi]] rebels from the northwestern region of the country, and protesters of the [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] regime received favorable treatment by Al-Sadr Online.<ref>{{cite web|title=Protests in Yemen against President Saleh|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3637-protests-in-yemen-against-presedent-saleh.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120720050754/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3637-protests-in-yemen-against-presedent-saleh.html|archive-date=20 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime's relations with [[Israel]] and tense relationship with [[Iran]] earned it negative coverage from Al-Sadr Online as [[Egypt]]ian security forces attempted to quell demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Millions demonstrate in Egypt|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3337-millions-demonstrate-in-egypt.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712184000/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/3337-millions-demonstrate-in-egypt.html|archive-date=12 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>   As demonstrations were violently suppressed in [[Syria]], however, Al-Sadr Online took a different tone similar to that of the [[Syria]]n government, pushing for dialogue and resisting calls for regime change.<ref>{{cite web|title=Syria Release 265 Detainees|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/4337-syria-release-265-detainees.html|work=Arab and World News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523180106/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/arab-world-news/4337-syria-release-265-detainees.html|archive-date=23 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>   Aside from the [[Arab Spring]] coverage, Al-Sadr Online highlighted the [[Sadrist Movement|Sadrist Movement's]] efforts to reach out to other religious groups in [[Iraq]], featuring meetings at [[Christianity in Iraq|Christian]] churches, [[Mandaeism|Mandaean]] gatherings, and events in [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] and [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdish regions]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Delegation of Honest Office Visits Sabian Headquarters in Basra|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4307-delegation-of-honest-office-visits-sabian-headquarters-in-basra.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=6 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120720113146/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4307-delegation-of-honest-office-visits-sabian-headquarters-in-basra.html|archive-date=20 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Sadr' Office Visited Halabja City|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4261-al-sadr-office-visited-halabja-city.html|work=Sadrist News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=6 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718055129/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/news/4261-al-sadr-office-visited-halabja-city.html|archive-date=18 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>    Al-Sadr Online has documented the role that [[Muqtada Al-Sadr]] has staked out as an intermediary between Prime Minister [[Nouri Al-Maliki]] and [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] and [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] politicians threatening secession of northern provinces from [[Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mr. al-Araji: Disagreements are Solved by the Dialogue|url=http://www.alsadronline.net/en/iraqnews/4285-mr-al-araji-disagreements-are-solved-by-the-dialogue.html|work=Iraq News|publisher=Al-Sadr Online|accessdate=7 May 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729185502/http://www.alsadronline.net/en/iraqnews/4285-mr-al-araji-disagreements-are-solved-by-the-dialogue.html|archive-date=29 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
