pages.title: Amaq News Agency
pages.text:
{{Lead too short|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox website | name = Amaq News Agency
{{lang|ar|وكالة أعماق الإخبارية}} | logo = Amaq logo.svg | logo_size = 100px | launch date = 2014 | current status = Active | language = Arabic, English, French, German, Spanish, Italian, Russian, Bengali, Urdu{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} | founder = Rayan Meshaal{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/syrie/article/2017/05/31/un-fondateur-d-aamaq-l-agence-de-propagande-de-l-ei-tue-en-syrie_5136836_1618247.html|title=Un fondateur d’Aamaq, l’agence de propagande de l’EI, tué en Syrie|date=31 May 2017|publisher=|via=Le Monde}} }} '''Amaq News Agency''' ({{lang-ar|وكالة أعماق الإخبارية}}) is a news outlet linked to the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL). It is often the "first point of publication for claims of responsibility by the group".{{Cite news|title=A News Agency With Scoops Directly From ISIS, and a Veneer of Objectivity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/15/world/middleeast/a-news-agency-with-scoops-directly-from-isis-and-a-veneer-of-objectivity.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 January 2016|accessdate=5 August 2016}} ==History== Amaq was created by Syrian journalist Baraa Kadek, who joined ISIL in late 2013, and seven others who originally worked for Halab News Network.{{cite web|url=https://it.notizie.yahoo.com/siria-fondatore-agenzia-ufficiale-isis-amaq-ucciso-raid-151213768.html|title=Siria, fondatore agenzia ufficiale Isis "Amaq" ucciso in raid Usa|language=Italian|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=2017-08-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170531180038/https://it.notizie.yahoo.com/siria-fondatore-agenzia-ufficiale-isis-amaq-ucciso-raid-151213768.html|archive-date=31 May 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', it has "a direct connection with ISIS", from which it "gets tips". Its name was taken from [[Amik Valley]] in [[Hatay Province]], which is mentioned in a [[hadith]] as the site of an [[Islamic eschatology|"apocalyptic victory over non-believers"]].{{cite web|url=https://eng-archive.aawsat.com/asharq-al-awsat-english/world-news/amaq-247-news-agency-run-isis|title=Amaq – 24/7 News Agency Run by ISIS|work=Asharq Al-Awsat|date=26 March 2016}} Amaq News Agency was first noticed by [[SITE Intelligence Group|SITE]] during the [[Siege of Kobanî]] (Syria) in 2014, when its updates were shared among ISIL fighters. It became more widely known after it began reporting claims of responsibility for terrorist attacks in Western countries, such as the [[2015 San Bernardino attack]], for which ISIL officially claimed responsibility the next day. An Amaq cameraman shot the first footage of the [[Palmyra offensive (May 2015)|capture of Palmyra in 2015]]. Amaq launched an official [[mobile app]] in 2015 and has warned against unofficial versions that reportedly have been used to [[spying|spy]] on its users.{{cite news|title=Islamic State: Fake version of Isis Amaq news app is spying on its supporters|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/islamic-state-fake-version-isis-news-app-amaq-android-spying-its-supporters-1563313|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=2 June 2016}} It also uses a [[Telegram (messaging service)|Telegram]] account.{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/europe-attacks-nice-claim-idINKCN0ZW0GS|title=Islamic State claims responsibility for Nice attack – Amaq news agency|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2017-08-19}} It had a [[WordPress]]-based blog, but it was removed without explanation in April 2016. On 31 May 2017, a Facebook post announced Amaq's founder, Baraa Kadek AKA Rayan Meshaal, had been killed with his daughter by an American airstrike on [[Mayadin]]. The post was reportedly made by his younger brother. [[Reuters]] could not immediately verify this account.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/05/31/us-led-coalition-strike-kills-founder-islamic-state-media-outlet/|title=US-led coalition strike 'kills founder of Islamic State media outlet Amaq'|website=Telegraph|accessdate=2017-08-19}} On 27 July 2017, the US confirmed that Kadek had been killed by a coalition airstrike near Mayadin between 25 and 27 May 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.centcom.mil/MEDIA/PRESS-RELEASES/Press-Release-View/Article/1259744/coalition-removes-isis-leaders-from-battlefield/|title=Coalition removes ISIS leaders from battlefield|publisher=U.S. Central Command|date=27 July 2017}} In June 2017, German police arrested a 23-year-old Syrian man identified only as Mohammed G., accusing him of communicating with the alleged perpetrator of the [[2016 Malmö Muslim community centre arson]] in order to report to Amaq.{{cite news|last1=Dearden|first1=Lizzie|title=Isis propagandist who linked terrorists with Amaq 'news agency' arrested in Germany|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/isis-amaq-agency-claim-responsibility-attacks-member-arrested-germany-mohammed-g-syrian-latest-a7782586.html|accessdate=11 July 2017|work=The Independent|date=9 June 2017}} On March 21, 2019, the U.S. Department of State officially deemed Amaq an alias of ISIL, and thus a [[Foreign Terrorist Organization]].[https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2019/03/290548.htm "Amendments to the Terrorist Designations of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria", by the United States Department of State] ==Character== Amaq publishes a stream of short news reports, both text and video, on the [[mobile app]] [[Telegram (software)|Telegram]]. The reports take on the trappings of mainstream journalism, with "Breaking News" headings, and [[Embedded journalism|embedded reporters]] at the scenes of ISIL battles. The reports try to appear neutral, toning down the jihadist language and sectarian slurs ISIL uses in its official releases. Charlie Winter of the Transcultural Conflict and Violence Initiative at [[Georgia State University]], and [[Rita Katz]] of [[SITE Intelligence Group]] in Washington say Amaq functions much like the state-owned news agency of ISIL, though the group does not acknowledge it as such. Katz said it behaves "like a state media. ISIS sees themselves as a state, as a country—and a country needs to have its own media". Amaq appears to have been created, or allowed to develop, by ISIS as a way to have a news outlet that is controlled by the group but is somewhat removed from it, giving ISIL more of the appearance of legitimacy. ==Reliability== {{Over-quotation|section|date=December 2018}} According to Chris Tomson of the Assad-friendly [[Al-Masdar News]], Amaq "is usually accurate" when reporting ISIL advances but "never admits caliphate losses."Tomson, Chris. [https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/5-syrian-soldiers-killed-near-palmyra-despite-huge-territorial-setback-isis/ 5 Syrian soldiers killed near Palmyra despite huge territorial setback for ISIS]. ''Al-Masdar News''. 2017-04-27. According to [[Rukmini Maria Callimachi|Rukmini Callimachi]] in ''[[The New York Times]]'': "Despite a widespread view that the Islamic State opportunistically claims attacks with which it has little genuine connection, its track record—minus a handful of exceptions—suggests a more rigorous protocol. At times, the Islamic State has gotten details wrong, or inflated casualty figures, but the gist of its claims is typically correct. The group has made it clear that it considers itself responsible both for acts carried out by its own personnel, as well as acts carried out by people who lack direct ties to the group but were inspired by its propaganda. In several instances, moreover, the Islamic State has claimed attacks before the identities of the killers were known".{{cite news|last1=Kallimachi|first1=Rukmini|title=Syrian Accused of Working for ISIS News Agency Is Arrested in Germany|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/08/world/europe/syrian-accused-of-working-for-isis-news-agency-is-arrested-in-germany.html?_r=0|accessdate=9 June 2017|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 June 2017}} According to journalist [[Graeme Wood (journalist)|Graeme Wood]] writing in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' in October 2017, "The idea that the Islamic State simply scans the news in search of mass killings, then sends out press releases in hope of stealing glory, is false. Amaq may learn details of the attacks from mainstream media—and often gets those details wrong, also like mainstream media—but its claim of credit typically flows from an Amaq-specific source." However, Wood continued, "A false claim of credit in the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]] will effectively shred the Islamic State's news agency's credibility. It will become a news agency that was once reliable, and now associates itself indiscriminately with heavily armed crazy people in casinos".{{cite news|last1=Wood|first1=Graeme|title=Why Did the Islamic State Claim the Las Vegas Shooting?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2017/10/isis-amaq-las-vegas/541746/|accessdate=2 October 2017|work=The Atlantic|date=2 October 2017}} According to an October 2017 article in ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', "Historically, ISIS has not been arbitrary in the attacks it claims have been carried out by its supporters. Experts who track the group closely say that when it comes to attacks in the West, if ISIS is claiming responsibility, there typically was some kind of connection between the perpetrator and the group. ... until recently, claims of responsibility put out through official channels were seen as reliable." However, "That might be changing," as ISIS loses territorial sovereignty in Syria. ''The Hill'' points to two incidents in the summer of 2017, the [[2017 Resorts World Manila attack|Resorts World Manila attack]] and a false claim that bombs had been planted at [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]] in Paris. In addition, the claim of an ISIS connection to the 2017 Las Vegas shooting appeared to be false.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/353518-terror-experts-puzzled-by-isis-claim-in-las-vegas-attack|title=Terror experts puzzled by ISIS claim in Las Vegas attack|last1=Williams|first1=Katie Bo|date=2 October 2017|accessdate=3 October 2017|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}} According to Rita Katz on the [[SITE Intelligence Group]] website, calling a terrorist a "soldier of the caliphate (warrior from the caliphate)" in a statement issued by Amaq, was the usual way in which ISIS indicated that it inspired an attack.{{cite news|last1=Katz|first1=Rita|title=Is ISIS’ Comment on the Manhattan Attack Out of the Ordinary? Not Really|url=https://news.siteintelgroup.com/blog/index.php/categories/jihad/entry/432-is-isis%E2%80%99-comment-on-the-manhattan-attack-out-of-the-ordinary-not-really|accessdate=8 November 2017|publisher=SITE Intelligence Group|date=6 November 2017}} Centrally coordinated attacks were usually described in language such as "executed by a detachment belonging to the Islamic State", and are often announced by both Amaq and by ISIS' central media command. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} [[Category:2014 establishments in Syria]] [[Category:Arabic-language media]] [[Category:Arabic-language websites]] [[Category:Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant media]] [[Category:Mobile applications]] [[Category:Publications established in 2014]] [[Category:Syrian news websites]]

[http://en.ammonnews.net/ Official English website] }} '''''Ammon ''''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] عمون) also known as '''''Ammon News''''' is a private news agency and alternative news body based in [[Amman]], Jordan. It is the first [[online newspaper]] of Jordan. The agency has both Arabic and English language websites. The name of the agency, ''Ammon'', refers to ancient name of Amman, capital city of Jordan.{{cite web|title=Ammon news, a great grassroots experience in Jordan|url=http://mediaoriente.com/2008/11/24/ammon-news-a-great-grassroots-experience-in-jordan/|work=Media Oriente|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=24 November 2008|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130921070751/http://mediaoriente.com/2008/11/24/ammon-news-a-great-grassroots-experience-in-jordan/|archive-date=21 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==History and profile== ''Ammon News'' using the slogan "Voice of the Silent Majority" (in Arabic: صوت الأغلبية الصامتة) is a private news agency.{{cite news|title=Jordan profile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14636310|accessdate=21 September 2013|work=BBC|date=4 June 2013}}{{cite web|title=Country Profile - Jordan|url=http://www.newshoundpr.com/PDFs/NettResults%20Public%20Relations%20Middle%20East.pdf|work=NettResults|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922124248/http://www.newshoundpr.com/PDFs/NettResults%20Public%20Relations%20Middle%20East.pdf|archive-date=22 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} It was launched in 2006 by Sameer Al Hayari and Bassel Elkour, being the first online newspaper of Jordan.{{cite web|title=The talk of Amman is Ammon|url=http://www.menassat.com/?q=en/news-articles/2142-talk-amman-ammon|work=Menassat|accessdate=21 September 2013|author=Hilmi Al Asmar|date=15 November 2007}}{{cite web|author1=Rana F. Sweis|author2=Dina Baslan|title=Mapping Digital Media: Jordan|url=http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/sites/default/files/mapping-digital-media-jordan-20131121.pdf|publisher=Open Society Foundations|accessdate=11 September 2014|date=10 October 2013}} Elkour is also the editor-in-chief of the news portal.{{cite news|title=Jordanian News site “Ammon” Accuses Jordan Intelligence of Hacking the Site|url=http://arabcrunch.com/2011/02/jordanian-news-site-%E2%80%9Cammon%E2%80%9D-accuses-jordan-intelligence-of-hacking-its-website.html|accessdate=21 September 2013|newspaper=Arab Crunch|date=14 February 2011}} Wael Jaraisheh is the managing editor of ''Ammon News''.{{cite news|title=Jordan journalists sound alarm over new media restrictions|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/12417|accessdate=21 September 2013|newspaper=Al Akhbar|date=19 September 2012}} He also contributes to the website in parliamentary affairs.{{cite news|author1=Ali Al Rawashdah|title=New Jordanian government wins confidence vote|url=http://al-shorfa.com/en_GB/articles/meii/features/2013/04/25/feature-01|accessdate=11 September 2014|work=Al Shorfa|date=25 April 2013}} The agency which is run from a cafe in Amman describes itself as voice to the "silent majority".{{cite news|title=About us|url=http://en.ammonnews.net/formviewer.aspx?form=Aboutus&SectionName=About%20Us|accessdate=21 September 2013|work=Ammon News}} It provides news which is not published in print media through its both Arabic and English news portals. Based on the 2010 [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] data ''Ammon News'' had a readership of 38%, making it the most visited website in Jordan. As of 2011 it was the most popular website in the country with 250,000 daily visitors according to Alexa. It was the fifth most visited website in the [[Arab world]] in 2012.{{cite news|title=Top websites in the Arab world 2012|url=http://english.forbesmiddleeast.com/details.php?row=2603&list=44465|accessdate=23 February 2014|work=Forbes Middle East}} In a market study carried out by [[Ipsos]] in March 2012 it was established that ''Ammon News'' was among the top 20 most visited websites in the country along with two other news portals, namely ''[[Saraya (newspaper)|Saraya]]'' and ''[[Khaberni]]''.{{cite web|title=Freedom on the Net|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2012/jordan|work=Freedom House|accessdate=21 September 2013|year=2012}} ==Attacks and blocks== In February 2011, the website of ''Ammon News'' was disabled following the publication of a statement by 36 leading Jordanian tribesmen who called for democratic and economic reforms in Jordan.{{cite web|title=News website hacked after publishing sensitive statement|url=http://www.ifex.org/jordan/2011/02/11/ammon_news_hacked/|work=IFEX|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=11 February 2011}} In addition, unknown people also attacked the owners of the news portal on the same date. [[Randa Habib]], a veteran journalist, published articles in a column in English and Arabic portals of the ''Ammon News'' until June 2011 when [[Government of Jordan|the Jordanian government]] implemented pressure related to the statement mentioned above.{{cite web|title=In Jordan, Some Threats Against a Foreign Journalist Are Realized|url=http://www.nieman.harvard.edu/reports/article/102678/In-Jordan-Some-Threats-Against-a-Foreign-Journalist-Are-Realized.aspx|work=Nieman Reports|accessdate=21 September 2013|author=Randa Habib|date=Fall 2011}} Regarding the hacking Bassel Elkour argued that it had been perpetrated by [[Jordan Intelligence services|Jordan Intelligence]]. The Jordanian authorities denied his claim.{{cite news|title=Jordan denies security services hacked website|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/tech/computer/220554/jordan-denies-security-services-hacked-website|accessdate=11 September 2014|work=Bangkok Post|agency=AFP|date=9 February 2011}} The website was blocked, temporarily, by [[Government of Jordan|the Jordanian government]] in June 2013 when it refused to comply the new press law in order to protest it.{{cite web|title=Jordanian Government Commences Blocking Websites|url=http://techpresident.com/news/23959/trying-out-new-internet-censorship-law-weekend-jordan-government-blocked-300-websites|work=Tech President|accessdate=4 June 2013|author=Jessica Mckenzie}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://www.ammonnews.net/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ammon News}} [[Category:2006 establishments in Jordan]] [[Category:Arabic-language websites]] [[Category:Digital newspapers published in Asia]] [[Category:Digital newspapers published in the Middle East]] [[Category:English-language websites]] [[Category:Jordanian news websites]] [[Category:Media in Amman]] [[Category:Publications established in 2006]]

''''' ARA News''''' ({{lang-ar|آرانيوز}}) was an online news service focussed on the consequences of war in [[Syria]] and [[Iraq]].<ref name="TilburgInterview"/> Although described as a [[Kurds|Kurdish]] news agency by its director, the site started as an Arabic-only news service and {{as of|2016|01|lc=yes}}, still published only in the Arabic and English languages,<ref name="BadranDeAngelis">{{cite journal|last1=Badran|first1=Yazan|last2=De Angelis|first2=Enrico|title='Independent' Kurdish Media in Syria|journal=Middle East Journal of Culture and Communication|date=1 January 2016|volume=9|issue=3|pages=334–351|doi=10.1163/18739865-00903001|url=https://cris.cumulus.vub.ac.be/portal/files/26813267/Kurdish_media_authors_version.pdf}}</ref><ref name="archiveJune2013">{{cite web|title=آرا : ARA News |url=http://www.aranews.org/ar/ |work=Internet Archive |accessdate=22 June 2013 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622001829/http://www.aranews.org/ar/ |archivedate=22 June 2013 }}</ref> and ceased publishing around August 2017.<ref name="ARANews_20170817" />

''ARA News'' was referenced hundreds of times by other news vendors, and thousands of times in social media.<ref>{{cite web|title=ARA news - Google Search |url=https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=%22ARA+news%22+-site:aranews.org+-site:aranews.net&tbm=nws|website=Google|accessdate=5 January 2017|quote=About 6,630 results}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=facebook.com aranews - Google Search|url=https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=site%3Afacebook.com+%22ARA+news%22|website=[[Google]]|accessdate=5 January 2017|quote=About 55,600 results}}</ref> ''ARA News'' was supported by [[:nl:Free Press Unlimited|Free Press Unlimited]], a media development organisation based in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.<ref name="freepressunlim_about" />

==Ownership, identity and reliability==
''ARA News'' is a member of the Ethical Charter for Syrian Media.<ref name="Almethaq"/>

The ownership of the ''ARA News'' is unpublished. The founder and chief editor is Adib Abdulmajid,<ref name="Clarion"/> a Syrian Kurd who fled Syria after taking part in pro-democracy activities, and sought asylum in the [[Netherlands]].<ref name="TilburgInterview"/> Reporters and editors of ''ARA News'' are named. Most of the staff are Kurdish, some are Arabs.<ref name="BadranDeAngelis"/>

''ARA News'' was supported by [[:nl:Free Press Unlimited|Free Press Limited]], whose mission statement is that "People deserve to know." Free Press Unlimited claims to work to ensure that impartial news and information are and remain available to people across the globe, particularly in countries where there is little to no press freedom. Free Press Unlimited has media projects in approximately 40 countries around the world.<ref name="freepressunlim_about">{{cite web|title=Our mission|url=https://www.freepressunlimited.org/en/about-us/our-mission|website=|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6xG5Ah3aG?url=https://www.freepressunlimited.org/en/about-us/our-mission|archivedate=2018-02-15|accessdate=5 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>

==Name==
''ARA'' is an abbreviation of the [[Kurdish languages|Kurdish]] ''Ajansa Rojnamevaniya Azad'', meaning "Independent Press Agency".<ref name="ARA-about">{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://aranews.net/about-us/|website=ARA News|accessdate=5 January 2017}}</ref> The Arabic name ({{lang-ar|آرانيوز}}) is a simple transliteration of ''ARA News''.

==History==
''ARA News'' was founded by Adib Abdulmajid in 2013, the website's domain name having been registered in April 2013,<ref>{{cite web|title=Domain aranews.org whois lookup|url=http://whois.uanic.name/eng/domainname/aranews.org.html|website=Uanic.name|accessdate=5 January 2017}}</ref> and the first news reports were published in June 2013.<ref name="archiveJune2013"/> Abdulmajid, a graduate of [[University of Damascus|Damascus]] and [[Tilburg University|Tilburg]] universities, believed that in Syria and its region "freedom of expression has been suppressed for decades", and he created ''ARA News'' as "a step forward towards free media" in the region.<ref name="Clarion">{{cite web|last1=Svirsky|first1=Meira|title=Adib Abdulmajid: Building Free Media in War Torn Iraq & Syria|url=https://clarionproject.org/adib-abdulmajid-building-free-media-war-torn-iraq-syria/|website=[[Clarion Project]]|date=11 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="TilburgInterview">{{cite web|title=Interview Adib Abdulmajid|url=https://www.tilburguniversity.edu/education/masters-programmes/management-of-cultural-diversity/interviews/adib/|website=Tilburg University|language=en}}</ref>

With the aim of developing professional journalism in Syria, in 2014 Free Press Unlimited gave training to editors, news managers and reporters from ''ARA News''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Developing Professional Journalism in Syria|url=https://reports.freepressunlimited.org/2014/projects/developing-professional-journalism-in-syria|website=Free Press Unlimited|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref>

In 2015 ''ARA News'' became one of the first 20 signatories of the Ethical Charter for Syrian Media, "an alliance of significant independent Syrian media organisations committed to the highest standards of journalism and unimpeded freedom of speech" established under [[Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency]] sponsorship.<ref name="Almethaq">{{cite web|title=Almethaq Syria Ethical Charter for Syrian Media Alliance|url=http://almethaq-sy.org/en/#!/ara-news|website=almethaq-sy.org|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ethical Journalism for Syria Alliance|url=https://reports.freepressunlimited.org/2016/projects/ethical-journalism-syria-alliance|website=Free Press Unlimited|accessdate=23 June 2017|date=2015}}</ref>

The last online publication of ''ARA News'' was issued online in late August 2017.<ref name="ARANews_20170817" />

pages.text:
{{Distinguish|Alarab News Channel|Al-Arab}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Al Arab
العرب | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Daily | format = [[e-newspaper]] | owners = | founder = | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = Ahmed Al Romaihi | assoceditor = Mohammed Haji | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{start date and age|1972|3|6|df=yes}} | political = | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Doha]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.alarab.qa/ ''Al Arab''] }} '''''Al Arab''''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] العرب meaning ''The Arabs'') was the first [[Arabic language|Arabic]] daily following the independence of Qatar. It was printed between 1972 and 1995 and was relaunched on 18 November 2007 as an e-newspaper which is based in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]].{{cite web|title=Al Arab Newspaper|url=http://wikimapia.org/9445501/%D8%AC%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8-Al-Arab-Newspaper|work=Wikimapia|accessdate=19 September 2013}}{{cite web|title=Qatari newspapers|url=http://www.worldpress.org/newspapers/MIDEAST/Qatar.cfm|work=World Press|accessdate=19 September 2013}} ==History and profile== ''Al Arab'' was established in 1972.{{cite book|title=The Middle East and North Africa 2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pP315Mw3S9EC&pg=PA954|accessdate=24 December 2016|date=30 October 2003|publisher=Taylor & Francis Group; Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-184-1|page=954}} The paper was first published on 6 March 1972 as a weekly tabloid and became Qatar's first post-independence Arabic publication.{{cite book|title=Mass Media in the Middle East: A Comprehensive Handbook|year=1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, CT|url=https://www.questia.com/read/23321662/mass-media-in-the-middle-east-a-comprehensive-handbook|author=Mohamed M. Arafa|editor=Yahya R. Kamalipour; Hamid Mowlana|accessdate=19 September 2013|chapter=Qatar}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}}{{cite book|author=William A. Rugh|title=Arab Mass Media: Newspapers, Radio, and Television in Arab Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UGfbluSa4N8C&pg=PA60|accessdate=11 September 2014|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-98212-6|page=60}} The paper is also the first political paper of the country.{{cite web|title=Qatar Press, Media, TV, Radio, Newspapers|url=http://www.pressreference.com/No-Sa/Qatar.html|publisher=Press Reference|accessdate=11 September 2014}} The founder and the first [[editor-in-chief]] of the daily was Qatari intellectual Abdullah Hussein Nemma,{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.aecqatar.com/aec/html/about.htm|publisher=Arabian Establishment for Commerce|accessdate=11 September 2014}} known as "Dean" of the Qatari press. The publisher was Dar Al Orouba. ''Al Arab'' was converted into a broadsheet daily on 22 February 1974. It was closed down in 1995.{{cite web|title=Al Jazeera Website Director to Quit; Start New Newspaper|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=06DOHA328|work=Wikileaks|accessdate=19 September 2013|location=Doha|date=2 March 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054615/http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=06DOHA328|archive-date=21 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The license of the paper was sold by Nemma's family to then Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani|Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani]] in the 1990s. It was relaunched on 18 November 2007 as [[online newspaper]].{{cite web|title=Biography of Abdulaziz Ibrahim Al Mahmoud|url=http://www.whartondubai09.com/bio-mahd.html|work=Wharton University|accessdate=19 September 2013}} [[Abdulaziz Al-Mahmoud]] who also contributed to the foundation of the daily was named as editor-in-chief and served in the post until November 2009.{{cite news|title=Abdulaziz Al Mahmoud|url=http://www.forbes-associates.com/team/abdulaziz-al-mahmoud.html|work=Forbes Associates|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616044958/http://www.forbes-associates.com/team/abdulaziz-al-mahmoud.html|archive-date=16 June 2012 }} Ahmed Al Romaihi is the editor-in-chief of the paper{{cite news|title=QMA threatens legal action over controversial newspaper column|url=http://dohanews.co/post/59571945317/qma-threatens-legal-action-over-controversial-newspaper|accessdate=19 September 2013|work=Doha News|date=August 2013}}{{cite news|title=UAE journalists in Qatar pressured to quit|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/03/saudi-uae-journalists-qatar-urged-quit-20143915551210408.html|accessdate=11 September 2014|work=Al Jazeera|date=9 March 2014}} and his deputy is Mohammed Haji.{{cite web|title=Al Arab Newspaper named as media sponsor for SOP|url=http://www.olympic.qa/en/NewsCenter/Pages/Al-Arab-Newspaper-named-as-media-sponsor-for-SOP.aspx|work=Qatar Olympic Committee|accessdate=19 September 2013|date=12 March 2013}} ==Political stance and content== ''Al Arab'' both in its first and second periods has had an independent political stance.{{cite web|title=Qatari newspapers|url=http://www.araboo.com/dir/qatari-newspapers|work=Araboo|accessdate=19 September 2013}} However, ''[[BBC]]'' describes it as a pro-government paper.{{cite news|title=Qatar profile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14702519|accessdate=19 September 2013|work=BBC|date=26 July 2013}} In 2009, ''Al Arab'' contributor Samar Al Mogren, a [[Saudi Arabian people|Saudi Arabian]] novelist and [[feminist]], received death threats due to her article in which she criticized Saudi cleric Mohammed Al Arifi for vilifying [[Shiites]] and calling [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] [[Ayatollah Sistani]] "an Infidel”.{{cite web|title=Al Arab newspaper condemns death threats|url=http://www.qatarliving.com/qatar-living-lounge/posts/al-arab-newspaper-condemns-death-threats|publisher=Qatar Living|accessdate=11 September 2014|year=2009}} In August 2013, Faisal Al Marzoqi published an article in the daily, accusing the officials of [[Qatar Museums Authority|the Qatar Museums Authority]] of power misuse. The criticism also indirectly targeted [[Al Mayassa Al Thani|Shaikha Al Mayassa Al Thani]], chairperson of the authority and caused reaction by the Qatari officials. ==Activities== The daily was one of the media sponsors for the Schools Olympic Program (SOP) in March 2013. ==See also== * [[List of newspapers in Qatar]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://www.alarab.qa/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Arab Al}} [[Category:1972 establishments in Qatar]] [[Category:Publications established in 1972]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Qatar]] [[Category:Media in Doha]] [[Category:Digital newspapers published in the Middle East]] [[Category:Qatari news websites]] [[Category:Arabic-language websites]] [[Category:Arabic-language newspapers]] [[Category:Defunct weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Online newspapers with defunct print editions]] [[Category:Digital newspapers published in Asia]]

The '''Arabic Wikipedia''' ({{lang-ar|{{#property:P1448}}}}) is the [[Arabic language]] version of [[Wikipedia]]. It started on 9 July 2003. As of {{Currentmonth}} {{Currentyear}}, it has {{NUMBEROF|ARTICLES|ar|N}} articles, {{NUMBEROF|USERS|ar|N}} registered users and {{NUMBEROF|FILES|ar|N}} files and it is the [[List of Wikipedias|17th largest]] edition of Wikipedia by article count, and ranks [[m:Wikipedia article depth|12th in terms of depth]] among Wikipedias that are above 50,000 articles. It was the first [[Semitic languages|Semitic language]] to exceed 100,000 articles.<ref>[[metawiki:List of Wikipedias#100_000+_articles|List of Wikipedias by number of articles]]</ref>

The design of the Arabic Wikipedia differs somewhat from other Wikipedias. Most notably, since Arabic is written [[Bi-directional text|right-to-left]], the location of links is a [[mirror image]] of those Wikipedias in languages written left-to-right. Prior to Wikipedia's update to [[MediaWiki]] [[mw:Release notes/1.16|1.16]], Arabic Wikipedia had a default page background of the site inspired by [[Islamic architecture|Arabic/Islamic tiling or ornament styles]]. Switching from MediaWiki's new default Vector layout to the original MonoBook layout may restore this page background. 
[[File:Edit-this-page-large-ar.png|thumb|"Edit" button on Arabic Wikipedia screenshot, old background in 2008]]

== History ==

[[File:Arab Wikipedians meeting.jpg|Arab Wikipedians meeting during Wikimania conference in Hong Kong|thumb]]

At the emergence of the Wikipedia project in 2001, there were calls to create an Arabic domain raised by Arab engineers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arsco.org/detailed/2fbe2ad4-57f3-42b7-8e72-005b95494f91|title=المستشار / طارق قابيل|publisher=|access-date=4 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205091127/http://arsco.org/detailed/2fbe2ad4-57f3-42b7-8e72-005b95494f91|archive-date=5 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The domain was created as "ar.wikipedia.org" but no serious activity took place except with anonymous users who experimented with the idea.<ref>[https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/What_to_do_with_www.wikipedia.org Archived discussions about International languages. Refer to section "Provisional is Best, Sort by Population".] Note the comment "Outside jokes, the french an german wikipedias is more developed than the one of hindi or Arab.". Last accessed 4 August 2014</ref> Until 7 February 2003, all contributors to the Arabic Wikipedia were non-Arab volunteers from the International Project Wikipedia<ref name="Bauer">{{cite web|url=http://lists.arabeyes.org/archives/general/2004/February/msg00023.html|title=arabic wikipedia|publisher=}}</ref> that handled the technical aspects. Elizabeth Bauer, who used the user name [[:ar:نقاش المستخدم:Elian|Elian]] in the Arabic Wikipedia, approached many potential Arabs who might be interested in volunteering to spearhead the Arabic project. The only group who responded was the [[Arabeyes|ArabEyes]] team who were involved in Arabizing the Open Source initiatives. Elian's request was conservatively received and the ArabEyes team was ready to participate but not take a leadership role<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lists.arabeyes.org/archives/general/2004/February/msg00029.html|title=We have a problem!|publisher=}}</ref> and then declined to participate on the second of February 2003. During this negotiation time, volunteer users from the German Wikipedia project continued to develop the technical infrastructure of the Arabic Wikipedia backbone.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ar.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=%D9%88%D9%8A%D9%83%D9%8A%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%A7:%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%86&oldid=94|title=ويكيبيديا:الميدان|date=1 August 2003|publisher=|via=Wikipedia}}</ref><ref>[[:ar:نقاش المستخدم:Stevertigo|The discussion page of Svertigo that shows the non-Arab volunteers working on the Arabic Wikipedia in late 2003]]</ref>

In 2003 Rami Tarawneh ({{lang-ar|رامي عوض الطراونة}}), a Jordanian PhD student in Germany who originated from [[Zarqa]], encountered the [[English Wikipedia]] and began to edit content. Contributors encouraged him to start an Arabic Wikipedia.<ref name=Flashpoint>{{cite journal|journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2014/02/arabic-wikipedia/ |title=In the Middle East, Arabic Wikipedia is a flashpoint — and a beacon |last=Su |first=Alice |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=14 February 2014 |accessdate=14 February 2014 }} ([https://www.webcitation.org/6QsskEiqt?url=http://www.wired.com/2014/02/arabic-wikipedia/ Archive])</ref> The Arabic Wikipedia opened in July 2003.<ref name=Panovicp94>Panović, Ivan ([[University of Oxford]] Faculty of Oriental Studies). "[https://www.academia.edu/363979/The_Beginnings_of_Wikipedia_Masry The Beginnings of Wikipedia Masry]." ''[[al-Logha]] Series of Papers in Linguistics'', 2010. 8: 93-127. (sourced content from p. 94)</ref> By that year a significant group of contributors included Tarawneh and four other Jordanians studying in Germany.<ref name=Flashpoint/>

On 7 February 2004,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tools.wmflabs.org/xtools/pcount/index.php?name=%D8%B9%D8%B5%D8%A7%D9%85%20%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%8A%D8%B2%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A&lang=ar&wiki=wikipedia|title=X!'s tools|publisher=}}</ref> one member from the ArabEyes, Isam Bayazidi ({{lang-ar|عصام بايزيدي}}), volunteered with 4 other friends to be involved with the Arabic Wikipedia and assumed some leadership roles. In 2004, Bayazid was assigned the [[SysOp]] responsibilities and he, with another 5 volunteers, namely Ayman, Abo Suleiman, Mustapha Ahmad and Bassem Jarkas<ref>These were [[:ar:مستخدم:أيمن|Ayman]], [[:ar:مستخدم:أبو سليمان|Abo Suleima]], [[:ar:مستخدم:مصطفى|Mustapha]] [[:ar:مستخدم:أحمد|Ahmad]] and [[:ar:مستخدم:Bassem JARKAS|Bassem Jarkas]]</ref> are considered to be the first Arabs to lead the Wikipedia project and they are attributed for working on translating and enforcing the English policies to Arabic. The Arabic Wikipedia faced many challenges at its inception. In February 2004, it was considered to be the worst Wikipedia project among all other languages. However, in 2005, it showed phenomenal progress  by which in December 2005, the total number of articles reached 8,285.<ref>[[:ar:ويكيبيديا:إحصاءات ويكيبيديا العربية|Wikipedia Statistics - Arabic Wikipedia. Accessed on 4 August 2014]]</ref> By that time, there were fewer than 20 contributors and the administrators and contributors made efforts to recruit new users.<ref name="Flashpoint"/>

In 2007 the secret police in an unspecified country detained Tarawneh and demanded that he reveal the [[IP address]] of a contributor. To protect the Wikipedian, the administrators forged a dispute that was the presumed reason for Tarawneh losing his administrator access, so the secret police was unable to obtain the IP. In response to the incident, the rules now state that no one user may have access to all information about the Wikipedia's users.<ref name=Flashpoint/>

[[File:2nd Celebration Conference, Egypt-February 2013-122.JPG|thumb|left|Second Conference of the Wikipedia Education Program in [[Cairo University]], Egypt, February 27, 2013]]
In 2008 the Wikipedia had had fewer than 65,000 articles and was ranked #29 out of the Wikipedias, behind the [[Esperanto Wikipedia]] and the [[Slovenian Wikipedia]]. Noam Cohen of ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that, to many of the attendees of the 2008 [[Wikimania]] conference in [[Alexandria]], [[Egypt]], the "woeful shape of the Arabic Wikipedia has been the cause of chagrin."<ref name=CohenNoam>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/21/technology/21iht-link21.1.14629408.html |publisher=''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' |first=Noam |last=Cohen |date=21 July 2008 |title=In Egypt, Wikipedia is more than hobby |accessdate=14 December 2008 }} ([https://web.archive.org/web/20081007162322/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/07/21/business/link21.php Archive])<!--Old URL: https://web.archive.org/web/20080803063734/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/07/21/business/link21.php--></ref> Cohen stated that out of Egyptians, fewer than 10% "are thought to have internet access" and of those with internet access many tend to be [[English as a second language|knowledgeable in English]] and have a preference of communicating in that language.<ref name=CohenNoam/> The Arabic Wikipedia had 118,870 articles as of 15 January 2010.

As of July 2012 there are around 630 active Arabic Wikipedia editors around the world. Ikram Al-Yacoub of ''[[Al Arabiya]]'' says that this is "a relatively low figure."<ref name="AlYacoub">Al-Yacoub, Ikram. "[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/07/19/227328.html ‘Taghreedat’ to offer Arab Tweeps their own search engine]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/6GYO0FLkI?url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/07/19/227328.html Archive]) ''[[Al Arabiya]]''. Thursday 19 July 2012. Retrieved on 24 August 2012.</ref> At the time there were hundreds of thousands of Wikipedia articles on the Arabic Wikipedia.<ref name=Flashpoint/> The [[Wikimedia Foundation]] and the nonprofit group Taghreedat established the "Arabic Wikipedia Editors Program" intended to train users to edit the Arabic Wikipedia.<ref name="AlYacoub"/> By the end of June 2014, the number of articles had reached 384,000<ref>[http://stats.wikimedia.org/EN/TablesWikipediaAR.htm Wikipedia Statistics Arabic. Retrieved on 4 August 2014]</ref>
{{-}}

== Blocking ==

The Arabic Wikipedia has been [[Block (Internet)|blocked]] in [[Syria]] with no official reasons given by the [[Syrian government]].<ref>{{ar icon}} [http://www.menassat.com/?q=ar/alerts/3726- ويكيبيديا يختفي عن صفحات الانترنت السوري]</ref> The block began on 30 April 2008 while all other language versions of Wikipedia remain unblocked and freely accessible. And it is still blocked in the country so far.{{when|date=November 2013}} [[Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia.org]]{{when|date=June 2014}} continues to be blocked, which causes all images on Wikipedia (in all languages) to be unavailable.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Tarawneh stated that ''[[wasta]]'' was used to unblock Wikipedia in Syria.<ref name=Flashpoint/>

== Evaluation and criticism ==
[[File:WP breakdown Arabic.png|thumb|Map showing which countries the page views for Arabic Wikipedia come from]]
[[File:WP countries and versions in Northern Africa and the Middle East.png|thumb|Page views to different Wikipedia language versions in Northern Africa and the Middle East, September 2009 to July 2010<ref>Wikimedia Traffic Analysis Report - Wikipedia Page Views Per Country, [http://stats.wikimedia.org/archive/squid_reports/ September 2009 to July 2010], map by Ziko van Dijk and numbers by Erik Zachte ([http://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportPageViewsPerCountryBreakdown.htm recent stats])</ref>]]

In June 2016, Arabic Wikipedia scored 233 in terms of depth (a very rough indicator of the encyclopedia's quality). This is better than the German version (102), the French version (207) or the Japanese version (74), making it the fifth highest +100,000 articles Wikipedia in the terms of depth, after [[English Wikipedia]] (930), [[Serbo-Croatian Wikipedia]] (561), [[Thai Wikipedia]] (253) and [[Hebrew Wikipedia]] (251).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/List_of_Wikipedias|title=List of Wikipedias - Meta|publisher=}}</ref>

At [[Wikimania]] 2008, [[Jimmy Wales]] argued that high-profile arrests like those of Egyptian blogger [[Kareem Amer]] could be hampering the development of the Arabic Wikipedia by making editors afraid to contribute.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/17/wikipedia-goes-to-alexandria-home-of-other-great-reference-works/ |title=Wikipedia Goes to Alexandria, Home of Other Great Reference Works |author=Noam Cohen |date=17 July 2008 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref>

In 2010, Tarek Al Kaziri, from [[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]], believed that the Arabic Wikipedia reflected the Arabic reality in general. Low participation lowers the probability that the articles are reviewed, developed and updated, and political polarisation of participants is likely to lead to biases in the articles.<ref>{{cite web
|script-title=ar:ويكيبيديا والعرب: خلل في المشروع أم في الثقافة؟
|url   = http://www.rnw.nl/arabic/article/%D9%88%D9%8A%D9%83%D9%8A%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%A7-%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8-%D8%AE%D9%84%D9%84-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B4%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B9-%D8%A3%D9%85-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%A9%D8%9F|language=ar}}</ref>

According to [[Alexa Internet]], on 26 November 2014, the Arabic Wikipedia is the 10th most visited language version of Wikipedia in terms of percentage of visitors on all of the Wikipedias over a month, with the "ar.wikipedia.org" [[subdomain]] attracting approximately 1.8% of the total visitors of the "wikipedia.org" website,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/wikipedia.org|title=Wikipedia.org Traffic, Demographics and Competitors - Alexa|publisher=}}</ref> despite being ranked no. 22 in term of the article count. In terms of page views, it is ranked 12th with the same 10 Wikipedias above it plus the Polish and Dutch ones.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportPageViewsPerLanguageBreakdown.htm|title=Wikimedia Traffic Analysis Report - Page Views Per Wikipedia Language - Breakdown|publisher=}}</ref>

== Usage and page views by country ==

[[Florence Devouard]], the former president of the [[Wikimedia Foundation]], stated in 2010 that the largest number of articles on the Arabic Wikipedia were written by Egyptians and that the Egyptians were more likely to participate in the Arabic Wikipedia compared to other groups.<ref name="Heb">{{cite news|last=Samir |first=Amira |title=Le masri est-il contre l’arabe ? |language=French |trans-title=Is Masri contrary to Arabic? |publisher=''[[Al-Ahram Hebdo]]'' |date=December 2009 |url=http://hebdo.ahram.org.eg/arab/ahram/2009/12/23/doss2.htm |accessdate=13 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6MNY7bJVJ?url=http://hebdo.ahram.org.eg/arab/ahram/2009/12/23/doss2.htm |archivedate=4 January 2014 |df=dmy }} () "« Les Egyptiens sont effectivement les plus nombreux à participer dans la Wikipedia arabe, c’est-à-dire que les statistiques montrent que le plus grand nombre d’articles dans la Wikipedia arabe sont envoyés par des Egyptiens.[...]"</ref>

== Milestones ==

* Arabic Wikipedia was launched in September 2001, yet due to [[MediaWiki]] software migration, the oldest surviving edit dates back to 9 July 2003.
* Article number 10,000 was [[:ar:نكاف|نكاف]] ([[Mumps]]) created on 25 December 2005.
* Article number 50,000 was [[:ar:جامعة تكساس مدرسة الطب في هيوستن|جامعة تكساس مدرسة الطب في هيوستن]] ([[University of Texas Medical Branch]]) created on 31 December 2007.
* Article number 75,000 was [[:ar:قائمة الصحاري حسب المساحة|قائمة الصحاري حسب المساحة]] ([[List of deserts by area]]) created on 30 August 2008.
* Article number 100,000 was [[:ar:المعهد العالي للفنون والحرف بقابس|المعهد العالي للفنون والحرف بقابس]] ([[University of Gabès]]) created on 25 May 2009.
* Article number 200,000 was [[:ar:الجوازع (إب)|الجوازع (إب)]] (A village in [[Yemen]]) created on 21 October 2012.
* Article number 250,000 was [[:ar:جانيت جاينور|جانيت جاينور]] ([[Janet Gaynor]]) created on 6 December 2013.
* Article number 400,000 was [[:ar:فيض الله قيقلك|فيض الله قيقلك]] (A Turkish politician) created on 17 December 2015.
* Article number 500,000 was [[:ar:أولاد بن كانة (تينزي 1)|أولاد بن كانة (تينزي 1)]] (A village in [[Morocco]]) created on 6 March 2017.
* Article number 600,000 was [[:ar:دارين براتلي|دارين براتلي]] ([[Darren Pratley]]) created on 12 September 2018.

'''Dandin''' (Arabic: دندن ) is a music platform and sound-hosting website for the Middle East. Established in Egypt in October 2013, Dandin is a platform that focusses on highlighting emerging talent from the region.

== History ==

Dandin.me was launched on October 10, 2013 as an independent audio platform based in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalvoices.org/2013/10/19/dandin-me-encompassing-the-emerging-talent-in-the-middle-east/|title=Dandin.me: Encompassing the Emerging Talent in the Middle East · Global Voices|date=19 October 2013|publisher=}}</ref> It invites users to upload recordings in different sections, such as music, comedy, podcasts, politics and poetry.<ref>http://www.madamasr.com/content/breakfast-mada-abdel-rahman-hussein-sound-hosting-site-dandin</ref>

== Origin of Name ==

Dandin is an Egyptian-Arabic slang term for humming<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cairoscene.com/ViewArticle.aspx?AId=2602 |title=DANDIN: UNITING OUR SOUNDS|website=www.cairoscene.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903123253/http://cairoscene.com/ViewArticle.aspx?AId=2602 |archivedate=2014-09-03 |df= }}</ref> and being a Middle Eastern platform it hosts output from artists originating only from that region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barakabits.com/2014/03/sign-hum|title=Calling All Talents: Your Audience is Just One Click Away - BarakaBits|date=12 March 2014|publisher=}}</ref>

== Sound types and genres ==

The platform hosts a variety of sounds derived from what is labelled the independent or alternative scene in the Middle East. Besides music it  also hosts poetry, comedy sketches, political rants and storytelling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/33/103193/Arts--Culture/Music/Dandin-Rendering-alternative-sounds-from-the-Arab-.aspx|title=Dandin: Rendering alternative sounds from the Arab region accessible - Music - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg}}</ref>

== Dandin Artists ==
