'''Inform Napalm''' is a volunteer initiative to inform Ukrainian citizens and the foreign public about the [[Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)|undeclared war against Ukraine]], the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation of Crimea]], and the activities of the Russian special services as well as the militants of the so-called "[[Donetsk People's Republic|DPR]]", "[[Luhansk People's Republic|LPR]]", and "[[Novorossiya (confederation)|Novorossiya]]". The team members are engaged in a wide range of other volunteer activities.  In order to inform the foreign audience, authors translate materials to dozens of languages, including [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[Chinese language|Chinese]].

The Informnapalm.org website was created in early 2014 after the [[Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)|Russian military intervention in Ukraine]] and annexation of Crimea. During the existence of the project, volunteers conducted two profound investigations of the [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17|Boeing-777 crash]] and gathered evidence of the presence of Russian troops in Ukrainian territory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.day.kiev.ua/uk/article/media/vvichlyva-zbroya|title=Ввічлива зброя|author=Марія Прокопенко|date=September 11, 2015|publisher=[[День (газета)|День]]}}</ref>

[[File:Top-10 military gadgets involved in the russian aggression against Ukraine.jpg|thumb|413x413px|TOP-10 Military Gadgets Involved in the Russian Aggression Against Ukraine. InformNapalm Infographics]]
The main activities of the project are collecting and analysing [[Open-source intelligence|OSINT]]-information, found in open sources, including social networks.   InformNapalm's investigation of 53rd Artillery Brigade commander colonel Sergei Muchkayev, suspected of killing the [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17|MH17]] passengers, was used in the report of the [[Eliot Higgins|Bellingcat research team]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=MH17 - Potential Suspects and Witnesses from the 53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/53rd-report-public.pdf}}</ref>

After the [[Russian military intervention in the Syrian Civil War|Russian intervention in Syria]], InformNapalm began publishing personal data of Russian pilots who bombarded Syrian cities, and together with the media project "[[Visuals (project)|Visuals]]" created infographics containing personal data of crew members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://informnapalm.org/ua/syriya-infografika-ofitsery-vks-rf-vijskovi-zlochyntsi-kremlya/|title=Сирія. Інфографіка: офіцери ВКС РФ – військові злочинці Кремля|publisher=Inform Napalm|date=October 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bild.de/politik/ausland/syrien-krise/syrien-russen-pranger-43264586.bild.html|title=Aktivisten stellen Putins Piloten an den Pranger|publisher=[[Bild]]|date=November 6, 2015}}</ref> These publications have caused negative reactions in Russia, in particular, the Russian President's press secretary, [[Dmitry Peskov]], has said that in response to the actions of the project "Russian special services will take all necessary measures".<ref name="bild20151106">{{cite web |title=Aktivisten stellen Putins Piloten an den Pranger |trans-title=Activists put Putin pilots to pillory|author=Julian Röpcke |date=November 6, 2015 |language=german |url=http://www.bild.de/politik/ausland/syrien-krise/syrien-russen-pranger-43264586.bild.html |publisher=[[Bild]] |accessdate=November 8, 2015}}</ref> In response, the authors of the site said that "every violation the ceasefire in the Donbass by the joint Russian-separatist forces will cause the publication of another OSINT-investigation with names, photos, tactical and registration numbers and other details and facts related to Russian pilots crimes during a military operation in Syria".<ref name="пєсков">[https://ua.informnapalm.org/informnapalm-vidpoviv-pyeskovu-nashi-publikatsiyi-shokova-terapiya/ InformNapalm відповів Пєскову: «Наші публікації — шокова терапія»]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Кремль відкрив ящик Пандори. "Партизани" з InformNapalm розповіли, чим шантажують російських генералів і як зупинити Путіна|author=Олександра Горчинська|date=October 21, 2015|url=http://nv.ua/ukr/publications/kreml-vidkriv-jashchik-pandori-partizani-z-informnapalm-rozpovili-chim-shantazhujut-rosijskih-generaliv-i-jak-zupiniti-putina-75240.html|publisher=[[Новое Время (журнал і сайт)|Новое Время]]|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> TV channel [[Al Arabiya]] compared this InformNapalm project activity with [[WikiLeaks|WikiLeaks publications]].<ref>[http://www.alarabiya.net/ar/arab-and-world/syria/2015/10/13/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%83%D8%B4%D9%81-%D8%B9%D9%86-%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%B1-%D9%88%D8%A3%D8%B3%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%A1-%D9%88%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B7%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%8A%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B3-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%B3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7.html تسريب صور وأسماء وبيانات الطيارين الروس في سوريا موقع روسي يشبه «ويكيليكس» نشر أيضا عناوينهم وأرقام هواتفهم وتعهد بتسريب المزيد](In Arabic)</ref>

== Surkov leaks ==
{{main|Surkov leaks}}
On 23 October 2016, Ukrainian hacker group CyberHunta published correspondence that it alleged was from the office email account of [[Vladislav Surkov]], a political adviser to [[Vladimir Putin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=КИБЕРХУНТА ПЕРЕДАЕТ ПРИВЕТ СУРКОВУ|url=http://cyberhunta.com/news/kiberhunta-peredaet-privet-surkovu/|publisher=Cyberhunta.com|language=Russian|date=23 October 2016}}</ref> Volunteers from Inform Napalm requested additional evidence from an alliance of hacker groups that includes CyberHunta, RUH8, FalconsFlame, and TRINITY. They secured the release of a 1GB Microsoft Outlook data file. Inform Napalm reported that the hackers also were in possession of documents from 2015 and 2016 that were being analysed by intelligence agencies and were not released due to their operational value.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bjorn|first1=Falcon|title=SurkovLeaks: 1GB mail cache retrieved by Ukrainian hacktivists (English)|url=https://informnapalm.org/en/surkovleaks/|publisher=Inform Napalm|language=English|date=25 October 2016}}</ref>

The document leak included 2,337 emails from Surkov's inbox.<ref name="DFRL">{{cite web|author1=Digital Forensic Research Lab|title=Breaking Down the Surkov Leaks – DFRLab|url=https://medium.com/dfrlab/breaking-down-the-surkov-leaks-b2feec1423cb#.t4wz7vsnx|website=Medium|publisher=Atlantic Council|date=25 October 2016}}</ref>  The emails illustrate Russian plans to politically destabilize Ukraine and the coordination of affairs with major opposition leaders in separatist east Ukraine.<ref name="IBTUK">{{cite news|last1=Murdock|first1=Jason|title=Surkov leaks: Thousands of hacked emails reportedly from high-ranking Kremlin official published|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/surkov-leaks-thousands-hacked-emails-high-ranking-kremlin-officials-published-1588645|work=International Business Times UK|date=27 October 2016}}</ref> The release included a document sent to Surkov by [[Denis Pushilin]], former Chair of the [[People's Soviet of the Donetsk People's Republic|People's Soviet]] of the [[Donetsk People's Republic]], listing casualties that occurred during 2014.<ref name="DFRL"/> It also included a 22-page outline of "a plan to support nationalist and separatist politicians and to encourage early parliamentary elections in Ukraine, all with the aim of undermining the government in Kiev."<ref name="FP">{{cite news|last1=Standish|first1=Reid|title=Hacked: Putin Aide’s Emails Detail Alleged Plot to Destabilize Ukraine|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/10/25/hacked-putin-aides-emails-detail-alleged-plot-to-destabilize-kiev-surkov-ukraine-leaks/|work=Foreign Policy|date=25 October 2016}}</ref>

The '''King Abdullah Bin Abdulaziz Arabic Health Encyclopedia''' ('''KAAHE''') is an [[Arabic]] public health encyclopedia. It was created in May 2010 by the [[King Saud bin Abdulaziz University for Health Sciences]] (KSAU-HS) in collaboration with the [[Saudi Association for Health Informatic]]s (SAHI). Medical content was added by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), the [[Health On the Net Foundation]] (HON) and the [[National Guard Health Affairs]] (NGHA).<ref>[http://www.kaahe.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=110&Itemid=30 About the Encyclopedia]</ref> 

According to a paper published in [[BMC Health Services Research]], the Arabic content of KAAHE is easy to understand for both experts and consumers. Although, some sections of the encyclopedia can be improved.<ref>Al Aqeel S, Abanmy N, Aldayel A, Al-Khalifa H, Al-Yahya M, Diab M. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5828313/ Readability of written medicine information materials in Arabic language: expert and consumer evaluation]. ''BMC Health Serv Res.'' 2018;18(1):139. Published 2018 Feb 27. doi:10.1186/s12913-018-2944-x</ref>

pages.title: Lakome.com
pages.text:
{{Infobox newspaper | name = Lakome.com | logo = | image = | caption = | type = news website | owners = | founder = [[Ali Anouzla]]
[[Aboubakr Jamaï]] | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = 2010 | political = Independent | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[French language|French]] | ceased publication = 2013 | headquarters = [[Casablanca]], Morocco | circulation = | sister newspapers = | website = {{URL|http://www.lakome.com}} }} '''Lakome.com''' was an Independent Moroccan news website. It was started in 2010 and banned in 2013. ==History and profile== Lakome.com was founded in December 2010 by [[Ali Anouzla]] later joined by [[Aboubakr Jamaï]]. The site had articles in [[Arabic-language|Arabic]] and in [[French-language|French]]. Ali Anouzla was also the editor of the English edition of the website. Aboubakr Jamaï was the editor of the French edition. A laureate of the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]]' [[CPJ International Press Freedom Awards|International Press Freedom Award]]{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/awards/2003/jamai.php|title=Morocco: Aboubakr Jamai|date=2003|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|accessdate=2 February 2012}} and the [[World Association of Newspapers]]' [[Gebran Tueni Prize]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wan-ifra.org/articles/2011/07/07/the-irresolvable-dilemma-of-the-newspaper-publisher |title=The irresolvable dilemma of the newspaper publisher|author=Andrew Heslop|date=7 July 2011|publisher=[[World Association of Newspapers]]|accessdate=3 February 2012}} Jamaï had previously started two newspapers in Morocco, ''[[Le Journal Hebdomadaire]]'' and ''[[Assahifa al-Ousbouiya]]''. His papers were banned by the [[government of Morocco]] on multiple occasions for their explorations of politically taboo topics, and Jamaï soon won an international reputation for independent reporting.{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/16/061016fa_fact_kramer|title=The Crusader|author=Jane Kramer|date=16 October 2006|work=[[The New Yorker]]|accessdate=2 February 2012}} After a series of ruinous libel suits and alleged government pressure on advertisers, however, the papers went bankrupt, with ''Le Journal'' shut down by court order in 2010.{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2010/02/morocco-draft-pioneer-of-independent-press-shut-over-debts-amid-censorship-suspicions-1.html|title=Morocco: Pioneer of independent press silenced amid censorship worries|date=16 February 2010 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=3 February 2012}} When the [[Arab Spring]]-inspired [[2011–2012 Moroccan protests|2011 protests]] broke out in Morocco, however, Jamaï began an web-based news service, Lakome.com. The site had a small staff and focuses on reporting political events throughout Morocco. By April 2011, it was the fourth-most-visited website in Morocco.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/28/world/middleeast/28iht-M28C-MOROCCO-MEDIA.html|title=Web Offers a Voice to Journalists in Morocco|author=Aida Alami|date=28 April 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=3 February 2012}} On 17 October 2013, both the Arabic and French version of the site were closed down in Morocco. The site is now redirected to porn web site. {{cite web|title=Lakome news website still blocked despite editor's repeated requests|url=http://en.rsf.org/lebanon-lakome-news-website-still-blocked-20-02-2014,45905.html|publisher=Reporters without Borders|accessdate=3 October 2014|date=20 February 2014}} As of May 2014, the website was blocked.{{cite news|title=Morocco: Human Rights Organizations Call for the Charges against Journalist "Ali Anouzla" to be Dropped, and "Lakome" Website to be Unblocked|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201405201301.html|accessdate=3 October 2014|work=All Africa|date=19 May 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.lakome.com Official site] (Arabic) {{Media in Morocco}} {{Human rights in Morocco}} [[Category:2010 establishments in Morocco]] [[Category:2013 disestablishments in Morocco]] [[Category:Moroccan news websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2010]] [[Category:Internet properties disestablished in 2013]] [[Category:Arabic-language websites]] [[Category:French-language websites]] [[Category:Censorship in Morocco]]

pages.title: Ma'an News Agency
pages.text:
{{Infobox Network | network_name = Ma'an News Agency (MNA) | network_logo = Ma'an Logo.jpg | country = [[Palestinian territories]] | network_type = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] [[radio]], [[television]] and [[Website|online]] | available = National
International  | owner = | key_people = | launch_date = 2005 | founder = Raed Othman | motto = | past_names = | website = [http://www.maannews.net/eng/Default.aspx www.maannews.net] }} '''Ma'an News Agency''' ('''MNA'''; {{lang-ar|وكالة معا الإخبارية}}) is a large wire service created in 2005 in the [[Palestinian territories]].{{cite web |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewContent.aspx?PAGE=AboutUs |title=About us |publisher=Ma'an News Agency |date= |accessdate=26 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726064643/http://www.maannews.net/Eng/ViewContent.aspx?PAGE=AboutUs |archive-date=26 July 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}[http://isper.escwa.un.org/Portals/0/National%20Profiles/2009/English/Palestine-09-E.pdf National Profile of the Information Society In Palestine] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227080221/http://isper.escwa.un.org/Portals/0/National%20Profiles/2009/English/Palestine-09-E.pdf |date=2013-12-27 }}, [[United Nations]], New York, 2009, p. 13. It is part of the Ma'an Network, a [[non-governmental organization]] media network created in 2002 in the Palestinian territories among independent journalists throughout the [[West Bank]] and [[Gaza Strip]]. It has partnerships with eight local television stations and twelve local radio stations. Ma'an News Agency publishes news 24 hours a day in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[English language|English]], and claims to be one of the largest wire services in the Palestinian territories, with over three million visits per month. Ma'an News Agency also publishes feature stories, analysis and opinion articles. The agency's headquarters are based in [[Bethlehem]] and it has an office in [[Gaza City|Gaza]]. == History == The Ma'an Network was launched in 2002 as a partnership between Bethlehem TV and local Palestinian media organizations. The name ''Ma'an'' is the Arabic word for "together". The group is run by Raed Othman, the former manager of Bethlehem TV. Ma'an has produced three [[soap opera]]s (one of which, ''Mazih fi Jad'' (''Joking Seriously''), was described as the first television drama series produced in the [[Palestinian territories]]), numerous news and public affairs programs and the [[television film]] ''Kafah''. Ma'an's programs are broadcast by ten independent [[terrestrial television]] stations in the [[West Bank]] and occasionally by the [[Fatah]]-run [[Palestine TV]] satellite broadcaster.{{cite journal |last1=Sienkiewicz|first1= Matt|year=2010|title=Hard Questions: Public Goods and the Political Economy of the New Palestinian Televisual Public Sphere|journal=The Velvet Light Trap|issue=66|pages=3–14|publisher=University of Texas Press |doi=10.1353/vlt.2010.0004}}{{cite journal|doi=10.1163/187398610X538696|title=Kafah and the Non-Profit Globalization of Palestinian Media|last1=Sienkiewicz|first1=Matt|year=2010|volume=3|number=3|pages=352–374|publisher=BRILL|journal=Middle East Journal of Culture and Communication}} The Ma'an News Agency was launched in 2005 with funding from the [[Denmark|Danish]] and [[Netherlands|Dutch]] Representative Offices to the [[Palestinian National Authority]]. The news agency is the most visible component of the Ma'an Network. On 15 May, the Ma'an network launched an eCommerce website called [https://swap.stanford.edu/20131109112417/https%3A//www.ms.ps/ Maan Souq]. == Independence == Ma'an News Agency says that it "scrupulously maintains its editorial independence and aims to promote access to information, [[Freedom of speech|freedom of expression]], press freedom, and media pluralism in Palestine." The Ma'an Network was founded with the goal of creating a media source that was free of factional control,{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} unlike the major existing broadcasters such as [[Hamas]]' [[Al-Aqsa TV]] and [[Fatah]]'s Palestine TV.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} In an interview with media scholar Matt Sienkiewicz, former Ma'an [[Chief financial officer]] Wisam Kutom stated that he told potential Ma'an funders that: "Palestinian television is factional television right now we [Palestinians] cannot tell the stories we want to, only the stories the factions will let us. There is no independent television". == Funding == Funding for Ma'an Network comes from advertising revenue and from foreign donors. == 2007 Threat from Hamas == In July 2007, at the time the [[Governance of the Gaza Strip|de facto Gaza Strip government]], MNA alleged that MNA's chief editor had received "direct threats" from [[Hamas]] to carry out a "defamation campaign" against MNA, and to cease its criticism of "the Hamas movement".{{cite news |title=Hamas spokesperson threatens Ma'an News Agency |date=7 July 2007 |publisher=Ma'an News Agency |url=http://www.maannews.net/en/index.php?opr=ShowDetails&ID=23728 |accessdate=30 December 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5dRcUlyum?url=http://www.maannews.net/en/index.php?opr=ShowDetails&ID=23728 |archivedate=30 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == Reach == Ma'an News Agency describes itself as "the main source of independent news from Palestine" and "the premier source of independent Palestinian news on the internet". According to a 2007 survey, 95.6% of Palestinians with internet access "frequently visit" the site.{{cite web|url=http://www.missionramallah.um.dk/en/servicemenu/News/PalestinianMaanNewsAmong1000MostPopular.htm |title=Palestinian Ma'an News among 1000 most popular |publisher=Representative Office of Denmark, Ramallah |date=19 October 2007 |accessdate=26 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115221338/http://www.missionramallah.um.dk/en/servicemenu/News/PalestinianMaanNewsAmong1000MostPopular.htm |archivedate=November 15, 2007 }} As of December 2013, Ma'an News receives the fourth most site visitors in the Palestinian territories.{{cite web |url=http://www.alexa.com/topsites/countries/PS |title=Top Sites in Palestinian Territory |publisher=[[Alexa Internet]] |date=December 2013 |accessdate=26 December 2013}} == Reality TV == In 2013, Ma'an TV (Ma'an Network's satellite channel) broadcast the hit reality show ''[[The President (Palestinian TV series)|The President]]'' in collaboration with [[Search for Common Ground]]. Described as "a cross between ''[[American Idol]]'' and ''[[The Apprentice (TV series)|The Apprentice]]''", audience members would vote through SMS to elect the show's young contestants who competed in mock press conferences, political campaigns, and debates.{{cite web |url=http://www.sfcg.org/programmes/jerusalem |title=Strengthening Palestinian Citizen Participation and Democracy: The President | publisher=Search for Common Ground |accessdate=4 March 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/palestinians-chose-new-president-reality-tv |title=Palestinians Choose A New President On Reality TV | publisher = Associated Press | accessdate=4 March 2014}} == Reliability == An Israeli NGO, [[NGO Monitor]], criticizes Ma'an for regularly re-publishing "non-verifiable or inaccurate claims" from partisan NGOs and for, "subjective, biased reporting."{{cite web|title=The Ma´an Network: Promoting Understanding or a Radical Palestinian Agenda?|url=http://www.ngo-monitor.org/article/the_ma_an_network_promoting_understanding_or_a_radical_palestinian_agenda_|website=NGO Monitor|accessdate=25 November 2014}} [[Palestinian Media Watch]] (PMW) criticized Ma'an for "sanitizing" its English-language reporting while publishing in Arabic reports that “include the hate ideology espoused by the terror organizations that deny Israel's right to exist [and] express reverence for suicide terrorists." In further reports, PMW criticized Ma'an for "demonization of Jews,",{{cite news|last1=Zilberdik|first1=Nan Jacques|title=Venomous Antisemitism published by Palestinian Ma'an News Agency|url=http://www.palwatch.org/main.aspx?fi=157&doc_id=8493|accessdate=25 November 2014|date=30 June 2013}} for publishing news stories in materially different Arabic and English versions,{{cite news|title=Ma`an publishes different accounts of same story; accuses Israel of "Judaizing" Jerusalem|url=http://www.palwatch.org/main.aspx?fi=606&doc_id=10661|accessdate=25 November 2014|publisher=Palestinian Media Watch|date=10 September 2013}} and for [[Holocaust denial]].{{cite web|url=http://palwatch.org/main.aspx?fi=157&doc_id=8493|title=Venomous Antisemitism published by Palestinian Ma'an News Agency|last=Itamar Marcus and Nan Jacques Zilberdik|date=2013-01-30|publisher=[[Palestinian Media Watch]]|accessdate=30 January 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Marcus|first1=Itamar|title=European-funded Ma'an published Holocaust denial|url=http://palwatch.org/main.aspx?fi=157&doc_id=8540|accessdate=25 November 2014|publisher=Palestinian Media Watch|date=11 February 2013}} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'' during the spate of Palestinian stabbing attacks against Israelis in 2015, Ma'an inaccurately reported that a young knife attacker had been "murdered" by Israeli police, (he was wounded and taken for treatment at [[Hadassah Hospital]]), "In a video report accusing Israel of faking evidence of other knife attacks, a reporter for the Palestinian news agency Maan described the clip as evidence of “murder” and claimed in her narration that the video showed the boy lying on the ground when “an Israeli occupation soldier shoots him in the head,” which it does not."{{cite news|last1=Kershner|first1=Isabel|title=Conflicting Accounts of Jerusalem Strife Surround a Wounded Arab Boy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/16/world/middleeast/conflicting-accounts-of-jerusalem-strife-surround-a-wounded-arab-boy.html|accessdate=18 October 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=15 '''''The Majalla''''', often directly transliterated as '''Al Majalla''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]:'''المجلة''', "the magazine") is a [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]]-owned, [[London]]-based political news journal published in Arabic, English and Persian.<ref name=aalawsat1112/> From 1980 to 2009 a print edition was issued weekly, every Sunday. In April 2009 the magazine moved to an all-online format.<ref>{{cite web|title=Social Media in the Arab World:  Leading up to the Uprisings of 2011|url=http://www.hirondelle.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/SocialMediaintheArabWorldCIMA2011.pdf|work=The Center for International Media Assistance|accessdate=25 September 2013|author=Jeffrey Ghannam|date=3 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Gabriel Chahine|author2=Christopher Vollmer|title=The Advent of Digital News in the GCC|url=http://www.strategyand.pwc.com/media/file/Strategyand-Digital-News-GCC.pdf|publisher=Booz & Company|accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref> The online version continues to be published weekly.<ref name=amout>{{cite web|title=Arab Media Outlook 2009-2013|url=https://www.fas.org/irp/eprint/arabmedia.pdf|work=Dubai Press Club and Value Partners|accessdate=15 September 2013}}</ref> 

==History and profile==
''The Majalla'' was launched by [[Hisham Hafiz]] in [[London]] in 1980.<ref name=hh>{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://www.hishamalihafiz.com/bio.htm|publisher=Hisham Hafiz|accessdate=4 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711170851/http://www.hishamalihafiz.com/bio.htm|archivedate=11 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=alt1998>{{cite journal|last=Alterman|first=Jon B.|title=New Media New Politics?|journal=The Washington Institute|year=1998|volume=48|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/uploads/Documents/pubs/PolicyPaper48.pdf|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> The magazine is currently owned by [[Saudi Research and Marketing Group|Saudi Research and Marketing Group (SRMG)]],<ref name=mec>{{cite web|title=Saudi Research and Marketing Group|url=http://mec.biz/term/uploads/SRMG_03112009.pdf|publisher=Money Expert Club|accessdate=4 June 2012|date=November 2009}}</ref> and was reestablished in 1987 by [[Ahmed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Ahmed bin Salman]], then chairman of the SRMG.<ref name=sep11>{{cite news|title=SRMG|url=http://www.majalla.com/eng/print-edition-pdf/al-majalla-issue-1566.pdf|accessdate=14 December 2012|work=The Majalla|date=September 2011}}</ref> The current chairman of the SRMG is [[Turki bin Salman Al Saud]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Saudi Research and Marketing Group appoints new chairman|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2013/02/10/265556.html|accessdate=12 February 2013|work=Al Arabiya|date=10 February 2013}}</ref>

The SRMG owns many other newspapers such as ''[[Arab News]]'', ''[[Al Eqtisadiah]]'', ''[[Urdu News]]'' and ''[[Asharq Al Awsat]]'' and magazines, including ''[[Sayidaty]]'', ''[[Al Jamila]]'', ''[[Arrajol]]'', ''Bassim'' and ''Heya''.<ref name=mepa>{{cite journal|title=Medıa personalıty of the year; AMF honours Saudı Prınce Faısal|journal=MEPA Monthly Bulletin|date=March 2009|volume=31|issue=31|url=http://www.mepa.cc/Pdf/en/mb_march2009.pdf|accessdate=28 May 2012}}</ref> 

''The Majalla'', along with ''[[Sayidaty]]'' and ''[[Al Yamamah (magazine)|Al Yamamah]]'', is among popular magazines in Saudi Arabia.<ref name=saudinet>{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia - Marketing and Sales Strategy|url=http://the-saudi.net/business-center/marketing_and_sales_strategy.htm|work=The Saudi Network|accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref>

===Editors===
Gabriel G. Tabarani served as the deputy managing editor of ''the Majalla'' from 1980 to 1984.<ref>{{cite book|author=Gabriel G. Tabarani|title=Jihad's New Heartlands: Why the West has Failed to Contain Islamic Fundamentalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2HB4cSQS_pgC&pg=PR7|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=16 May 2011|publisher=Author House|isbn=978-1-4678-9180-6|page=7}}</ref> From 1983 to 1987 the chief editor of the magazine was [[Othman Al Omeir]] who currently owns news portal ''[[Elaph]]''.<ref name=themaj2010>{{cite news|title=The Murdoch of the Middle East|url=http://www.majalla.com/eng/2010/05/article5555857|accessdate=2 June 2012|work=The Majalla|date=21 May 2010}}</ref> Then Abdel Rahman Al Rashid served as the editor-in-chief of the magazine from 1987 to 1998.<ref name=emiratesc>{{cite web|title=Abdel Rahman Al Rashid|url=http://www.ecssr.com/CDA/en/ProfileBank/ViewProfile/0,,748,00+en-USS_01DBC.html|publisher=The Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research|accessdate=26 February 2013}}</ref> [[Adel Al Toraifi]] was appointed editor-in-chief of ''the Majalla'' in 2010,<ref name=aalawsat1112>{{cite news|title=Al Toraifi New Editor-in-chief of Asharq Al Awsat|url=http://www.asharq-e.com/news.asp?section=1&id=32123|accessdate=14 December 2012|newspaper=Asharq Al Awsat|date=11 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211060843/http://asharq-e.com/news.asp?section=1|archivedate=11 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the chief editor of the magazine.<ref>{{cite web|title=About The Majalla|url=http://susris.com/the-majalla/|work=SUSRIS|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> In July 2012, Toraifi was also appointed deputy deputy chief editor of ''Asharq Al Awsat'', a daily published by SRMG.<ref name=maj412>{{cite news|title=Adel Al-Toraifi appointed Deputy Editor-in-Chief of Asharq Al Awsat|url=http://www.majalla.com/eng/2012/07/article55232831|accessdate=14 December 2012|work=The Majalla|date=4 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006212216/http://www.majalla.com/eng/2012/07/article55232831|archivedate=6 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His term ended in July 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Adel Al Toraifi|url=http://m.arabianbusiness.com/arabian-business-power-500-2013-493796.html?view=profile&itemid=493998|accessdate=26 June 2014|work=Arabian Business}}</ref> Toraifi's term as the editor-in-chief of the magazine ended in July 2014 when [[Salman bin Yousuf Al Dossary]] was appointed to the post.<ref>[http://english.aawsat.com/2014/07/article55333868/salman-al-dossary-appointed-asharq-al-awsat-editor-in-chief Salman Al Dossary appointed Asharq Al Awsat editor in chief] ''Asharq Al Awsat''. 2 July 2014. Retrieved 19 October 2015.</ref>

==Content==
''The Majalla'' offers the readers an overview of the main weekly news, analysis and exclusive reports with a focus on political affairs.<ref name=gih/> The magazine also provides news from ''[[USA today]]'', ''[[Time Magazine]]'', ''World Monitor'' and ''MEED''.<ref name=gih/>

Because of its close connection with the Arab world, ''The Majalla'' has often broken stories from sources close to militant groups like the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]],<ref>{{Cite news|title=Rage and Reason|author=Remnick, David|work=The New Yorker|date=6 May 2002}}</ref> [[Hamas]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://shaulmishal.com/pdf/sm_academic_10.pdf|title=The Pragmatic Dimension of the Palestinian Hamas: A Network Perspective|page=583|author=Mishal, Shaul}}</ref> and [[Al-Qaeda]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Japan/EK22Dh01.html|title=Japan, Korea new terror fronts|date=22 November 2003|author=Miyazaki, Jamie|work=Asia Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Al Qaeda vows back-breaking strike|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/storyOld.php?storyId=38038|date=27 December 2003|work=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/report-al-qaida-claims-responsibility-for-attacks-1.105744|title=Report: Al-Qaida claims responsibility for attacks|date=15 November 2003|author=Lis, Jonathan|work=Haaretz}}</ref> It also publishes articles written by senior Saudi princes like [[Prince Turki Al Faisal]].

The magazine is also well known for its political cartoons, particularly those by the late [[Mahmoud Kahil]].<ref name=mkahil>{{cite web|title=Welcome|url=http://www.mahmoudkahil.com/|publisher=Mahmoud Kahil|accessdate=4 April 2013}}</ref> These were often critical of [[Israel]] and [[the United States]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Popular Culture in the Arab World: Arts, politics, and the media|page=260|author=Hammond, Andrew|year=2007|isbn=977-416-054-1|publisher=American University in Cairo Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O06bOHRW7s8C&pg=PA260&lp#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Saddam's war of words: politics, religion, and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait|page=165|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0OkasRnU4K0C&pg=PA165&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|author=Long, Jerry M|year=2004|isbn=0-292-70264-7|publisher=University of Texas Press}}</ref> ''The Majalla'' sponsored [[London]]'s first Festival for Arab Caricature in 1989.

===Circulation===
The 1994 circulation of ''The Majalla'' was 116,000 copies.<ref name=krr94>{{cite book|title=Mass Media in the Middle East: A Comprehensive Handbook|year=1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, CT|page=247|url=https://www.questia.com/read/23321484/mass-media-in-the-middle-east-a-comprehensive-handbook|author=Kuldip R. Rampal|editor=Yahya R. Kamalipour; Hamid Mowlana|accessdate=14 October 2013|chapter=Saudi Arabia}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}}</ref> The audited circulation of the magazine at the end of the 1990s is stated to be just under 100,000 copies.<ref name=alt1998/> Its 2009 circulation was 86.961 copies.<ref name=gih>{{cite web|title=Saudi Research and Marketing Group|url=http://mec.biz/term/uploads/SRMG_03112009.pdf|work=Global Investment House|accessdate=28 May 2012|date=November 2009}}</ref>

'''Maktoob''' ({{lang-ar|مكتوب}}) is an online services company founded in [[Amman]] ([[Jordan]]). Maktoob.com was known for being the first Arabic/English [[email]] service provider.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-04-29/syrias-tech-startups-find-a-refuge-in-jordan |title=Syria's Tech Startups Find a Refuge in Jordan |website=Bloomberg.com |date=30 April 2013 |author=Patrick Clark |access-date=17 March 2017}}</ref> In 2009, [[Yahoo!]] acquired Maktoob.com, thus turning Maktoob into Yahoo!'s official arm in the [[MENA]] region.

==History==
===Early days===
Maktoob was founded  in 1999 by Samih Toukan and Hussam Khoury who were able to introduce a [[webmail]] service with Arabic support for emails when no other free email service had such support.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wamda.com/2013/10/case-study-yahoo-acquisition-maktoob |title=The story of Yahoo's acquisition of Maktoob [Case Study] |website=Wamda.com |date=13 October 2013 |access-date=17 March 2017}}</ref> They also helped users who did not have [[Arabic keyboard]] or browsers that support Arabic to send and receive emails by using a [[virtual keyboard]] which was done in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], and using [[Java applet]]s that had better Arabic support.

The initial flourish of Maktoob and its large user base led the company to create several services and content channels for Arab users, many of which were not found previously in Arabic format. Chatting, Greeting Cards, and simple content channels were upon the first to be developed internally. Since then, Maktoob diversified its services through both acquisitions and internal development to have close to 40 different channels and services.

The success of the Maktoob portal drove the company to start new online businesses. [[cashU Inc|cashU]] was founded to address the issue of electronic payments in the region, [[Souq.com]] as an auctions and marketplace; Tahadi.com was founded to provide the best MMO/MMORPG games for the Middle East internet users, [[Araby.com]] an Arabic Search engine; Maktoob Research a successful online research service founded by Tamara Deprez; and Sukar.com the first and biggest online private shopping club in the [[Middle East]], founded by [[Saygin Yalcin]].

===Abraaj Capital acquisition===
In June 2005, the [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]]-based private equity house [[Abraaj Capital]] purchased 40% of the company shares in a USD 5.2 million buyout deal. The rationale for such an acquisition (according to Abraaj's website) is that Maktoob has a large user base (claimed to be more than 4 million) and, according to marketing literature, "a dominant online payment option [[cashU Inc|cashU]] and a strong brand name. It has established the first Arab online auction site souq.com which will benefit from leveraging the large community network."

In April 2006, Maktoob acquired 80% of popular Arab sports website [[Sport4ever]].com.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.albawaba.com/news/maktoobcom-picks-majority-stake-popular-arab-sports-website |title = Maktoob.com picks up majority stakes in popular arab sports website|date = 24 April 2006|work = |access-date = 17 March 2017}}</ref>

In December 2007, Abraaj sold its share to Tiger Global Management with an [[internal rate of return]] of 75%.<ref>[http://www.albawaba.com/en/countries/UAE/220448 Albawaba.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103115355/http://www.albawaba.com/en/countries/UAE/220448 |date=2008-01-03 }}</ref>

===Yahoo!===
In 2009, Maktoob was sold to Yahoo! for $164 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Social Media in the Arab World:  Leading up to the Uprisings of 2011 |url=http://www.hirondelle.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/SocialMediaintheArabWorldCIMA2011.pdf |work=The Center for International Media Assistance |accessdate=25 September 2013 |author=Jeffrey Ghannam |date=3 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928203824/http://www.hirondelle.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/SocialMediaintheArabWorldCIMA2011.pdf |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> In January 2011, email users were migrated from the @maktoob.com domain to the @yahoo.com domain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/thousands-hit-by-yahoo-maktoob-change-to-e-mail |title=Thousands hit by Yahoo Maktoob change to e-mail |website=Thenational.ae |date=14 January 2011 |author=Ben Flanagan |access-date=17 March 2017}}</ref>

In January 2015, Yahoo! let go half of its staff in Dubai, and it announced in December 2015 the closure of its office in Dubai, its last office in the MENA region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/yahoo-close-last-middle-east-office-in-dubai-615619.html |title=Yahoo to close last Middle East office in Dubai |website=Arabianbusiness.com |date=16 December 2015 |author=Neil Halligan |access-date=17 March 2017}}</ref>

The Yahoo! acquisition of Maktoob remains one of the biggest acquisitions in the region, and a success story for other entrepreneurs. Yahoo!'s money made it possible for Souq.com to develop and reach a $1 billion valuation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wamda.com/2015/12/yahoo-closes-but-maktoobs-legacy-continues |title=Yahoo! closes but Maktoob’s legacy continues |website=Wamda.com |date=23 December 2015 |author=Samih Toukan |access-date=17 March 2017}}</ref>

==Activity==
Yahoo! Maktoob provides the following online services: News (''Yahoo! Maktoob News''), sports news (''[[Sport4ever|Yahoo! Maktoob Sport]]''), a blogging platform (''Yahoo! Maktoob Blog''), a social network (''Yahoo! Maktoob As7ab Maktoob''), a bilingual online research community (''Yahoo! Maktoob Research''), a marriage portal (''Yahoo! Maktoob Bentelhalal''), a travel portal (''Yahoo! Maktoob Travel'') and a casual gaming platform (''Yahoo! Maktoob Games'').

'''Masrawy''' (Arabic: مصراوي) is an [[Arabic]] [[Egypt]]ian news [[web portal]] <u>It operates under the ONA institution for press and media which owns YallaKora, ONA and Elconsolto websites and Gemini media company.</u> 

It presents Arabic-language news, commentary, and lifestyle articles directed at the Middle East and wider Arabic-speaking community. It is online-only and presents news across multiple social media platforms.

Magdy ElGalad is the editor-in-chief.

== Services ==
=== News ===
Masrawy covers wide range of news including political, economical, artistic and technology related news.

=== Classifieds ===
Masrawy also provides the largest Arabic video directory, and the largest classifieds channel in Egypt. Also, Masrawy users can deliver their thoughts and voice over Masrawy through dedicated channels for user’s news and articles, Ketabat and Moraselon channels.

=== Women ===
This covers issues as beauty, fashion, cooking, health, jewelry, maternity and kids.

=== Entertainment ===
Entertainment channel, Masrawy jokes, is one of the most viewed channels on Masrawy providing a corner for fun and entertainment including jokes, funny stories, optics and other sections. Plus, Masrawy provides a channel for games providing a wide variety of single and multiplayer games.

===Bulk SMS===
Providing Bulk SMS services for SMEs.

==Audience==
Masrawy was the first most visited website in the [[Arab world]] in 2012 and in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Top websites in the Arab world 2012|url=http://english.forbesmiddleeast.com/details.php?row=2603&list=44465|accessdate=23 February 2014|newspaper=Forbes Middle East}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Jordan Times most active local newspaper in social media — Forbes|url=http://jordantimes.com/article/the-jordan-times-most-active-local-newspaper-in-social-media----forbes|accessdate=23 February 2014|newspaper=Jordan Times|date=23 February 2014|location=Dubai|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140223110055/http://jordantimes.com/article/the-jordan-times-most-active-local-newspaper-in-social-media----forbes|archivedate=23 February 2014|df=}}</ref>

'''''Mena Report''''' ('''''Middle East and North Africa Business Report''''') is a business news source established in 2001 and run by [[Al Bawaba]] ([[Amman]], Jordan, and [[Dubai]]).<ref name=mm>{{cite web|url=http://mediame.com/country/pan_arab/al_bawaba|publisher=MediaMe|accessdate=30 October 2012|title=Al Bawaba}}</ref> It covers business and economics across the [[Arabic world]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dotmena.com/?website=menareport-com-2|title=Mena Report|work=[[dotmena]] |accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref>

==Profile==
The ''Mena Report'' was established in 2001.<ref name=mm/><ref>{{cite news|author=Massoud Derhally|title=MENA Report launched by Al Bawaba|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/mena-report-launched-by-al-bawaba-142212.html|accessdate=20 September 2014|work=Arabian Business}}</ref> It covers economy and trade, IT and telecom, financial markets, oil and energy, agriculture, general industry, retail and services, transport and tourism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comtex.com/loadpublisher.aspx?pagename=Al%20Bawaba--MENA%20Report|title=Al Bawaba MENA Report|work=Comtex News Network|accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref> At time of launch, Menafn.com and Zawya.com provided similar content as  the ''Mena Report''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itp.net/472449-mena-report-launched-by-al-bawaba/?tab=article#.UI6qq2_A_Zc|accessdate=30 October 2012|work=ITP|title=MENA Report launched by Al Bawaba|date=30 May 2001}}</ref> Al Bawaba employs journalists and editors to cover news and events in the Middle East and North Africa. The content is presented on Al Bawaba's own website, and is syndicated to other publishers and aggregators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albawaba.com/Content|title=Content |work=Al Bawaba|accessdate=30 October 2012}}{{failed verification|date=November 2012}}</ref> In 2009 the ''Mena Report'' portal claimed to have 123,409 monthly site visits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mediame.com/sites/default/files/Al%20Bawaba%20Mediapack.pdf|title=Al Bawaba Mediapack|publisher=Al Bawaba |year=2009|accessdate=30 October 2012}}<!-- needs independent source --></ref>

'''Nogoom Masrya''' ({{lang-ar|نجوم مصرية}}<!--ى as written in Egypt-->, {{IPA-arz|nudʒuːm masˤriːah|IPA}}, meaning ''Egyptian Stars'')  is an [[Arabic]] Egyptian independent news [[web portal]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptian Newspapers in Arabic, French, and English|url=https://www.w3newspapers.com/egypt/|website=www.w3newspapers.com|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dmoztools.net/World/Arabic/%D9%85%D8%AC%D8%AA%D9%85%D8%B9/%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A9/|website=Dmoz Archive|title=DMOZ Archive}}</ref> founded in September 2009 by Abdelrahman Ellithy<ref>{{cite web|title=مقابلة مع مدير موقع نجوم مصرية الاستاذ عبد الرحمن الليثي|url=https://news.traidnt.net/2015/03/31/%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%B9-%D9%85%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%B1-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%82%D8%B9-%D9%86%D8%AC%D9%88%D9%85-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%B0/|website=Traidnt|publisher=traidnt.net}}</ref>. The website is best known for being the first revenue sharing platform in the Arab world <ref>{{cite news|title=اثراء المحتوى العربي .. سجل واشترك معنا .. اربح المال من منزلك|url=http://www.elfagr.com/635182|work=بوابة الفجر|publisher=[[El Fagr]]|date=2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Popular Egyptian News Portal Nogom Masrya Emerges as the Top Choice for Adsense Revenue Sharing |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/pr/3615529|website= [[Digital Journal]]}}</ref>

Nogoom Masrya started as an [[Internet forum]] in September 2009 with domain name 100fm6.com and focus on celebrity news. Then, it became popular during the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Egypt beyond Tahrir Square|page=93|url=https://books.google.com.eg/books?isbn=0253023319|language=ar-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Egypt's Long Revolution: Protest Movements and Uprisings|page=153|url=https://books.google.com.eg/books?isbn=1317647785|language=ar-US}}</ref> and  launched a news portal in 2013 in the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{cite web|title=أخبارك.نت|url=http://www.akhbarak.net/sources/286-%D9%86%D8%AC%D9%88%D9%85-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9|website=أخبارك.نت|language=ar}}</ref>

Nogoom Masrya launched its news app on [[App Store]] for [[iPhone]] and [[iPad]] users and another app on [[Google play]] for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] users in April 2018.<ref>{{cite news|title="نجوم مصرية" يطلق تطبيقه الإخباري على منصة "App Store" للأيفون|url=http://www.dostor.org/2160773|agency=Al-Dustour|publisher=[[Al-Dustour (Egypt)|Al-Dustour]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=إطلاق تطبيق "نجوم مصرية" لهواتف الأندرويد على متجر جوجل بلاي|url=http://www.elfagr.com/3085033|agency=الفجر|publisher=[[El Fagr]]}}</ref>

Nogoom Masrya applied new internet technologies like for example: [[Accelerated Mobile Pages|AMP]] (Accelerated mobile pages), using [[HTTPS]] internet protocol and web push notifications.<ref>{{cite news|title=«نجوم مصرية» يطلق خدمة الإشعارات بتقنيات حديثة|url=http://www.vetogate.com/3177710|work=بوابة فيتو|publisher=Veto Gate|language=ar-AR}}</ref> Nogoom Masrya was one of the early sites that adopted these technologies, and this helped in having fast loading pages for users.<ref>{{cite news|title=نجوم مصرية.. موقع مصري يدخل ضمن الـ1000 الأوائل بالعالم بتقنيات متقدمة وإمكانيات بسيطة|url=https://alwafd.news/%D8%AB%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%A9-%D9%88%D9%81%D9%86/1878586-%D9%86%D8%AC%D9%88%D9%85-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%82%D8%B9-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%AE%D9%84-%D8%B6%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%801000-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%84-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85-%D8%A8%D8%AA%D9%82%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%85%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%AF%D9%85%D8%A9-%D9%88%D8%A5%D9%85%D9%83%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%B7%D8%A9|work=Al-Wafd|publisher=[[Al-Wafd]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= How did Nogoom Masrya rank 12 in Egypt? (Arabic) |url= https://www.gomhuriaonline.com/Story/1049715/%D9%83%D9%8A%D9%81-%D8%A3%D8%B5%D8%A8%D8%AD-%D9%86%D8%AC%D9%88%D9%85-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%88%D9%82%D8%B9-%D8%B1%D9%82%D9%85-12-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1 |agency= |publisher= Egypt News}}</ref>

'''''NOW News'''''<ref name="LebWeb">{{cite web|url=http://www.lebweb.com/site/lebanon-nowlebanon-97887|title=NOW News, Lebanon |work=LebWeb|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="onlinenewspapers">{{cite web|url=http://www.onlinenewspapers.com/lebanon.htm|title=Lebanese Newspapers|publisher=Online Newspapers|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="sahafa">{{cite web|url=http://www.sahafa.com/newspapers-and-magazines/lebanon/now-lebanon |title=newspapers and magazines in Lebanon|work=Sahafa|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="Prevention Web">{{cite web|url=http://www.preventionweb.net/english/professional/contacts/v.php?id=9490 |title=NOW News |publisher=PreventionWeb|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="beirut">{{cite web|url=http://www.beirut.com/l/3191|title=NOW Lebanon|work=Beirut|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref> (sometimes abbreviated '''NOW''') is a [[Beirut]]-based Lebanese [[news website]] focused on the [[Middle East]] founded in late 2012 and published in both [[English language|English]] and [[Arabic]] by M Publishing SAL. It used to be known as '''''NOW Lebanon'''''.<ref name=NOWLebanon>{{cite web|title=NOW welcome screen|url=https://mmedia.me/pages/welcomescreen.aspx|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref>

The site offers  reports, news, features, and analysis on [[Lebanon]], the [[Lebanese diaspora]]  and the Middle East. The website offers minute-by-minute news updates as well as a special section and live [[blog]] on the [[Syrian civil war|developing situation]] in [[Syria]].

== History ==
{{refimprove section|date=May 2018}}
On 14 March 2005 an estimated 1 million Lebanese took to the streets concentrated in [[Martyrs' Square, Beirut]] primarily to protest [[Syrian occupation of Lebanon|Syrian military occupation of Lebanon]] and Syrian intelligence and political domination of Lebanon since 1976. The mass mobilization was triggered by widespread unrest following accusations of Syrian involvement in the 14 February 2005 assassination of Lebanese Prime Minister [[Rafic Hariri]].

The New Opinion Workshop (NOW) was created to provide news reports and opinion pieces as well as a digest of relevant news and opinion from a variety of media outlets. It aims to enable [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese citizens]] and the [[Lebanese diaspora]] to stay informed on a wide range of issues.

NOW News is the redesigned website that was known as "NOW Lebanon".<ref name=NOWLebanon/> The change came in late 2012 as the site’s publisher decided to widen the scope of coverage to include the wider Middle East region. 

NOW News has a large online readership mainly from the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[European Union member states|European Union]], and [[Australia]].

Due to financial crisis NOW website was put off air since December 2017.{{fact|date=May 2018}}

== Contributors ==

[[Hussein Ibish]],<ref name="Hussein Ibish ATFP">[http://www.americantaskforce.org/staff/hussein_ibish "[[Hussein Ibish]] on "[[American Task Force on Palestine]]"]</ref> a senior fellow at the [[American Task Force on Palestine]].

[[Michael Weiss (journalist)|Michael Weiss]],<ref name="Michael Weiss HJS">[http://henryjacksonsociety.org/author/michael-weiss/ "Michael Weiss on "[[Henry Jackson Society]]"]</ref> former director of communications at the [[Henry Jackson Society]].

Tony Badran,<ref name="Tony Badran defenddemocracy">[http://www.defenddemocracy.org/about-fdd/team-overview/badran-tony/ "Tony Badran on "[[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]]"]</ref> a research fellow at the [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]]. 

Michael Young,<ref name="Michael Young Daily star">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Michael-Young.ashx#axzz21RLM4HND |title=Michael Young/ Columnists Index |work=The Daily Star (Lebanon)|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref> opinion-page editor of ''[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]]''.

'''Qaym''' is an [[Arabic]]-language review site specialized at user-based reviews on restaurants around the world. It started as a review site mainly for restaurants in the Arabian region. The website runs a [[social network service|social networking]], [[Review site|user review]], and [[Local search (Internet)|local search]] using the second generation of web [[Web 2.0]]. The website is aimed to deliver good restaurant reviews and easy access contents for [[Arab]] readers.

== History ==
*2007: Qaym started as beta version. The beta version was a basic prototype to test the system's performance by selected professional users and normal internet users.
*2008: By early 2008 Qaym was officially released to the public.
*2009: Qaym joined Badir-ICT, a technology [[Business incubator|incubator]] in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>Qaym on Badir ICT website {{cite web|url=http://www.badir.com.sa/en/Client/13 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402095939/http://www.badir.com.sa/en/Client/13 |archivedate=April 2, 2012 }}</ref>
*2011: On March 2011, Qaym raised a round of funding from N2V, a top [[MENA]] [[Venture Capital]] firm.<ref>N2V Announcing Qaym Deal {{cite web|url=http://www.n2v.com/en/article/n2v-invests-in-qaym-com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914211545/http://www.n2v.com/en/article/n2v-invests-in-qaym-com/ |archivedate=September 14, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://arabcrunch.com/2011/03/n2v-invests-in-restaurants-review-site-qaym-com.html N2V Invests in Restaurants Review Site Qaym.com - ArabCrunch]</ref>

=== API ===
*2009: Qaym released a free application programming interface ([[API]]) V.1.0 in April 2009.<ref>[http://arabcrunch.com/2010/07/qaym-launches-improved-design-to-make-critical-decisions-in-the-coming-weeks.html Qaym Launches Improved Design, To Make Critical Decisions in The Coming Weeks - ArabCrunch]</ref> The API provides access to business listing details, reviews, photos, and ratings to a website, widget, or mobile application.<ref>http://api.qaym.com{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The API has been used to integrate business reviews into existing [[Google]] Maps applications.

== Qaym Applications ==
*Sep 02, 2011: Qaym launched its first [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/id460210125?mt=8 Qaym] [[iPhone]] official app on the Apple Apps-Store.<ref>Qaym iPhone App https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/id460210125?mt=8 /Qaym App</ref>
*July 28, 2011: Ahmad Salman, a web developer has created [https://github.com/ahmads/Qaym-API-Class  Qaym-API-Class Resources ] that employs [[PHP]] and [[API]] for web and mobile applications.<ref>Qaym-API-Class Resources by Ahmad Salman https://github.com/ahmads/Qaym-API-Class</ref><ref>Ahmad Salman Website http://as.sa/</ref>
*Aug 26, 2011: Ahmad Salman, a web developer has launched [https://web.archive.org/web/20120402100036/http://asandbox.fluxflex.com/QaymRoulette/ QaymRoulette].<ref>Ahmad Salman Announcing QaymRoulette on Twitter https://twitter.com/a7mads/status/106831979605012480</ref>
*Aug 17, 2010: A group of [[Android (operating system)|Android]] developers have launched an [http://devdroid.org/ Restriod] which is an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] Application.<ref>Resriod on ArabCrunch http://arabcrunch.com/2010/08/restdroid-social-restaurants-review-site-qaym-gets-its-android-app.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903235302/http://arabcrunch.com/2010/08/restdroid-social-restaurants-review-site-qaym-gets-its-android-app.html |date=September 3, 2011 }}</ref><ref>Devdriod website http://devdroid.org/</ref>

== Publicity==
*Qaym was mentioned on Saudi local newspapers such as ''[[Al Riyadh (newspaper)|Al Riyadh]]'' and ''[[Al Eqtisadiah]]'' in April 2009.<ref>[http://www.aleqt.com/2009/04/02/article_210762.html Article About Qaym] 2 April 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.alriyadh.com/2009/04/03/article419783.html Article About Qaym] ''Al Riyadh''. 3 April 2009.</ref> Several remarks was mentioned about Qaym such as that it is one of its kind in Saudi Arabia.
* In 2010, [[Blog]]gers and editors compared Qaym to [[Yelp, Inc.]] as the "Yelp for the Arab word".<ref>[http://arabcrunch.com/2010/07/qaym-launches-improved-design-to-make-critical-decisions-in-the-coming-weeks.html Qaym is the New Yelp of Arabia] TechCrunch. July 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.zawya.com/marketing.cfm?zp&p=/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20100328061146?q=Qaym&cc Join Zawya Business Development & Solutions, Latest Intelligence on Industry] Zawya</ref>

== April Fools ==
On April 1, 2009, Qaym has featured an [[April Fools' Day|April Fools]] prank on the site. It was blocked by the Jordanian government in June 2013. ==Profile== Hashim Al Khalidi is the owner of the website.{{cite news|title=Jordan arrests two journalists on aiding terrorism charges|url=https://cpj.org/2015/01/jordan-arrests-two-journalists-on-aiding-terrorism.php|accessdate=5 June 2015|work=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=29 January 2015}} The [[editor-in-chief]] is Seif Obeidat. Aguado|author2=Meredith Turk |date=14 June 2013}}{{cite news|title=Al Bawaba breaks free: one of the lucky nine websites Jordan '''Sheeel.com''' is a [[Kuwait]]i [[One deal a day|deal-of-the-day]] website generally offering one discounted product a day,<ref name="Sheeel.com FAQs">{{cite web|url=http://www.sheeel.com/faq|title=Sheeel.com FAQ}}</ref> covering several categories such as, Electronics, Household Goods, and Toys. The origin of the website name comes from the [[Arabic]] language, where the word "Sheeel", ([[Arabic]]:شيييل) is the affirmative form of the verb "raise" which is usually used for picking up items or buying goods at bazaars.

==History==

Sheeel.com sold its first deal on January 19, 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mediame.com/news/digital_media/universal_media_launches_sheeelcom| title=Universal Media launches Sheeel.com |first= |last= |date=January 19, 2011|work=Media ME}}</ref>

==Awards==

Sheeel.com was awarded first prize in the Kuwait e-Awards under the e-commerce category,<ref>{{cite news|url=
http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20110612105833/KFAS_awards_EStore_wwwSheeelcom_the_Kuwait_eAwards_2011_within_ecommerce_category| title=KFAS awards E-Store www.Sheeel.com the Kuwait e-Awards 2011 within e-commerce category |first= |last= |date=June 9, 2011|work=Zawya.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.kuwaiteaward.org.kw/show_winners_year_ar.aspx|title= KFAS Kuwait e-Award Winners list | publisher= [[Kuwait e-Awards]]}}</ref> only three months after launch. The Kuwait e-Awards<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.wsis-award.org/contest/national-contests-43820100618|title= WSA NAtional Contest | publisher= [[World Summit Award]]}}</ref> is sponsored by the Kuwait Foundation for the Advancement of Sciences (KFAS), and is arranged in cooperation with the [[World Summit Award]].

==Business==

The website sells one discounted deal a day. The selection of products covers various categories including but not limited to Electronics, Toys, Fashion, Fragrances, Home Medical Equipment, and Appliances. From time to time, the website will randomly offers bonus deals when a daily product sell-out early. The website marketing efforts is focused on driving traffic using social media outlets such as [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]]. In terms of accessibility, Sheeel.com is viewable as a normal website using desktop browser and as a Webapp using Smartphones.

==Geographic markets==

[[File:Persian Gulf Arab States english.PNG|thumb|right|Sheeel.com Regional Coverage]]
Sheeel.com serves all Six [[CCASG|GCC]] markets namely, [[Kuwait]], [[KSA]], [[UAE]], [[Bahrain]], [[Qatar]] and [[Oman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheeel.com/ |title=Sheeel.com |publisher=Sheeel.com |date= |accessdate=}}</ref>

The '''SMART News Agency''' is an independent online [[Arabic]]-language [[media agency]] that mainly operates in [[Syria]]. It is owned by the '''Syrian Media Action Revolution Team''' ('''SMART'''), the largest independent [[Syrian opposition|opposition]] media network operating in Syria.<ref name=age>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2014/09/19/independent-syrian-media-comes-age-time-war-269202.html|title=AN INDEPENDENT SYRIAN MEDIA COMES OF AGE AT A TIME OF WAR|work=[[Newsweek]]|author=Charlotte Eagar|date=9 September 2014}}</ref> Launched in August 2013, the agency releases daily news content, including photographs, videos, and text.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cfi.fr/en/project/structuring-syrias-smart-news-agency|title=Structuring Syria’s “SMART News Agency”|work=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Development (France)|Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs]]}}</ref> As of October 2015, the agency has 300 staff members.<ref name=gen>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globaleditorsnetwork.org/9655|title=The Journalists Risking Their Lives in Syria|work=[[Global Editors Network]]|author=Karen d'Burke|date=29 October 2015}}</ref>

==History==
Syrian activists based in [[France]] established the Syrian Media Action Revolution Team (SMART) in April 2011. One of its co-founders was Chamsy Sarkis, who would later become the founder and [[CEO]] of SMART News Agency. SMART cooperates with other media organizations such as the Association for the Support of Free Media and [[Enab Baladi]].<ref name=gen/> Part of their work included smuggling [[modem]]s into Syria to broadcast content.<ref name=age/>

In 2014, the European Endowment for Democracy based in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] gave SMART a [[€]]129,000 [[grant (money)|grant]].<ref name=age/>

In September 2015, SMART News Agency and Okio Report released an interactive [[virtual reality]] video on the aftermath of the [[Northwestern Syria offensive (April–June 2015)|Battle of Jisr al-Shughur]]. On 26 September, Obada Ghazal, the SMART journalist who filmed the video, was killed by an [[airstrike]] in [[Taftanaz]]. Two days later, SMART's office in [[Deir ez-Zor]] was raided by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] and two SMART staff members were abducted.<ref name=gen/>

In June 2016, SMART News Agency released another VR video, this time on the [[White Helmets (Syrian Civil War)|White Helmets]] in [[Aleppo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.journalism.co.uk/news/how-smart-news-agency-is-telling-stories-from-syria-in-virtual-reality/s2/a651020/|title=How SMART News Agency is telling stories from Syria in virtual reality|work=Journalism.co.uk|author=Catalina Albeanu|date=4 July 2016}}</ref>

'''Sport4ever''' ({{lang-ar|الرياضة إلى الأبد}}) or Maktoob Sport or Yahoo! Maktoob Sport is a sports site contains specialized forums. It is known as the first [[Arabic]] sports site on the Internet and one of the earliest Arabic sites in general.

==History and profile==
The website was launched on 12 October 2000<ref name=bb>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Sport4ever.com|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=62152471|work=Bloomberg Businessweek|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> by Sami Almalki, Adel Almalki, and Imran Athunayyan. In addition to being a news site, Sport4ever contains a rich historical information and a variety of sections like sport reports for players and clubs from around the world. The site incorporates libraries of images, videos, journals, matches schedules and so on. Sport4ever reached its summit glory in 2006 when it became one of the top 600 sites in the world according to [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al-jazirah.com.sa/digimag/01012006/co13.htm |title="الرياضة للأبد" أكبر موقع رياضي عربي متخصص على الإنترنت|publisher=صحيفة الجزيرة|language=Arabic|accessdate=6 September 2012}}</ref>

==Maktoob Acquisition==
On 1 April 2006, and in undisclosed deal, Maktoob announced that it had acquired an 80 percent stake in Sport4ever.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albawaba.com/news/maktoobcom-picks-majority-stake-popular-arab-sports-website 
|title=Maktoob.com picks up majority stake in popular Arab sports website|work=Albawaba News|language=Arabic|accessdate=6 September 2012}}</ref> The process was finalized on 24 April 2006.<ref name=bb/>

'''Superkoora'''  (Arabic: سوبر كورة) is a pan-[[Arab]] [[internet]]-based [[sports]] [[statistics]] [[Web portal|portal]] that proved to be the most searched website in [[Google]]'s 2008 [[Zeitgeist]] or annual report from [[Egypt]]. Superkoora was also the very first Arab website ever listed by Google.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sports and Suzanne Tamim are Egypt's 2008 searches|url=http://www.masress.com/en/dailynews/114324|publisher=Masress|accessdate=23 December 2008}}</ref> It is the largest statistics portal of its kind in the region and is fast becoming a sought-after data and information source for sport media.

== History ==

The online statistics portal was launched in August 2007 with the web domain superkoora.com providing sports results and statistics from all over the world.

== Statistics ==

Superkoora.com contains regional and international [[association football|football]] data and information not available on any other website. This free and accurate information includes: comparisons, data and figures on players, clubs, coaches and matches.<ref>{{cite web|title=يونس محمود على بعد خطوة من معادلة الرقم القياسي في عدد الأهداف|url=http://www.azamn.com/sport/?p=9796|publisher=Azamn|accessdate=21 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=يونس محمود على أعتاب معادلة رقم ناصر كميل|url=http://www.estad-aldoha.net/arabic/vews_view.php?id=61261&hot=1&col=|publisher=Estad|accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> The site also contains a unique list of historic goal scorers for all [[FIFA World Cup]]s. As a result it is often utilized or its data by large media organizations including [[Al Jazeera]]<ref>{{cite web|title=يونس محمود على أعتاب معادلة رقم ناصر كميل|url=http://www.aljazeerasport.net/news/football/2013/04/20134218397343358.html|publisher=Aljazeera Sport|accessdate=21 April 2013}}</ref> Sport. Superkoora2022.com is the newest site launched ahead of the FIFA World Cup [[Qatar]] 2022 to cover sport in that country and has been referred to by, among others, the most popular newspaper in the Arab World, London-based [[Asharq Al-Awsat]].<ref>{{cite web|title=موقع "سوبر كورة 2022": الهلال الأكثر مشاركة في دوري أبطال آسيا|url=http://www.aawsat.com/details.asp?section=21&article=718862&issueno=12510#.UdPeX_nfCSr|publisher=Aawsat|accessdate=27 February 2013}}</ref> Contributors to Superkoora's English site include author and former [[BBC]] sports reporter, Keir Radnedge, Steph Clark, sports journalist and blogger, [[Ben Lyttleton]] and Will Scott. Superkoora was appointed the official media partner of the 2011 [[Golden Foot]] Award in [[Monaco]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Goldenfoot Partners|url=http://www.goldenfoot.com/partners.html|publisher=Golden Foot|accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref>

== Founder ==

[[Egypt]]-born, Abdelaziz Younis Abuhamar is the founder of superkoora.com. He is a bilingual [[journalist]] with 20 years of experience in the field of sports media.

'''''Syria-News''''' is an online [[press agency]] intended to report news about [[Syria]]. Their website features several categories of news (domestic, regional, political, and economical) as well as reports and questionnaires that concern Syrian issues. It enables users to comment on most of the news, as well to send contributions; in both cases, they can be published only upon approval.

''Syria-News'' was launched in late 2003, and at that time publishing an online press agency was not straightforward in Syria where most websites featuring political news about Syria were blocked. This gave it a semi-official status, since it was approved by the [[Syrian government]], and the participation of some ministers confirmed this status.

The website has become quite popular in Syria, as an approved portal to discuss domestic issues.

In 2006, the official domain name of their website was hijacked, but soon later retaken.

On February 18, 2008, all Syrian ISPs blocked domestic access to the site and its alternate URL www.news-sy.com. Access was restored by March 6, 2008, though there has been no official statement from the site or Syrian authorities.
